loans.name: Katalina

texts.en:
Katalina is a member of the Mgodi North borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 46-year-old woman, married, and the mother of six children. Her children are aged 34, 32, 29, 27, 23, and 20 years.

Katalina started her own business selling charcoal two years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Katalina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 TSH in order to buy charcoal. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Katalina hopes to save money, get more food for her family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita O. is from the village of Lantay, Valencia City Bukidnon. She is 41 years old. Teresita is married and has adult-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. She also has a sideline business, which is peddling dried fish in the nearby village. But the main source of income for Teresita's business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a loan which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business and supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie T.'s main source of income comes from selling seafood products, including a variety of dried fish, in her community. She is 39 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Lantay, Valencia City, Bukidnon. Jessie has been in this business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jessie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Jessie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of her family and support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma is a member of the Amani East borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 25-year-old woman, married, and the mother of two children. Her children are aged 7 and 2 years.

Mwajuma started her own food business selling bananas and tomatoes three years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Mwajuma’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 TSH in order to buy more bananas and tomatoes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Mwajuma hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, bananas and fruits

loans.name: Naseema Group

texts.en:
Naseema is the group leader of Naseema Group. There are four members in this group. Each of them wants to take out a loan for expanding their businesses and making them larger, so they are requesting a group of loan. 

Naseema wants to take a loan for her husband who is a taxi driver. 
Faraba wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a burger and ice cream shop. 
Zaui Gul wants to take out a loan for her son who has mobile selling card. 
Lilaw wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a general store. 

They are very thankful for Kiva lenders that can support all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: For expanding business

loans.name: Carl Harvey

texts.en:
Carl Harvey B. is from the village of Barangay Poblacion, Iligan City. He is 24 years old. Carl Harvey is single. To make a living, Carl Harvey owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling snacks like barkeron in the local community. Carl Harvey is just starting this business.

In July 2009, Carl Harvey joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carl Harvey is requesting a new loan which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Carl Harvey from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

Fe is requesting a new loan which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Fe from HSPFI. location.town: Poblacion, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita A. is 41 years of age and is happily married to Rufino, who is a 42-year-old farmer. The two were blessed with four children whose ages range from 19 to 12 years old. All of her kids are in school and are accumulating bigger amounts of expenses each year. Through a business she has been growing for 19 years, she has been able to sustain her children's education. 

Carmelita's hog (pig) breeding and fattening (raising a pig for four months and selling after that) business started to grow when she availed a loan after she became a member of ASHI five years ago. Just recently, she sold eight piglets - which were the piglets of her raised pig amounting to PHP2,500. Aside from having a gilt (mother pig), she also has two hogs for fattening.

Because of the success she found in her business, the loan she is applying for will be used to purchase more piglets to raise and another gilt. She hopes that her business will prosper and that she can start up another business supported by the profit from her hog raising and breeding business so that she can employ some of the members of her family, especially her mother in- law.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and a gilt

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Area Five borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 40-year-old woman, married, and the mother of three children. Her children are aged 19, 14, and 10 years. She also cares for one other dependent. 
Maria started her own business selling food 10 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Maria’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 TSH in order to buy rice and beans. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Maria hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice and beans

loans.name: Virgena

texts.en:
Virginia O. is a 25-year-old mother of two children. She is raising pigs to support the needs of her family. What she is doing in her business is buy a piglet and then let it grow bigger and bigger before selling it to her regular customers. 

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 5,000. She will use the loan to purchase three sacks of feed. The loan will really help her achieve a better income from her business.

Now, she actively participates in the CEVI cluster meetings. She receives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase three sacks of feed

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea C. is a 55 year-old woman.  She lives in the Takeo province.  She is married and has two children.  To make a living, Chea is starting a farming business.  She typically makes US$1 each day and would like to increase her profits. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. 

These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Chea Chim included. She is asking for a loan of US$400 to purchase fertilizer for the farm and a cow, increasing her current profits and prospects for the future.  (She pictured with her son from home)

loans.use: To purchase cows

loans.name: Friah

texts.en:
Friah E. is from the village of Barangay Poblacion, Iligan City. She is 29 years old. Friah is single and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Friah owns & operates a business venture in the food sector, making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling processed food products like dressed chicken and longganisa (sausages) to the local community. Friah has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 Phillipine pesos a month for these activities.

In July 2009, Friah joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Friah is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Friah from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education and to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell.

location.town: Poblacion, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Khadam Ossian

texts.en:
Khadam Ossian, son of S. A., lives in Kabul, Afghanistan.

He has a family of six, and he owns a shop that sells fuel. Khadam Ossian has requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani in order to expand his business.

He is confident that the loan will allow him to increase his business.

loans.use: To expand his retail business, which is a shop that sells fuel.

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn P. is a 22 year old farmer from Trento, Agusan Del Sur. She is married to Noel P. and is blessed with one child. Now she is helping her spouse on the farm. They are tilling a 1.5 hectare farm and have toiled so hard to achieve an abundant harvest. 

She would like to ask for a loan worth Php 6,000. She will use the loan to purchase 3 sacks of rice seeds and 4 sacks of complete fertilizers.

Now she is joining with the other entrepreneurs in their village. She receives not just loans but training and insurance coverage services as well.

loans.use: To purchase 3 sacks of rice seeds and 4 sacks of complete fertilizers

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is a member of the Mgodi Center borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 44-year-old woman, is widowed, and is the mother of one child aged 27 years. She also cares for one other dependent.

Yolanda started her own food business three years ago selling sugar and fruit. She works fifteen hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Yolanda’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more soap, sugar and fruit. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Yolanda hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fruit, sugar and soap

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda T. is from the village of Barangay Poblacion in Iligan City. She is 40 years old. Imelda is married to Derek and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda owns and operates a business buying and selling fish in the local community. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In July 2009, Imelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be Imelda's 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and support her children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

location.town: Poblacion, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Phaiy

texts.en:
Phaiy S., 29, pictured with her husband, is married and lives with three of her children in the Takeo province. Two of the children are in school and one is too young to attend.

Phaiy S. works as a professional tailor and typically makes US$3 every day. Her husband, Ouk Reaksmey, typically makes US$10 each day as a construction worker, building houses. Phaiy S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase construction materials for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for her husband

loans.name: Soeung

texts.en: The woman in the picture is 49-year-old Soeung S.. She resides in Siem Reap Province where she earns a living planting various crops. Soeung S. was married, but her husband died of senility many years ago. She is now a single mother blessed with a son. Her son teaching English at a private school and provides his income for the family's needs. Soeung S. saw that her son finds it hard riding to work or anywhere else, because he doesn’t have his own vehicle. She is, therefore, applying for a $200 loan to purchase an old motorbike for her son to ride to work.

loans.use: To purchase used motorbike

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida P. is a rice grower. Though its really tough work, she continues doing it because this their only source of livelihood. Until CEVI came, she wasn't able to get started on her additional business which is pigs.

To purchase certified rice seed, and three sacks of complete fertilizer are the purpose why she would like to apply for a loan from CEVI. Part of the loan will also be used to support her little piggery.

While its true that its expensive to start a business now, it is not too difficult because of the micro-financing efforts of CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase certified seeds and three sacks of fertilizer

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:

To make a living, Evangeline owns & operates a business providing beauty services and reflexology to local community members. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In July 2009, Evangeline joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Evangeline's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and supplement her family's income.

Mirasol has been engaged in her business for over a years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

location.town: Del Carmen, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza P. is 37 years old and is married to a fisherman named Joseph. The two are blessed with four children aged from 11 years to one year old. The beautiful town of Culasi in a province where mountains meet the sea – Antique, is where they reside.

While her children are still young, Flordeliza and her husband are working hard to have savings so that someday they will be able to purchase some land of their own and will be able to build a house that is comfortable to live in for their children. Flordeliza also wishes to have the opportunity of sending all of her children to school until college – the opportunity that she never had. 

In 2002, Flordeliza joined ASHI and obtained her first loan. The loans she obtained, from then until the present, support her farming (rice-growing) business. She and her husband have been farming a rice field owned by someone in their village. They were allowed to farm the said land provided they spend their own money and they have to pay back sacks of rice to the owner. This system is called "arriendo" and this is usual for most people in the province who do not have a rice field of their own. 

Because of the opportunity of loaning she has with ASHI, Flordeliza has stayed away from another system of obtaining capital which is called "alili", wherein someone will lend money to a farmer and, after harvest, a sack or sacks of rice, depending on the amount borrowed, will be given to the lender.

Flordeliza is happy for the opportunity given to her by ASHI and she wishes that she can finance a larger rice field to farm someday to increase her profit.

loans.use: To pay for land preparation, fertilizer, seed, insecticide and pesticide

loans.name: Manolo

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum P. is a 56-year-old woman. She lives in the town of Takeo province and is married and has two children. Sum P. was not available for the photo and so her husband is pictured instead.

Together, Sum P. and her husband hire out chairs, tables and other items when there is a wedding taking place. Sum P. has been engaged in this business for over thirteen years and they typically make a combined income of about US$5 per day. The couple is also supported by two of their children who are working. 

Sum P. joined CREDIT MIF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting for the first time a loan from CREDIT. She is requesting a loan of US$1,200 which will be used to invest in expanding the business.

This is Jeni’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Jeni hopes to save money and expand her business.

texts.en: Lem V. is a 26-year-old father who has been blessed with a lively young child. He currently helps provide for his family by driving a motorcycle taxi, while his wife plants vegetables for additional profit. Using his personal vehicle, Lem picks up people who need to travel in and around the community. However, his income is limited due to the motor's small size and unattractiveness. Lem is requesting a $500 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL to purchase a trailer and paints. He is planning to connect the interestingly painted trailer to the existing motor. The trailer will create new seats and allow Lem to pick up more passengers.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea Y. N., 57, is a widowed woman who runs a business on her own as a food (green papaya and some other types of vegetable mixed together) and soy-milk seller living in the Battambong province; she typically makes US$6 every day and is aided by her daughter who works in a garment factory with an income of US$3 per day.

N. wants to operate another business for her family members to generate more income to cover her family’s expenses and to save more income to repair her house. That is why she has approached CREDIT with a request for a loan. N. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase clothes, a purchase that she sees as a good opportunity to resell them at a fairly profitable price to increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Theopista

texts.en:
Theopista is a member of the Amani East borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 30-year-old single woman and she cares for one dependent.

Theopista started her own restaurant business selling food two years ago. She works 15 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Theopista’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, wheat and sugar to her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Theopista hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly A. is from the village of Zone 1B, Del Carmen Iligan City. She is 56, married and has 4 adult children. Beverly owns & operates a business selling beauty products and medicinal products from companies such as Avon, Natasha and Vita Plus. Beverly has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month.

In July 2009, Beverly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beverly is requesting 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family's basic needs and supplement their income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Zone 1B, Del Carmen, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Mean S. C., 28, has four young children and lives in Battambong Province with her husband, Tun Narith (pictured).  C. stays at home and looks after her children.  One of her children is enrolled in a local primary school while the rest stay at home because they are too young to attend school. Her husband is a construction foreman and generally earns an income of US $7.5 per day to cover the family expenses.  C. is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike with a trailer as a mean of transporting builders their work sites.

loans.use: to purchase a bike and trailer

loans.name: Eplida

texts.en:
Epleda A. is 54 years old and is married to a farmer named Lolito. The two are not blessed with many children. However, they are very happy to have at least one child, who is now ten years old. Epleda does not want anything in life other than to give her only child a better living, by allowing them to reach a higher level of education and to live in a better house someday. The best way Epleda thinks she can achieve her dream for her child and to make herself happy is to have her own business. 

There is land owned by Epleda's family that can be used for agricultural purposes. Epleda joined ASHI to get a loan to enable her to maximize the land by planting rice. With the help of her husband, their business has grown. Her loan amounts have increased since she was able to repay previous loans and maintain very good performance with ASHI.

Recently, Epleda applied for a loan for her new business endeavor, a hog fattening business. However, she will continue her farming business with a portion of her loan. Hog fattening is just Epleda's way of diversifying in case her farming business defaults and she needs capital.

loans.use: buying piglets and fertilizer

loans.name: Trong

texts.en: Trong L. is 25, married and has one child who attends school. His wife stays at home; she is responsible for daily housework, cooking, and caring for their child. She also grows different kinds of vegetable for sale. Trong L. works driving a truck for a small firm, but for a long time he has had difficulty with transportation in getting to work, because his workplace is far from his house. He therefore requests a loan in order to buy a motorcycle, to make it easier to get to work, and also to help his family’s traveling needs.

loans.use: To buy a vehicle to make it easier to ride to work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cloth to sell

loans.name: Khun

texts.en:
Khun O., 65, is a widow living in Battambong province with her four children. She is a cleaner in a hotel in the town and makes about $5 USD a day, but it is not enough to support her family so two of her children send money every month from their work in garment factories. The global financial crisis has had unfavorable consequences for Khun O.'s family's standard of living, and inflation has been high. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, O. included.

In light of these difficulties, Khun O. is asking for a loan of $1000 USD to purchase new sewing machines for members of her family. She sees these new sewing machines as a great economic opportunity for her. She believes that the machines will help to both increase her income and improve her standard of living. (One of her daughters is shown in the picture.)

loans.use: To purchase new sewing machines

loans.name: Rey Micho

texts.en:
Rey Micho A. is from the village of Zone1B, del Carmen, Iligan City. He is 44 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children. For a living, Rey Micho owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector--raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, raising pigs for sale is the primary source of income. Rey Micho has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6000.00 PHP a month.

Rey Micho joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services and help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rey Micho is requesting a loan of 5000.00 PHP which he will use to purchase additional animals. This will be his first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to support the education of his children."

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. Based in Cagayan de Oro City, HSPFI is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional animals

location.town: Zone 1B, Del Carmen, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en:
Nergui D. is a 71-year-old married man. He lives with his wife, Pagamjav, 66, in Harhorin, the ancient Mongolian city. The couple have three children, all of whom have graduated from university and now live on their own. In 2006, when Nergui was 68 years old, he started a small manufacturing business making wooden furniture for the home. He usually makes beds, chairs and tables for 'ger' district residents or herders who live in a ger. (A ger is a nomadic housing tent that is easy and simple to build or remove for migrant populations.) He also makes clothing boxes as people who live in gers have no closet, and they keep their clothes in a wooden box instead.

Nergui's business is his family's only source of income besides a small amount of pension and government stipend. Nergui used to work at home, but with the profit from his business he built a simple house as a working space on the plot of land on which he lives. Nergui's wish is to teach one of his sons to become a carpenter so that he can continue the business in the future. He is requesting a loan to purchase unprocessed wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase unprocessed wood for his business

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim P. has been growing various crops on her own farmland since early 2005; she inherited the land from her grandparents years ago. She is 34, married, and has three children who are in primary school. To help meet her family’s needs, her husband works by playing traditional Khmer music for wedding parties. Sim P.’s husband complains that he has trouble with transportation getting to his work,  because he doesn’t own a vehicle. Because of this problem, Sim P. decided to take out a loan to buy a new motorbike for her husband, so that he can get to work.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her husband, so he can drive to work

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena R. is a native of Jala-jala, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 34 years old and mother to three. She is married to Abelardo, a tricycle driver, 32 years old. She is a woman of courage and faith to overcome poverty.

She believes that the greatest gift in the world is opportunity; that is why in 2001, when she was given the opportunity to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, she really grabbed the chance. Since her first loan, she invested her loans in the resale of ready-to-wear clothes. These include school uniforms and blouses among many others.

Now on her 9th loan, she proposes a loan of 19,000 pesos as additional capital to pay for resale of school uniforms, 10 dozen blouses and polo shirts, 5 dozen skirts and 5 dozen black pants. And part of her loan will be invested in her secondary business: a variety store.She is positive that her business will grow since it catches the attention of the buying public.

With the proceeds she receives, she really dreams of saving for their future and for her children’s school needs, and she also dreams of building a small restaurant someday.

loans.use: resale of school uniforms, 10 dozen blouses and polo shirts, 5 dozen skirts and 5 dozen black pants

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy recharge cards to sell

loans.name: Jhenalden

texts.en:
Jhenalden B. is from the village of zone1B, del Carmen, Iligan City. He is 30, married and has 4 school-aged children. Jhenalden owns & operates a business providing cellphone repair services to the local community. Jhenalden has been engaged in his business for over 6 years and earns approximately P12,000 PHP a month.

Jhenalden joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jhenalden is requesting 5000 PHP,  which he will use to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be his 1st loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Zone 1B, Del Carmen, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita J. is a 50-year-old persistent and courageous woman working to step out from poverty. She is married to Domingo, a 64-year-old jeepney driver. She is a mother to three sons; two are of legal age already and the youngest is 13 years old.

In 2006, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with the hope of having access to capital for her business. She invested her previous loans in the buy and sell of charcoal and a Sari-sari Store (General Store). But years ago, she opted to invest in a jeepney which until now serves as her primary business.

Now on her 6th loan, she proposes the amount of 30,000 pesos to pay for sacks of charcoal and maintenance of their jeepney (purchase tires, renewal of licenses, etc.). She is hopeful that their business would bring her good income to sustain the needs of her family. She dreams sending her youngest child to college until he finds job.

loans.use: To pay for sacks of charcoal and maintenance of their jeepney (purchase tires, renewal of licenses, etc.)

loans.name: Dorj

texts.en: Dorj G. is a 38-year-old, married, father of one. His family lives in a rental apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city. His spouse Bujidmaa, 38, is unemployed. His only daughter Bujmaa, 16, is a local high school student. Dorj has been running a transportation business during the last 5 years. When he started his business he used to rent a mini bus from others for use as public transportation. Two years after he started his business he could save enough money to purchase a second hand mini bus. Since then he's been using his own mini bus for his business. He says that "My family's living condition has improves a lot since i started running transportation. Now i will start saving small amount to own an apartment in the future." With this loan Dorj will buy spare parts for his mini bus.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his mini bus.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy spare parts to sell

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta A. is a mother to four children. She is 55 years olds and widowed but she has a business partner Noli, who is her brother. She hails from the busy town of Morong, Rizal province in the Philippines. She has perseverance and determination within her to come out from poverty.

Her desire to pull out her family from the spiral of poverty has driven her to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2000. During her membership, she was noted of being one of the most active and with exemplary performance in ASHI.

Her previous loans were invested in her computer shop business. Every time she receives a loan, she put them in the shop as additional capital. Now on her 11th loan, she proposes a loan of 30,000 pesos as additional capital for her computer shop. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for 2 sets of brand new computer as additional units in her shop. She believes that her business will grow since the use of computer shops is in demand by students.

Her dream in life is to expand her business and be able to purchase additional computers, hire labor, and also help her grandchildren with their school fees.

loans.use: To pay for 2 sets of brand new computer as additional units in her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy an embroidering machine and a sewing machine

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita S. is a 70 year old woman who lived in Hamtic, Antique with her 69 year old husband and three remaining unmarried children ranging in age from 18 to 14. Lolita dreamed of giving her children a better education. However, she failed because she had no opportunity at the time of having loan for a business capital.

When Lolita became a member of ASHI in 2007, her hopes for the two children that are still studying were rekindled. She started up a business raising and selling livestock. After years of loaning, her business eventually grew and now she wishes to buy a carabao and another pig to raise and sell in a given period of time. She wishes to raise a greater variety of livestock someday so that she can also help her children send her grandchildren to school.

loans.use: A carabao and piglet to raise

loans.name: Gladys Kezia Magana

texts.en:
Gladys K., 24 and single, has operated the business of providing phone service to the public for the past five years on Odinga Street in Eldoret Town. She owns a booth equipped with mobile phones that customers can use to make calls from for a fee and also sells prepaid mobile phone cards to people who own their own phones

With the money from this loan, Gladys plans to buy more calling cards for her business as well as detergent for resale, another business she is engaged in. In the future, she intends to diversify by starting a wholesale business. She also hopes to be able to buy a plot of land within Eldoret and to be able to pay school fees for her sister.

Gladys was introduced to KADET by an acquaintance who was already a KADET client.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more calling cards for resale and business use.

loans.name: Francis Nzioka

texts.en:
Francis, 27 years old and married with one child, has been in the business of buying and selling timber for the past six years. His business is located in the Kimumu suburb of Eldoret Town. Francis was introduced to KADET by his friend who is a KADET client. With this loan, he plans to buy more wood for his business as well as new equipment and tools.

Francis hopes that in future he'll be able to diversify his business and begin making furniture. He wants to be able to educate his children as fully as possible, and would like to send them to university or college.

About KADET The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more wood for a timber shop, and new equipment and tools.

loans.name: Ven

texts.en: Ven B. is 37, married and lives in Siem Reap Province. Her husband works in construction. They have four children who are all in school.  To earn a living, Ven B. raises many pigs in a stall behind her house. She normally sells all her mature pigs for slaughter three or four months after she begin feeding them. Because raising pigs is a very profitable business for her family, Ven B. requests a loan to use as capital to purchase pig food and additional small pigs to raise.

loans.use: To purchase pig food and additional small pigs to raise

loans.name: Amani West Group

texts.en:
Sophia is a member of the Amani west borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 32-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of two children aged 8 and 2 years.
 
Sophia started her own business selling sugar, rice and wheat two years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 80,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Sophia’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more soap, rice and wheat. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Sophia hopes to save money and expand her business.

Valelia, the other member of the Amani west borrower group, has also requested 200,000 Tsh in order to support her own business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities to sell

loans.name: Gecelie

texts.en:
Gecelie J. is from the village of Zone1B, del Carmen, Iligan City. She is 22, married and owns & operates a a food stall, where she sell a variety of fruits to the local community. Gecelie has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately P15,000 PHP a month.

Gecelie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gecelie is requesting  5,000 PHP, which she will use to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Zone 1B, Del Carmen, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
Araceli B. is 44 years old and mother to four; two girls and two boys. She is happily married to Rodel, 49 years old and a tricycle driver. She is full of determination to cut the bonds of poverty that hinder her way and her family's to success. She lives in Angono, Rizal province in the Philippines.

With her desire to look for a greener living, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, just recently with a bagful of hope to have access to capital to start a business. Her first loan was invested in a sari-sari Store (general store) as her primary business and part was used in her secondary business: hog raising.

Her businesses went well and seem to bring her enough income for their living. Now on her 2nd loan, she proposes the amount of 10,000 pesos to pay for sacks of rice, cases of soft drinks, canned goods and groceries for her store. And again, a portion of her loan will be used as additional capital for her secondary business: hog raising.

Araceli's aspiration in life is to be able to send her children to school until they finish college and find jobs. She dreams also of expanding her business someday.

loans.use: To pay for sacks of rice, cases of soft drinks, canned goods and other groceries for her store

loans.name: Amani West Group

texts.en:
Demetelia is a member of the Amani West borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 33-year-old woman, married, and mother of 4 children. Her children are aged 18, 15, 12, and 6 years old.

Demetelia started her own shop 8 years ago. She works 14 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 80,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Demetelia’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Demetelia hopes to save money and expand her business.

Veronica, another member of the Amani West borrower group, has also requested 200,000 Tsh in order to support her own business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities

loans.name: Nyamdavaa

texts.en:
Nyamdavaa B. is a 49-year-old married man who has two sons aged 20 and 11. His family lives in a ger (nomadic housing tent) district in Arhangai, one of Mongolian central provinces. His spouse Surenjav, 49, used to work as a teacher for a local elementary school. Unfortunately, because of the financial crises, she was let off. His elder son Anhbayar, 20, is a college student and the younger one Erdenebat, 11, attends elementary school.

Nyamdavaa has been running a carpentry business since 2004. He started his retail business with the working capital of 40,000 tugrugs (~ 30 USD). As a result of his hard work, his business inventory has increased and reached 250,000 tugrugs. In 2005, with the profit, he bought a plot of land. He usually makes home furnishings and sells them to local residents. Sometime he gets orders from herders. He is requesting a loan to purchase raw materials to increase his business inventory.

loans.use: to purchase raw material for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open a pub

loans.name: Chuong

texts.en:
Chuong L. is a 63-year-old woman. She lives in a town in Takeo province. She is a widow and has 2 children. Years ago, Chuong was a local doctor; now retired she still provides health services in her village. Chuong had been engaged in this work for over 25 years. From this activity, Chuong earns approximateL. 8,000 riel about US$ 2 a day. She is aided by her two children who are construction workers.

Chuong joined CREDIT MFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Chuong is requesting for the first time a loan from CREDIT. She is now requesting a loan of US$ 400. The current loan will be used to purchase a motorbike for her sons for commuting to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona is 42 years old and is married to a farmer named Avelino. They have four children ranging from 16 to 3 years old now. All of them are studying except for the youngest.

In the municipality of Hamtic in the province of Antique, most people are into the rice production business, as are Chona and her husband. Chona started this kind of business when her brother in- law gave her money for capital in 2003. However, the capital was not enough to grow the business. In 2007, Chona found out about ASHI and she became a member of said institution. She had the opportunity to borrow and expand her business from then on until she was able to set up another source of income while waiting for the harvest: her variety store.

Chona is so happy that she has a variety store. It has brought convenience to people in their community especially during the harvesting period. Furthermore, Chona wishes that, together with her farming business, her variety store will grow and will generate bigger profit. By then, she will be able to send all her children to school until college. This is Chona's greatest dream.

loans.use: Fertilizers, chemicals for killing pests, insects, and grass, and rice seedling; and part for her ongoing variety store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy pork

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock his shop

loans.name: Zainab A.

texts.en:
Here is Zainab A. B., a local entrepreneur in the northern city of Makeni. She is both a medical nurse and a businesswoman. She sells ready-to-wear clothes, mobile phones, and DVDs. Zainab wants a loan of Le 3,000,000 in order to improve her business.

Thirty years old, Zainab has been a businesswoman for barely a year now. She decided to augment her nursing profession with little petty trading in order to supplement her meager monthly salary. Zainab was born in Yele village, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married with two children. One of her children is in junior secondary school and the other in primary school.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add to her savings to buy a piece of land to cultivate rice

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
ELSA C., is 50 years old, married with 5 adult children, and lives in Purok Kakahuyan, Brgy. Daga in the outskirts of Cadiz City, Negros Occidental.

Elsa and her husband have been ambulant fish and crab vendors for the past 15 years and this earns them on the average, PHP 5,000 per month.

In 2000, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, and the loans that she borrowed over the past nine years have had a great impact in stabilizing the financial situation of their family.

Now on her 13th loan cycle, she wants to use the PHP 11,000.00 additional capital to increase their volume capacity in the fish and crab vending business to enable them help financially support immediate members of her family.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: additional capital for the borrower's fish and crab vending business

loans.name: Penh

texts.en: Mrs. Penh S. lives in Preak Doung village in Kandal province. She is employed in a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Ma Ma Dy, is a flour middleman in the local market. Since his business is doing well, he wants to expand his business. Thus, Mrs. Penh S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more flour to sell to earn more profit. This couple has four children, two of whom are goldsmiths while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is present in the picture with her.

loans.use: buy more flour to sell to earn more profit

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr: Essi E. est une femme de 43 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle est propriétaire d’un bar restaurant à Lomé. Elle désire avec ce deuxième crédit, améliorer la taille de son commerce en approvisionnant son magasin et aussi élargir son espace de réception.
texts.en:
Essi E. is a 43-year-old woman, married, and the mother of three. She is the owner of a bar-restaurant in Lomé. She would like to use this second loan to better the size of her business by stocking her store and also to enlarge her reception area.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock her store and to expand

loans.name: Houn

texts.en:
Mrs. Houn S. is a villager in Chrouy Dang village in Kandal province. She makes Khmer cake to sell. She is 58 years old, a widow with three children, two of whom are grocers and own a grocery store while the other is a worker in Korea.

Although Mrs. Houn S.'s family members have different careers, they still earn too little income to support their household. Thus, Mrs. Houn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets for breeding to earn more income.

loans.use: buy piglets for breeding to earn more income

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata S. is a small-scale businesswoman in the city of Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. Fatmata is requesting a loan of Le 3,000,000 from Kiva lenders in order to boost her business. With the help of a loan, Fatmata will be able to expand her business so that both sales and profit will improve for her. As such, Fatmata’s living standard will improve; she will be able to better look after herself, her children, and other family members.

Fatmata is thirty-two years of age. She was born in Makeni and is married to a businessman; they have four children. Two of her children are in Junior Secondary schools and the other two are in primary schools. Fatmata sells ground-nuts; palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), pepper and other locally produced market-food. She has been a businesswoman for ten years now.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Warlyn

texts.en:
Warlyn A. is from the city of Oroquieta. She is 26 years old. Warlyn is married and has 3 very young children. To make a living, Warlyn owns and operates a sari-sari store (general store). The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Warlyn has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Warlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Warlyn has successfully repaid previous loans from PMPC. Warlyn is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 25th loan taken out by Warlyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg D. is a 41-year-old, married and a mother of two children. Her family lives in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She has fully repaid her first Kiva loan, which will appear on www.kiva.org in August when the repayments are posted online.

Altantsetseg is a professional tailor. She runs a sewing business out of a 10-square-meter rented room. In 2007, she started her business by buying a sewing machine and fabric that cost MNT 40,000 ($1.00 USD=1,450.00 MNT). Her business has been successful ever since and has allowed her to purchase three more sewing machines and hire two tailors. Her working capital has grown from 40,000 MNT to 1.5 million MNT. Her daily income now is around 1.0 million MNT.

Altantsetseg gets many orders due to the lack of competing businesses in her area. With her profits, her husband built a 40 sq. meter house on the plot of land that they own. Before her business flourished, she lived in a "ger" (traditional, nomadic form of tent housing) in the local ger district. One of her sons goes to elementary school, the other one is a university student. She is requesting a loan to repair and expand her house. With this loan she will purchase building material.

loans.use: To purchase building material

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia B. is a 47-year-old mother of three children. She is a farmer and rice is her main crop. She helps her husband till a 1-hectare farm. She dreams that someday she will be able to buy a a hand tractor for them to use in the farm.

The reason why she is applying for a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI is that she will be buying one sack of fertilizer and paying the laborer in their farm.

Now, she actively joins the CEVI cluster meetings and takes advantage of the services such as loans, training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase 1 sack of fertilzer and pay the laborer

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Mrs. Concepcion D., 41 years of age, is a resident of P-6 Gango, Ozamis City, married to Mr. Edmund D. and blessed with 3 children. To complement the income of her husband, she decided to engage in a gardening and vegetable and fish vending business in the year 1988 with an initial capital of P 2,000 only.

Now, she is earning an average monthly net income of not less than P3,000 from her business. In July 2008, she joined PAGLAUM MPC and was able to access loans and other services offered in our cooperative. Being responsible in her account, she finished the term with a good credit record, and now she is applying for the amount of P10,000 to add to her capital for her business. She expects to be able to earn more in order to sustain the needs of her family, especially in food. She is planning to own a stall in the market.

loans.use: Additional capital for her gardening and vegetable and fish vending businesses

location.town: P6 Gango, Ozamiz City, Mis. Occ.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Mrs. Thav Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank which consists of eleven members is located in Ta Nu village in Kandal Province. The members plan to use the loans they obtain for different purposes.

Mrs. Thav C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a laborer who has been hired by the villagers. She owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to cultivate rice in the field. Thus, Mrs. Thav C. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She is a 37-year-old widow and the mother of a child who is attending the local school.

Mr. Orn A. was not available when the photo was taken, so his wife appears on his behalf.

loans.use: To fund cultivation of rice.

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Mrs Ludivina D., 38, is a resident of P4 Gango, Ozamiz City. She is married to Roel D., a construction worker, and they are blessed with four children. One of her children is in high school, two are in elementary school, and the other is an infant. In order to help her husband support the family, Ludivina set up a business selling fruit and vegetables two years ago with an initial capital of only 1,000 PHP. Now, her business has grown bigger and she is earning an average net income of 5,000 PHP a month from her sales.

Ludivina joined Kiva partner, PMPC, in September 2007, and her membership has proved very helpful to her as she has been able to avail herself of the cooperative's products and benefits. Now on her third loan cycle, she is applying for a loan of 10,000 PHP to add to her existing fruit and vegetable business. Her only dream in life is to give her children a better future and be able to expand her business some day.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her fruit and vegetable business

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda D. is 43 years old and has four children. She raises pigs and also has a sari-sari (general) store business. She is engaged in these businesses to help provide for the growing needs of her family. Erlinda is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase two sacks of pig feed and two additional piglets.

CEVI helps small business to grow. Through CEVI, Erlinda and other CEVI clients are able to sustain their livelihood through credit, training and insurance cover.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of pig feed and two additional piglets

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Coconut trading is the new source of livelihood for Mrs Maria C.. She is 63 years old, married to Crispin C., and blessed with five children. She now has only one dependent, a daughter, as her other four children are already married. Her husband is a farmer who manages and cultivates his own cornland for their consumption and sometimes for sale. He is also sometimes her partner in the coconut trading business.

Maria started her coconut trading business in September 2008 with an initial capital of 1,500 PHP from her savings. Her neighbors were her first coconut suppliers. In addition to this business, Maria also has a piggery business, with one sow and twelve piglets. Now on her third loan cycle, she is applying for a loan of 14,000 PHP to purchase feed for her little piggery and additional capital for her coconut trading business. Her dream for the future is to become a successful trader and hog raiser.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her piggery business and additional capital for coconut trading

loans.name: Proeung

texts.en: Mrs Proeung N. lives in Moeun Tra village in Kandal province. She is a widow with two children. One of her children is a beautician who owns a small beauty shop, while the other is a driver. Since her first child’s business is doing well, Proeung N. wants to expand it by purchasing more beauty supplies. Therefore, she decided to request a loan for this purpose. She hopes to increase the beauty shop's income and improve the business

loans.use: To purchase more beauty supplies

loans.name: Mrs Saran Pich Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is for 24 people living in Preak Ta Kaev village in Kandal province. The members of this group will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs Saran P. is 60 years old and the village bank president. She is a mat maker and owns her own business. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it but she does not have enough money to buy the necessary raw materials to make the mats. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She hopes to improve her family's living conditions with this loan. Mrs Saran P. has three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is a farmer.

Nineteen members in this group have end-of-term (EoT) loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. In EoT loans, the borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make mats

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Akossiwa K. est une femme de 42 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle est revendeuse des tenues prêt à porter à Lomé. Elle exerce ce métier depuis 4 ans et souhaite avec ce crédit accroître la taille de son commerce en achetant de nouveaux produits pour la revente.
texts.en:
Akossiwa K. is a 42 year old woman, married and the mother of 2 children. She sells ready to wear clothing in Lomé. She has been practicing this trade for 4 years. She wishes to use this loan to increase the size of her business by purchasing new items to resale.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ready-to-wear clothing for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To change his car's engine

loans.name: God's Grace Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 35, divorced, and has two daughters who are in school. She is very dedicated to her family. She is a food vendor and sells rice with gravy stew in her community. She started her operation about ten years ago in order to take care of her home. However, her food production is on a low scale because of inadequate funds to support her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more meat, vegetables, and bags of rice, to increase her efficiency in producing larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business, to raise more income to support the growth of her business and for her children's education. 

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘God’s Grace’. She is the one sitting in front in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and for peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat and firewood etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and resell pagnes (colorful African cloth)

loans.name: God Is Great Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 35 years old and a divorced mother of two kids. The children are currently in school. She is a petty trader who trades in used clothes and has been in business for the past three years. Used clothing has a very big market in Ghana as brand-new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore, the selling of used clothing has created opportunities for many women like Elizabeth. 

She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her save for her children's education and for renting a store as she now sells through hawking.

She is the leader of a trust bank group called "God is great." She is the one sitting in front in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and as peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing

loans.name: Yesu Tease Group

texts.en:
Philomena, a 28-year-old petty trader, is divorced with one son. Currently her child is in school. She is a very resourceful mother whose hard effort brings livelihood to her home. She is a used clothing and soap seller. Selling used clothing is a very big market in Ghana as brand-new clothes are very expensive for the economically active poor. Therefore selling of used clothing has created a market for many women.

Philomena has been in this business for the past two years. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing and detergent to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her save for her child's future and also to rent a store.

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Yesu Tease’ which literary means 'God lives'. She is the one sitting in front in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing and soap

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is 24 years old; she is currently single and seriously preparing herself for Mr. Right. She is determined to raise her business to a higher level. To achieve that, she does not play with her work; she has been selling cosmetics with products like spray, powder, lip gloss, blouses etc. She sells on the top of a table in a community market. She has been in business for three years now. She says selling cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make good income. She is sure that your loan support will bring her to the desired results.

loans.use: To buy bulk stocks of cosmetics

loans.name: Mavis

texts.en:
Mavis is 24 years old. She is currently single and seriously preparing herself for Mr. Right. She is determined to raise her business to a higher level. To achieve this, she does not play with her work. She sells cosmetic products like sprays, powders, lip gloss, blouses, etc., on top of a table in a community market. 

She has been in business for three years now. She says selling cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore, she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make a good income. She is so sure that your loan support will bring her the desired results she expects.

loans.use: To buy bulk stock of cosmetics

loans.name: Boafo Ne Nyame Group

texts.en:
Sophia is married and mother of three children. Currently, two of her children are in school whilst her last born is still breastfeeding. She is a 35-year-old petty trader who sells clothing materials. She is very hard-working woman who works very hard to cater for herself, her children and her business backed by her husband's support. She sells cloth for sewing garments, shoes, slippers, and lace materials. She started her business three years ago. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations.

Sophia treks to Kumasi to buy her stock of goods. For lack of adequate working capital she buys little because of inadequate funds. She sells her goods at the community market center. For this reason she requests a loan to make business progress. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level.

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Boafo Ne Nyame’ which literary means 'Our helper is God'. She is the one sitting in front in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase bulk of lace materials and textiles

loans.name: Lustica

texts.en:
Lustica is a member of the Bingwa borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 36-year-old woman, is single, and is the mother of three children aged 22, 19 and 14 years.

Three years ago, Lustica started her own cafe business selling food. She works fifteen hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Lustica’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, wheat and sugar. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Lustica hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, wheat and sugar

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Rebeca is married and mother of two girls. Currently both her children attend school in the community where they live. She is 34 years old and a petty trader who trades in clothing materials. She is a very hard-working young woman who works to cater for herself and her business. She trades in cloth for sewing clothing, shoes, slippers and lace materials. She started her business sixteen years ago. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations.

Rebeca treks to Kumasi to buy her stock of goods. For lack of adequate working capital she buys little because of inadequate funds. She sells her goods at the community market center. For this reason she requests a loan to make business progress. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level.

loans.use: To purchase bulk amounts of lace materials and textiles

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a business woman and has ten years' experience in sales. She sells Dumas clothes, linen, and lace materials. She is 43 years old, married, and lives with her husband. She has five children who are currently in school. She helps support her family through her sales business. She is very hard-working and time-conscious but progress has persistently been low due to insufficient funds.

Victoria hopes the loan will enable her to revive the business and make more viable profit. She wants to purchase bulk quantities of Dumas clothes, linen and lace materials to increase her inventory. It is her desire to rent a store in the community market. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase bulk quantities of Dumas clothes, etc. to increase her inventory

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is a 40-year-old woman. She is married with seven children; four are currently in school. She is a food vendor and sells 'banku' and rice balls ('omotuo'). 'Banku' is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. She has many customers since it is enjoyed by many Ghanaians as breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to raise increased income to support her children's education. She has been in business for five years now and believes with her rich experience, she can improve her sales.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Ushirikiano Group

texts.en:
Anna is a member of the Ushirikiano borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 20-year-old woman, is single, and is the mother of one child aged 4 years.

A year ago, Anna started her own clothing business selling clothes. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Anna’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Anna hopes to save money and expand her business. 

Maria, the other member of the Ushirikiano borrower group, has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to support her own clothing business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married and a mother with four children. She is a 38-year-old petty trader and her husband is also a petty trader. All her children are in school. She sells lace materials, textiles and clothing materials. She takes her stock of goods from importers in Kumasi central market. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations. For lack of adequate working capital, she buys only a little lace materials and sells through hawking. She sells during the markets days in the surrounding market communities.

She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level. With the loan, she wants to purchase bulk quantities of lace materials and textiles. She hopes to use part of her profit to rent a store and also save the larger part for the children's education.

loans.use: To purchase bulk quantities of lace materials, clothing materials and textiles

loans.name: Hadiango

texts.fr: Hadiango B. est âgée de 36 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle achète des moutons qu’elle revend dans sa localité et aux environs. Son objectif est d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Hadiango B., age 36, is married and the mother of 4 children. She buys sheep that she resells in her village and in the surroundings. Her goal is to improve the living standard of her family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell sheep

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is forty-five years old; she is a married woman with three children. Her eldest child is in the polytechnic, one has finished the senior high school whilst her last-born is still schooling. She has been in business for fifteen solid years; this has given her a lot of experience in selling and record-keeping in business.

Comfort sells cereals such as maize and other food items. She buys from the farmers directly at a relatively low price. She sells at the local market in the town where she lives with her family. She also treks with some of her goods to nearby markets to sell as well. She says she wants to use the loan to buy the goods in bulk so that she can distribute to a number of customers. She dreams of saving more to give her children better education.

loans.use: To buy more cereals

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 36 years old; she is married and a mother with two children. Her children are currently in school. To support her household, she has been hawking and selling cosmetics in her neighborhood to her loyal customers. She says selling of cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make good income for the family’s needs.

Rita walks very long distances to make sales; sometimes she does that by hiring a taxi to carry her goods. She is therefore appealing for your assistance to make good sales and take care of her home. She dreams of suffering for her children so as to provide them with education.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of cosmetics

loans.name: Tabu

texts.en:
31-year-old Tabu is a member of the Maendeleo borrowing group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a single mother of 2 children, aged 10 and 14 years. She also cares for 2 other dependents. Tabu started her own salon 1 year ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tanzanian Shillings.

This is Tabu’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more equipment for her salon. With the additional profits she gains from the use of this loan, Tabu hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more equipment for her salon

loans.name: Adèle

texts.fr: Adèle D. est âgée de 48 ans, veuve et mère de 3 enfants. Elle fait un commerce de légumes et divers produits tropicaux. Elle souhaiterait renforcer le capital de son activité pour mieux subvenir et améliorer les besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
Adèle D., age 48, is a widow and the mother of 3 children. She sells vegetables and various tropical products. She would like to bolster her working capital to better support her family, and to improve its standard of living.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell vegetables and tropical products

loans.name: Unique Group

texts.en:
Joseph started his fish and meat business four years ago in a market where he currently lives. He treks to rivers and village hunters to purchase his stock. He buys stocks of fish from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Many people buy from him in the marketplace. He is 43 years old, married, and the father of three children. Currently two of the kids are schooling and his first-born is learning a trade. He is asking for the loan to buy increased stocks of assorted fresh fish and bush meat to make increased sales and income to support his children's education and business growth.

Joseph is the one sitting in the red chair in the group photograph. He is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Unique’. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors, and/or farmers. They request the loan to upgrade their businesses to increase sales. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy bulk quantities of fish and bush meat

loans.name: Saphina

texts.en:
Saphina is a member of the Sokoni borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 40-year-old woman, is separated from her husband, and is the mother of four children aged 25, 23, 21 and 14 years.
 
Four years ago, Saphina started her own food business selling vegetables. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Saphina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more vegetables. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes, bananas and potatoes

loans.name: Okamafo Jesus Group

texts.en:
Gilbert is a 42-year-old man. He is married and has four children, two girls and two boys. All his children are in school, and he works hard to provide for the children's education.

Gilbert is an achiever and a resourceful father for his household. He loves selling goods, the business through which he makes a living. He sells foodstuffs like bunches of plantains and cassava. He treks to surrounding villages in the community to purchase bulk stocks of cassava and plantains from the farmers. He also packages them and treks them to the city of Accra where they go for more money. For lack of adequate working capital, he is not able to pick up enough stock to make his business profitable to support his family. With the loan, he wants to purchase bulk supplies of plantains to enable him to scale up his business growth.
