texts.fr: Thérèse F. est une femme célibataire de 45 ans. Elle fait de la couture et du petit commerce. Elle aimerait augmenter son capital et mieux subvenir à ses besoins.
texts.en:
Thérèse F. is a 45-year-old unmarried woman. She is into dressmaking and petty trading. She would like to increase her capital and better provide for her needs.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Dressmaking and petty trading

loans.name: Josefa

texts.es: La Señora Josefa P. tiene 57 años tiene 7 hijos y ninguno depende de ella. La actividad económica de Josefa es la venta y elaboración de repostería. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. Ella dio inicio a su negocio por generar a su familia los ingresos necesarios para salir adelante, a pesar de las dificultades que presento como fue el tiempo, por lo que tenía que cuidar sus hijos, y al mismo tiempo salir a vender sus productos pero esto no le impidió salir adelante. El motivo del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de materia prima como huevos, harina, mantequilla entre otras cosas. Su mayor sueño es establecer su propio lugar de venta de repostería.
texts.en:
Josefa P. is 57. She has seven independent children. Josefa makes and sells baked goods. She has been doing this for five years. She started the business to generate the income needed to get her family ahead. In spite of the difficulties that presented themselves, like having to take care of her children and leave to sell her products at the same time, she was not deterred from getting ahead. She is asking for a loan to buy raw materials like eggs, flour, shortening, and other things. Her biggest dream is to establish her own place to sell her baked goods.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ngalla Sona

texts.fr: Ngala Sona S. est une mariée de 54ans, mère de 3 enfants. Elle vend des rafraîchissants à domicile et à l’école à proximité de chez elle. Elle prépare aussi et vend le petit déjeuner. Les revenus générés lui permettre de régler ses factures d’électricité et d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ngala Sona S. , age 54, is married and the mother of 3 children. She sells berverages at home and in a school near her home. She also prepares breakfast to serve as part of her business. The income generated will enable her to pay her electricity bills and improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Selling berverages and preparing breakfast to serve

loans.name: Liliana Teresa

texts.es: Doña Liliana se enuentra en su septima secuencia en su credito indiidual, la señora ha trabajado junto a la Institucion desde el año 2007 adicionalmente cuenta con un credito paralelo en el que se encuentra en su segunda secuencia nunca ha presentado problemas en sus pagos.  La actividad economica que realiza es la venta de desayunos en el Mercado yungas de la Cuidad de La Paz, la señora comienza su jornada de trabajo desde muy temprenas horas de la mañana.  Ella vive con sus hijos y su esposo quien cuenta con un trabajo fijo y colabora on los gasto generados dentro de la familia.  La cliente invertira el dinero del prestamo en la compra de insumos para su puesto de venta y cambiara algunos artefactos (calderas y tazas).
texts.en:
Liliana is in her seventh individual loan cycle. She has worked with the Institution since 2007. She also has another loan in its second loan cycle. She has never had problems with her payments. She sells breakfast in the Yungas market in the city of La Paz. She starts her trip to work in the very early hours of the morning. She lives with her children and her husband, who has a steady job and contributes to the family expenses. She will use the money from the loan to buy supplies for her sales location. She will also buy some new utensils (kettles and cups).

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for her sales location

loans.name: Reina Elizabeth

texts.es: Reina Elizabeth B. D. V. resiD. en Cojutepeque departamento D. Cuscatlán. Madre soltera D. 30 años D. edad, vive con su hija Estefani D. 3 meses D. edad, Reina posee un negocio es una venta D. flores naturales en el mercado municipal D. Sensuntepeque , con 10 años D. experiencia en su negocio Reina posee una clientela estable, pero Reina desea aumentar sus ventas surtiendo  su negocio no solo con flores naturales si no que también vender artificiales, es por eso que hoy solita este crédito , para comprar dichas flores por las que sus clientes solicitan a menudo, y así lograra aumentar sus ventas, que le serán D. gran ayuda para la crianza D. su bebé.
texts.en:
Reina Elizabeth B. D. V. lives in Cojutepeque in the Cuscatlán department. She is a 30 year old single mother. She lives with her three month old daughter, Estefani. Reina sells live flowers in the Sensuntepeque municipal market. She has ten years of experience in the business, and Reina has a stable customer base. However, Reina wants to increase her sales by stocking her business with artificial flowers as well as live flowers. That is why she is now asking for a loan to buy artificial flowers. Her customers ask for them frequently. This way she will increase her sales, which will be a big help in raising her baby.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her store with artificial flowers

loans.name: Marlin Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Marlin del Socorro Hernández C. se dedica al negocio de venta de ropa usada, la cual vende en su casa y también de forma ambulante. Ella actualmente es soltera, tiene 50 años, y no tiene hijos. Ella empezó con este negocio desde hace 15 años, ya que su hermana le regalo una paca de ropa en ese tiempo para que se ayudara con sus gastos. De ese tiempo, ella decidió invertir parte de su dinero a la venta ambulante de ropa usada. Actualmente está solicitando este crédito para la compra de más mercancías de ropa. Cabe señalarse, que la señora recibe ingresos adicionales ya que trabaja medio tiempo como maestra en una escuela de primaria de Jinotepe. Su sueño siempre ha sido llegar a tener una tienda grande de ropa usada  para trabajar todo el tiempo en ese negocio.
texts.en:
Doña Marlin del Socorro Hernández C. has a business selling used clothing from her home and also door-to-door. She is 50 years old, single and does not have any children. She started her business 15 years ago when her sister gave her a bale of clothing to help her with her expenses. Since that time, she decided to invest part of her earnings to purchase more used clothing to sell door-to-door.

Today, she is requesting a loan to increase her inventory of clothing. It should be pointed out that Doña Marlin earns additional income working part-time as an elementary school teacher in Jinotepe. Her dream is to open a large clothing store so that she can work full-time in this line of business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.es: Rosalina G. D. M. resiD.  en el municipio D. San Martin departamento D. San Salvador. La Sra. Rosalina tiene 50 años D. edad, vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos D. los cuales dos son mayores D. edad y trabajan, y su otra hija flor D. 11 años D. edad es estudiante, Rosalina tiene una tortillería y una tienda en su casa donD. posee  15 años D. experiencia, en su colonia es muy conocida es por eso que mantiene una clientela estable, ahora Rosalina solicita un crédito para comprar  maíz utilizado en las tortillas y para surtir su tienda.
texts.en:
Rosalina G. D. M. lives in the San Martin municipality in the San Salvador department. Rosalina, 50, lives with her husband and their three children. Two children are grown and working. Her third child, a daughter, is an 11 year old student. Rosalina has a tortilla shop and a store in her house. She has 15 years of experience, and she is well known in her colony. She, therefore, has a stable customer base. Rosalina is now asking for a loan to buy corn to use in making the tortillas and to stock her store.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn and stock her store

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Doña Rosa se encuentra en su decimo cuarta secuencia trabajando junto a la Institucion durate todos sus creditos siempre a demostrado ser una persona responsable, trabajadora y con ganas de superacion.  La actividad economica que realiza la cliente es la venta de Produtos de belleza esta actividad la realiza en oficinas del centro de la ciudad entregando sus productos a credito,.  Ella vive con su nieta la cual estudia en la universidad y con su hijo quien la ayuda con los gastos de la casa.  La cliente invertira el dinero del prestamo en la compra de productos de belleza que se encuentran en oferta para asi porder ganar un porcentaje mas alto cuando los venda, ademas tiene pedidos para aros de promocion.
texts.en:
Ms. Rosa is in her fourteenth cycle working with the Institution. During all of her loans she has always shown herself to be a responsible, hardworking woman with a desire to excel. She sells beauty products in the offices downtown where she delivers the products on credit. She lives with her granddaughter, who is going to university and with her son who helps her with the household expenses. She will invest the money from the loan into buying beauty products at a better price so that she makes a higher profit when she sells the products.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase promotional materials for her store

loans.name: Yanaturo Alto (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Yanaturo Alto esta ubicado al oeste de la ciudad de Cuenca, aproximadamente 15 minutos fuera de la urbe, vía a Lazareto sector del Carmen, en este lugar sus habitantes se dedican en su mayoría a la agricultura, crianza de animales, existen fábricas de velas, sombreros y mecánicas industriales que brindan trabajo a personas que desean trabajar en el sector, por ser un sector elevado a comparación de la ciudad, el desnivel del terreno y por ser un sector semiurbano todo el día sopla un fuerte viento que es lo que hace que los niños permanezcan en su gran mayoría dentro de sus casas, este banco esta conformado por 12 mujeres trabajadoras, organizadas y bien llevadas, se dedican a diferentes labores sean en la casa o fuera de ellas, es así por ejemplo citamos unas de ellas:
Sra. C. I. Blanca Celestina
Blanca tiene 27 años de edad, es casada y tiene tres hijos de 9,7 y 1 año, los dos primeros estudian en la escuela del sector que lleva el nombre de Yanaturo, el esposo se dedica al arte de la joyería en la ciudad, la casa donde vive y realiza las reuniones cada 15 días ya que ellas es presidenta del Banquito Comunal es arrendada, cuenta que tiene casa propia por el sector pero aún no termina, posiblemente a unos dos meses se pasa a su propia casa, Blanca se dedica exclusivamente a quehaceres domésticos, los fines de semana y cuando la soliciten realiza comidas a domicilio o en su propia casa, le gusta cocinar hace mucho tiempo, aprendió más o menos hace unos 10 años cuando trabajaba en el restaurant Balcón Cuencano, todo lo que le piden ellas los realiza y cuenta que tiene mucha acogida ya que su comida es muy sabrosa.
El crédito que Blanca solicitó a la Fundación ESPOIR fue de 440 dólares, los cuales  invirtió adquiriendo una cocina industrial, ollas, trastos y otros materiales que se necesitan para sus labores, su meta en el futuro es poder terminar su casa y en la misma ponerse un local de comidas (restaurant).
Sra. C. Guamán Cecilia Del Rocío
Cecilia es oriunda del Puyo al Oriente del Ecuador, vive en Cuenca 23 años, su esposo es también del Puyo, es de 33 años de edad, casada y tiene cuatro hijos de 15,10,8 y 3 años, los tres primeros estudian el uno en colegio y los otros dos en la escuela, Cecilia se dedica a la costura, no es todavía profesional esta aprendiendo todavía, ya lleva esta trabajo más o meno unos 4 meses, trabaja con la señora Pilar S. que es también socia del banquito, ella la invitó a que se integre al banco, es su primer crédito y cuenta que es muy beneficioso ya que con lo que ha pedido el crédito de 330 dólares ha podido comprarse una máquina de coser y telas con las cuales trabaja. Como todavía no sabe bien trabaja con una socia  doña Pilar ella la enseña, realiza pantalones, blusas, vestidos, y en especial ropa deportiva por lo que necesita comprar telas licra circuito que esta a 5.80 dólares la yarda, su horario de trabajo es de 8 a 12 y de 2 a 5 de la tarde y cuando tienen obras se quedan también los fines de semana hasta la madrugada, aprovecha los fines de semana para adelantar más el trabajo ya que su esposo como es chofer de una compañía descansa los fines de semana y le ayuda en casa con las ocupaciones. Su meta es poder aprender bien la profesión y ponerse un taller independiente en su propia casa.
Sra. I. Zumba María Ángeles
María tiene 55 años de edad, es casada y tiene 12 hijos, entre 30 y 10 años, ya ni se acuerda cuantos años tienen cada uno de ellos, los cuatro hijos están en el colegio, tres en la escuela, y los mayores trabajan y son casados, vive en una casa arrendando porque la suya no pudo terminar solo esta comenzada, su esposo se dedica a la agricultura y cuando no tiene trabajo la ayuda en casa, María se dedica a la casa, crianza de animales, a lavar ropa ajena y también a la agricultura, los fines de semana a partir del día jueves sale a lavar ropa de las vecinas que le pagan 1 dólar por cada docena de prendas que lava, cada cobija cobra 0,50 centavos de dólar y 0,25 centavos las casacas. Es oriunda de Santa Ana una parroquia de Cuenca, vive en Yanaturo ya unos 18 años, pidió 330 dólares de préstamo para comprar ganado (yunta) debido a que se van acercando las siembras utilizan la yunta para arar, su meta es seguir luchando en la vida y poder terminar su casita para poder descansar en paz sin tener que estar pensando cada mes en el arriendo.
texts.en:
The Yanaturo Alto Communal Bank is located west of the city of Cuenca, about 15 minutes away, and lies in the area of Lazareto del Carmen. The residents of the area are engaged primarily in agriculture and animal husbandry. There are factories that produce candles, hats and industrial machinery, and provide work to anyone who wants a manufacturing job similar to those found in larger cities. Children spend most of their time inside because of the unevenness of the land and the strong winds that blow all day long. This group consists of 12 women, all of whom are organized and well-mannered. They are devoted to different business activities, carried out both within and outside of the home. Here are some examples:

Sra. C. I. Blanca Celestina: Blanca is 27 years old, married, and has three children (ages 9, 7, and 1). The two oldest children attend school in the Yanaturo area. Her husband works in the city as a jeweler. The communal bank gathers at her house every 15 days for their meetings because she is the group president. She currently leases her home, but will own it outright in about two months when she completes the payments. During the week, Blanca spends most of her time on household chores. On the weekends or whenever people ask her, she prepares food at her customer’s house or in her own home. She learned to cook about 10 years ago when she worked at a restaurant called Balcón Cuencano. Everything she makes is well received because the food is quite tasty.

Blanca is requesting a loan of $440 USD from Fundación ESPOIR to buy pots, industrial kitchenware, and other materials needed for her work. Her future goal is to finish her house payments and, at the same time, open a restaurant.

Sra. C. Guamán Cecilia Del Rocío: Cecilia is a native of East Puyo, Ecuador and has lived in Cuenca 23 years. Her husband is 33 years old and also from Puyo. They have four children (ages 15, 10, 8 and 3). The first three children are students, one in high school and the other two in elementary school. Cecilia spends her time sewing, which she has been doing for about 4 months. She is not a professional yet, but is still learning. Sra. Cecilia works with Sra. Pilar S., who is also a communal bank member, and asked to be part of the group. Her first loan was very beneficial because she used her $330 to buy a sewing machine and fabric. Although not yet known for her work, she is learning from Doña Pilar how to make trousers, blouses, dresses, and sportswear. She needs to purchase lycra fabric, which costs $5.80 per yard. Her work schedule runs between 8am-12pm and 2pm-5pm. She also works on the weekends during the morning. She is able to get much accomplished on the weekends because her husband helps with the household chores. He works as a company driver and is off on the weekends. Cecilia’s goal is to continue learning her craft and open a workshop in her home.

Sra. I. Zumba María Ángeles: María is 55 years old, married and has 12 children between the ages of 10 and 20. She doesn’t remember the exact ages of each of them. Four of them are in high school, three are in elementary school, and the older ones are working and married. She lives in a rented house because her family cannot complete the construction on their own. Her husband is a farmer, and when he is not working, he helps around the house. She spends her time performing household chores (including washing clothes), raising animals, and cultivating crops. Starting on Thursdays and through the weekend, she washes clothes for neighbors. She charges $1 per dozen garments, $0.50 for blankets, and $0.25 for jackets. María is a native of Santa Ana, which is a parish in Cuenca. She has lived in Yanaturo for 18 years. She will use her loan of $330 to buy livestock that she will yoke together to plow her fields. She plans to fight through life’s struggles and hopes to own a house so that she can rest peacefully and not have to worry about the rent each month.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase livestock and other materials

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es:
El señor Roberto V. esta casado con la señora Natalia Alcaraz con quien tiene 4 hijos.
Roberto se dedica a la compra y venta de CD de músicas y películas hace ya varios años, luego gracias a las ganancias que le genero este trabajo el pudo montar en su casa una despensa y ya van dos años de mucho éxito.

 El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con créditos de la Fundación Paraguaya, es más, fue la única Institución que lo ayudo a montar su negocio y fue así que se inicio.  En su pequeña despensa el vende todos los productos de primera necesidad al vecindario. Mas adelante piensa en ampliar su local ya que ahora le es muy pequeño su espacio debido a la cantidad de mercaderías que tiene.

El crédito solicita para la compra de diversas mercaderías para surtir en su despensa.
texts.en:
Mr. Roberto V. is married to Mrs. Natalia Alcaraz, with whom he has four children.

Robert was in the business of buying and selling CDs and movies for several years. It was thanks to the earnings this business generated that he was able to assemble a small store in his home which has been very successful for the last two years.

He has worked before with loans from Fundación Paraguaya. In fact, it was the only institution that would help him initially set up his business. In his small store he sells essential products and foodstuffs to the neighborhood. Later he wants to think about expanding his site since right now his space is very small which limits the quantity of merchandise he carries.

He is asking for a loan to buy a variety of goods to stock his store.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying candy, noodles, sodas, etc.

loans.name: Kuña Kuera Katupyry Group

texts.es:
El contacto para el inicio del presente comité fue la señora Graciela T. quien invito y organizo a sus amigas para formar parte del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.

La señora Graciela T. se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir en general, invirtió el dinero en la compra prendas en general de esa manera ofrecer mayor variedad a sus clientes. 

La señora Nancy del Carmen A.  se dedica a la venta de bebidas, invirtió el dinero en la compra de esas mercaderías al por mayor y venderlos obteniendo así mayor ingreso, y variedad para su clientela. 

La señora Patrocinia A. se dedica a la venta de comestible, invirtió el dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de los comestibles y así ofrecer mayor calidad, variedad a sus clientes. 

La señora Maria Sachelaridi se dedica a la venta de ropa, invirtió el dinero en la compra de prendas en general, logrando ofrecer mayor variedad a sus clientes. 

La señora Francisca A. se dedica a la venta de bijuoterie, invirtió el dinero en la compra de esas mercaderías, logrando ofrecer variedad y buenos precios a sus clientes.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn A. is a 46-year-old mother of three children. She hails from the busy town of Angono, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is married to Samuel, who is 46 years old and her business partner. She believes that to get out of poverty, you yourself should take steps to unleash yourself from being tied to the poor situation.

With her desire to uplift the status of her living, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2008. Having access to capital through ASHI has brought her courage to continue what was her dying business of hog raising. Now on her second loan, she is excited to receive a loan of 10,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. This will be used to pay for four piglets, two sacks of feed and vitamins for the hogs.

She is optimistic that her business will bring them proceeds for their living expenses. She dreams of sending her children to school until they find jobs for a better way of life.

loans.use: To pay for four piglets, two sacks of feed and vitamins for the hogs

texts.es:
El comité Mujeres Emprendedoras con Esperanza del barrio San Carlos, se formó hace ya tres años, gracias a que la encargada de limpieza de la oficina de la ciudad de Luque de la Fundación invitó a sus vecinas a formar un grupo para que de esa forma tengan la posibilidad de incrementar sus mercaderías para ir creciendo laboralmente. Actualmente el grupo se encuentra en el décimo primer ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya y esta conformado por 18 integrantes las cuales invierten en distintas actividades.

The Foundation invited these neighbors to form a group so that they could have the possibility of increasing their goods and growing their businesses. Currently the group is on its eleventh loan cycle. The Mujeres Emprendedoras of Fundación Paraguaya has 18 members involved in various business activities.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn B. hails from the beautiful town of Pililia, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is full of faith that she can overcome poverty in her family. She is a mother to three: two boys and a baby girl. She is 41 years old and happily married to 38-year-old Rolando.

Life is not easy and the income of her husband, as a hired laborer, is not enough for the needs of her family. In 2004, she joined Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, full of hope to have access to capital for the continuation of her business selling fish.

Now on her fifth loan, she requests 10,000 pesos as rolling capital for her fish selling business: specifically to pay for 50 kilos of assorted fish. She will use a small amount of the loan to finance her secondary business – hog raising. She is hopeful that her business will grow and wishes to send her children to college so they can find jobs for greener living.

loans.use: To pay for 50 kilos of assorted fish and to finance hog raising

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina C. is a young mother with two daughters. She is only 27 years old, yet full of dreams for her children. She wants her children to grow up in a poverty-free situation. She is married to Jose, a 32-year-old responsible man. She lives in Pililia, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

Just recently, Cristina joined Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with the hope of bringing greener living for her family. She is excited to receive her first loan of 5,000 pesos as rolling capital for her vegetable business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for 55 kilos of assorted vegetables. With her membership in ASHI, and with the help of Kiva, she is hopeful that her dreams will come true sooner.

loans.use: To pay for 55 kilos of assorted vegetables to sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena D. S. is a 44-year-old woman who is determined to step out of poverty. She is married to Crisanto, who is 44 years old and her business partner. She is mother to four kids: one daughter and three sons. She lives in Jala-jala, Rizal province in the Philippines.

Aspiring to improve the well-being of her family, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2001. She has invested previous loans in fishing gear, which brought her good proceeds.

Now on her 5th loan, she seeks a loan of 30,000 pesos to pay for fish nets, to buy a boat and a second-hand engine for the boat.

With the access to capital provided by ASHI and KIVA, she is hopeful that she can step out of the spiral of poverty. She dreams of sending her children to college so they can find jobs for better living, and she also hopes to expand her business someday.

loans.use: To pay for fish nets, a boat, and a second-hand engine for the boat.

loans.name: Emelina

texts.en:
Emelina S. hails from the town of Jala-jala, Rizal province, in  the Philippines. She is determined to break down  the wall of poverty that stands between her family and success. She is 44 years old and mother of two sons.  Emelina is married to Guillermo, who is 47 years old.

In 1999, Emelina joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc., an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines), hoping to have access to capital for her fishing business. The business appeared sound and worthy of being continued. Now on her fifth loan, Emelina is seeking 25,000 pesos to pay for bundles of nets and payments for labor to prepare fishing gear.

She is hopeful that with the opportunity given by ASHI and KIVA, she can bring her family out of poverty. She dreams of building her own house, sending her children to college and to find jobs, so that her children do not experience the same life that she has.

loans.use: To pay for bundles of nets and payments for labor ito prepare fishing gear.

loans.name: Hom

texts.en: Hom H., 27, has been working as a motor-taxi driver since 2005 with a typical income of $US6 per day. He works hard every day to generate a primary source of income and to ensure a comfortable standard of living for his family. He usually provides transportation services at the town and local markets in Battambong Province. He is married and lives with his wife, Eng Eang, who stays at home to take care of her 6-year-old child. Because his motorbike is old and consumes a lot of gasoline, he has requested a loan of $US 400 to have his motorbike repaired so that he may resume doing his normal business.

loans.use: To repair his motorbike

loans.name: Joylyn

texts.en:
Joylyn A. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 23 years old. Joylyn is married and has 3 very young children. To make a living, Joylyn owns and operates a variety (sari-sari) store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling variety products in the local community. Joylyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In February 2009, Joylyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joylyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Joylyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase needed products for sale. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Joylyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Tap

texts.en:
Tap P., 45, is a village woman living in Siem Reap Province. She is a local farmer, growing rice, vegetables, and some fruit on her own farmland. To help meet the family's daily expenses, her husband works in construction. Tap P. now has six children, one of whom is married and has ready started a new family home, while the other five are single. Two of her children are employed: her son is a building worker and her daughter is a garden keeper.

Tap P. saw that her two employed children face difficulties with transportation when they go to work since they have no vehicle of their own. Hence, Tap P. would like a loan of $700 to buy a motorcycle for her children to ride to their workplace.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for her children to ride to their workplace

loans.name: Cory

texts.en:
Cory B. is from the village of Extension, Taglimao Cagayan De Oro City. She is 23 years old. Cory is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Cory owns and operates a variety store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Cory is just starting this business.

In 2009, Cory joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cory has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Cory is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products for sale. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Cory from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her inventory

location.town: Taglimao, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en:
Cornelia is a woman of vision, striving to remove her family from poverty. She is 47 years old and the mother of six children: four boys and two girls. She is married to Benito, 47 years old, and her business partner. She hails from the island village of Binangonan, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

Aspiring to rise up from poverty, Cornelia joined Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2008 with the hope of accessing capital for her sari-sari store (general store). She notes that her store brings in good income since, in an island village, not everyone has the capacity to go to the mainland to buy items for their basic needs.

Just recently, she applied for a loan of 5,000 pesos as additional capital to pay for two sacks of rice, sugar and groceries for the store. She is looking forward to sending her children to school and to expanding her business.

loans.use: To pay for two sacks of rice, sugar and groceries for a store

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda A. hails from the beautiful town of Binangonan in the Rizal province of the Philippines. She is 49 years old and married to Arnel, 48 year old. She is a mother to seven children; five are already adults, while two are still young and dependent on her.

Poverty is not a hindrance to success. There's always a way to get out from under it. In 1999, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with hope to access capital for her business. During her previous loans, she carefully invested in resale of fruits and dressed chicken. The business went good and brings her enough income for her family.

Now on her 10th loan, she proposes a loan as addtional capital for her business fruit stand and resale of dressed chicken. She is optimistic that she can bring her family out of poverty as she feels slowly the progress of her business.

loans.use: As addtional capital for her business fruit stand and resale of dressed chicken.

loans.name: Poch

texts.en: Poch S. is a 41-year-old farmer who lives in Siem Reap Province. Poch S. is married to Mr. Earn, age 42, who works with her in the farming business. This couple currently owns a cultivating machine that they use for their farming. In addition, they use their machine to plow a nearby farmer’s farmland for profit. Unfortunately, the machine has often broken down during the plowing process. Because of this problem, Poch S. would like a loan to purchase spare parts in order to replace a part of the cultivating machine. With the loan, this family will be able to continue providing their service to generate income.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts in order to replace a broken part of the cultivating machine.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad R.'s main source of income comes from cultivating fruit trees and harvesting the fruit to sell. She is 59 years old, married and has eight adult children. They are from the village of Unidos. Trinidad has been in this business for over three years and earns approximately 500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Trinidad joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Trinidad is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP which will be invested in expanding the business. This will be her first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a fruit business

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa R. is her own business manager. She is the 34-year-old mother of three: a girl and two boys. She is happily married to Ernesto, who is her business partner. She hails from the town of Binangonan, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

Life was not easy for Teresa – having a business with no sufficient rolling capital – until she decided to join Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 1999. Her previous loans were invested in a sari-sari store (general store), and it brings in a good income to sustain her family.

Now, she is excited to receive a loan of 18,000 pesos to pay for five sacks of rice, cigarettes, canned goods among many other groceries for the store. She believes that, with the continued assistance of ASHI and Kiva, she can reach her goals in life – to send her children to school until they find jobs and to expand her business.

loans.use: To pay for five sacks of rice, cigarettes, canned goods and other groceries for a store

loans.name: Salceda

texts.en:
Salceda P.'s main source of income comes from making and selling snacks and delicacies in her community. Salceda is just starting this business. She is 51 years old, married and has 10 adult children. She is from the village of Unidos.

In 2008, Salceda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Salceda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.

Salceda is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a food business

loans.name: Mercedez

texts.en:
Mercedez D. C. is a woman full of determination to rise above poverty. She is 63 years old but still the fire within her to get out of poverty is burning. She is widowed and the mother of six children: all of legal age already. She lives in Binangonan, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

In 2007, she decided to join Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, hoping to access capital for her sari-sari store (general store). During her membership in ASHI, her performance has been noted to be very good. Now she is requesting a loan of 15,000 pesos to pay for three sacks of rice among many other groceries for the store.

With the opportunity given to her by ASHI and Kiva, she believes that she is getting nearer to the fulfillment of her dreams. She wants to help her grandchildren with their school fees and also to save for their future, since she is getting old already.

loans.use: To pay for three  sacks of rice among many other groceries for a store

loans.name: Earn

texts.en: Earn Y. is 42 years old and is married. She has lived with with other family members in a medium-sized wooden house in the Siem Reap Province for years. She earns a living selling fresh fish in the local market and in her village as well. She gets her fish from her husband’s fishing from Tunle Sap River, as well as from other fishermen. Earn Y. complains that she finds it hard to transport fish because she doesn’t have her own vehicle. She has always hired a neighbor’s taxi at a steep rate to transport her goods. She hopes to reduce this cost by using this loan from Kiva to buy a motorcycle which she will use for her needs. Earn Y. has six children, two of whom are employed in different jobs. She and her husband are pictured above.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Joaquina

texts.en:
Joaquina U. believes that being poor is an opportunity to step forward into a higher status of living. She is a 61-year-old and married to Porfirio her business partner. She is mother to seven children and almost all of her children are already of legal age. She lives in Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines.

In 2001, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with hope to have access to capital for her business Sari-sari Store (General Store). She has been doing the business for  five years already and she found it to be helpful to her and her family. Now on her 4th loan, she proposes a loan to pay for 1 sack of sugar, 1 gallon of cooking oil, soft drinks, liquors and groceries for the store.

She is looking forward to improving her status of living. She dreams of helping her grandchildren in their school fees and also to expand her business.

loans.use: To pay for 1 sack of sugar, 1 galoon cooking oil, soft drinks, liqours and groceries for the store.

loans.name: Sor

texts.en: Sor S., 43, has been farming rice in her village for years. She is married and is blessed with three school-aged children. A primary source of income for the family comes from her husband, who repairs generators and vehicles. He also sells spare parts. Sor S.’s husband says that business is going well but that he needs money to upgrade his inventory of spare parts. Therefore, Sor S. is taking out a loan for her husband to use as capital to purchase additional parts.

loans.use: To purchase additional spare parts to sell

loans.name: Baasanjav

texts.en: Baasanjav is 53 years old and runs a produce stand at the open market. They sell potatoes, carrots, cabbage, onions etc. at her stand. She has been doing this since 2002 and even though she is older she is very good at running her business. She has lots of experience.  She is separated from her husband and her son is going to school in China. She lives with her younger siblings in a small shack. With the profits from her produce stand she pays for her sons schooling in China.  With a loan, she hopes to be able to buy more vegetables in greater bulk. With the extra profits she hopes to improve the standard of living for her and her family and be able to keep her son in school. Above all, Baasanjav wants to be able to make sure her son gets a good education so he can have a real occupation some day. She lives for her family and is a very hard worker.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables in greater bulk

loans.name: Frances

texts.en:
Frances A. is from the village of Magting, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 25 years old and single. To make a living, Frances owns & operates specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling electronic cellphones to local community members. Frances is just starting this business.

Frances joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Frances is requesting a new loan of 5000 Philippine pesos (or about $125 US). This will be used as additional working capital, and is the first loan Frances has taken out from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To generate additional working capital.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma N. hails from the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 45-years-old and still single. Even though she is single living, she still works hard for a living. She believes that someone should not stop seeking an opportunity to get out from poverty. If not for herself, at least for others she can offer help.

In 2007, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since before her membership with ASHI, she was already engaged in the selling of fried ducks. She buys the dressed ducks (slaughtered ducks), then she slices the ducks, fries them and sells them in the market and in restaurants. She earns good income from this work. Now she requests a loan as rolling capital for her business, specifically to pay for 150 heads of ducks, 3 gallons of cooking oil and to pay for transportation and packaging expenses.

She believes that with the opportunity given by ASHI and KIVA, she can develop her business into something much bigger so she can have savings for her future and also help her nephews and nieces with their school fees.

loans.use: To pay for 150 heads of ducks, 3 gallons of cooking oil, transportation and packaging expenses.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en: Jacinta P. is from the village of Langcayan, Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 49 years old and is married. Jacinta owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling personal and home products such as cologne, shampoos, powder and bath soaps in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In July 2009, Jacinta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Chuluuntsetseg

texts.en: Chuluuntsetseg B. is 27 years old. She is married with two children, a 7 year old son and a 4 year old daughter. Her husband drives his own car as a taxi for a living. Chuluuntsetseg used to run a hardware/building material stand at the outdoor market but three years ago started a grocery stand. She started out with 1,000,000 Tugrugs (about $715) as capital and with the profits from the business she and her family were able to buy their own land and build a shack on it.  Obviously, she works very hard.  She wants to be able to buy all groceries in bulk (things like flour, rice, bread etc.).  With the extra money from a loan she wants to expand her stand until she can achieve her real dream, to own her own grocery store. She is very diligent and works tirelessly for herself and her family.

loans.use: to buy all groceries in bulk (things like flour, rice, bread etc.).

loans.name: Lann

texts.en:
Lann is a 47-year-old mother of six children, four of whom are married and have already started new homes. The others are still attending school. She currently stays at home to plant a few vegetables for sale. Her husband owns a small garage which he uses to provide a vehicle washing service, and is earning around $8 each day. The family depends on this income to meet their daily expenses. Lann’s husband says that he can attract many regular customers, but is hampered by the fact that his work space is too small and overcrowded. Lann requested a loan in order to get a larger garage, which will permit better service.

Note: Lann was not available for photographing, so her husband appears in the photo instead.

loans.use: To get a larger garage for better service

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita S. is from the village of San Roque, Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 53 years old. Conchita is married and has 9 adult children. To make a living, Conchita owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Conchita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In July 2009, Conchita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Conchita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Conchita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family and support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia W. is from the village of Binaliwan, Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 56 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Virginia owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In July 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Leyce

texts.en:
Leyce is a member of the Tushikamane borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 33-year-old woman. She is married and the mother of two children. Her children are aged 12 and 5 years.

Leyce started her own business selling medicine three years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 400,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Leyce’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 350,000 TSH in order to buy more medicine. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Leyce hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more medicine

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema is a member of the Jipe moyo borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 27-year-old woman. She is married and the mother of one child. Her child is 10 years old.

Neema started her own business selling bicycles three years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Neema’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 350,000 TSH in order to buy more bicycles. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Neema hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more bicycles

loans.name: Munkhsaikhan

texts.en: Munkhsaikhan is a 37-year-old mother of three. She, her husband and three daughters all work together out of their small shack, sewing and selling shoes.  The shoes they sell are good winter shoes. They have been working together as a family since 1994. On average they make a profit of 9-10,000 Tugrug on each shoe. They sell most of their shoes in the winter when the market is very good. With the help of a loan, they want to be able to buy more material in the summer so they can have more shoes to sell in the winter when the market is best.  Her husband, Chuluunbat, does the main sewing but the whole family helps. Their daughters are 14, 10, and 5 years old. They have recently been using their profits to improve and fix up their little home and have also now hired an employee.  Most important to Munkhsaikhan is that her daughters all grow up to be well educated and wise, good girls.

loans.use: To purchase raw material

loans.name: Ludah

texts.en:
Ludah S. is from the village of Binaliwan, Mahinog, Camiguin. Ludah is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Ludah operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Ludah has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (about $104) a month for these activities.

Ludah just joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ludah is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the first loan taken out by Ludah from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children and supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Huluka

texts.en:
Huluka is a member of the Twiga borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 26-year-old woman, is separated from her husband, and is the mother of two children aged 13 and 7 years.
 
A year ago, Huluka started her own business selling charcoal. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Huluka’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Huluka hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is a member of the Uwasombo borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 49-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of four children aged 32, 29, 26 and 16 years. She also cares for three other dependents.

Three years ago, Mwanaisha started her own business selling bicycles. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 45,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Mwanaisha’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more bicycles. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Mwanaisha hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more bicycles for her business

loans.name: Anick

texts.en:
Anick is a member of the Upendo North borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 37-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of four children aged 20, 15, 9 and 4 years.

Nineteen years ago, Anick started her own business selling vegetables. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Anick’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more vegetables. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Anick hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Upendo North Group

texts.en:
Siwazuri is a member of the Upendo North borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is a 23-year-old woman, is single, and is the mother of one child aged 2 years.

Siwazuri started her own business selling vegetables three years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 240,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Siwazuri’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more vegetables. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Siwazuri hopes to save money and expand her business. 

Jenisia, another member of the Upendo North borrower group, has requested 250,000 Tsh in order to support her own food business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Darisuren

texts.en:
Darisuren is 22 years old and lives with her father in their own little building (shack). Her elderly father works as a security guard in town and earns less than 100 dollars a month.

Before she rented space for a grocery stand, Darisuren made money by sewing. She eventually was able to save up enough to lease the space and begin selling groceries. As of now the stand brings in around $60-$85 a day.

Darisuren wants to be able to buy a greater variety of food and in bulk to increase her income. With the extra income she wants to add another booth to the one she has and eventually own her own store. She is a very modest and down-to-earth girl. She wants two things: to be able to take care of her father and to own her own store.

loans.use: To buy a greater variety of food and in bulk to increase her income

loans.name: Servanda

texts.en:
Servanda I. is from the village of Mantique, San Roque Mahinog, Camiguin. She is 55 years old. Servanda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Servanda operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Servanda has been engaged in her business for more than 40 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2008, Servanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Servanda is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Servanda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children and supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty C. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao Camiguin. She is 49 years old. Betty is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Betty owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for more than 12 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

On March 19, Betty joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Betty from HSPFI. She just finished paying her previous loan of 4,000 PHP. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bingin Sari Group

texts.en:
Ni Wayan Sulastri is a 38-year-old female living in the town of Pangkung Tanah - Melaya. Ni Wayan Sulastri is the leader of an 11-member loan group sponsored by DINARI.  Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Bingin Sari (DNR.M-0586).

Ni Wayan Sulastri is married and has 2 school-aged children. To making a living, Ni Wayan Sulastri raises pigs for sale. Ni Wayan Sulastri has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 400.000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ni Wayan Sulastri joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ni Wayan Sulastri is requesting a loan from DINARI for the first time. She is requesting a loan of 2.200.000 IDR which will be used to expand her business. Ni Wayan Sulastri plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About DINARI:

The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Ni Wayan Sulastri 0 (0) merupakan 38 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Pangkung Tanah - Melaya.  Ni Wayan Sulastri adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 11 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Bingin Sari (DNR.M-0586).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Wayan Sulastri sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 10 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Wayan Sulastri menghasilkan sekitar 0,400 IDR.  Dalam 2009, Ni Wayan Sulastri bergabung DINARI untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Wayan Sulastri telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya dari DINARI.    Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 2.200.000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari DINARI.


Tentang DINARI:

Misi DINARI adalah memperjuangkan kelestarian lingkungan, memberdayakan kaum miskin, dan menyediakan kesempatan pembangunan sosial ekonomi bagi pemilik usaha kecil.


*Catatan: Untuk memaksimalkan efisiensi & menurunkan biaya, pinjaman ini ditempelkan menggunakan templat sehingga dapat diterjemahkan otomatis oleh Kiva. .  Mengingat bahwa terjemahan manual atas profil memakan biaya besar, Kiva menciptakan templat ini untuk Mitra Lapangan untuk memungkinkan mereka terus menempelkan pinjaman dalam  Bahasa sambil memberikan informasi yang bermutu & akurat kepada para pemberi pinjaman Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Dejidmaa

texts.en:
Dejidmaa M., a 44-year-old widow with two sons and one daughter, currently resides with her two younger children in Arhangai Province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. The oldest son, Ganbat, 23, helps in her business full time. Her only daughter Ganchimeg, 18, is a university student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The youngest son, Ganbold, 16, goes to a local high school. Dejidmaa rents a small stall in the local food market and sells various daily food products such as soft drinks, biscuits, etc. She has been in the food retail business since 1995 and in the meantime, her business capital has increased from 300,000 MNT to 5,000,000 MNT. She recently bought a small stall in the clothing market for her son, where he currently sells various women's and children's clothes. Dejidmaa is helping her son launch his own business so that he can become financially independent.

She is now requesting a loan to purchase more products for her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase food products.

loans.name: Kichangani Group

texts.en:
Witnes is a member of the Kichangani borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 30-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of two children aged 7 years and 1 year old. She also cares for two other dependents.

Three years ago, Witnes started her own business selling food. She works six hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Witnes’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice and wheat. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to save money and expand her business. 

Aisha, Ashura, Mwajabu and Rehema are the other members of the Kichangani borrower group. They requested 150,000 Tsh each in order to support their own businesses.

loans.use: To buy more rice and wheat

loans.name: Алибой

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan
Абдурахимов Алибой – мужчина 42 лет , женат имеет пятерых детей. Алибой имеет высшее образование, сейчас работает в колхозе «Урунходжаева» заведующим фермой.
Его заработная плата хватает на минимальное проживание, поэтому уже много лет как Алибой занимается бизнесом животноводства. Он в сезон дешёвого скота закупает несколько десятков голов скота и откормив их продаёт за хорошую цену. Алибой хочет на полученный кредит закупить несколько коров и бычка. Алибой хорошо разбирается в породистых быках.

loans.use: откорм и продажа скота

loans.name: Reny

texts.en:
Reny F., 50, lives in Habitat for Humanity at the heart of a former slum community in BASECO, Port Area, Manila. Her husband, Rolando, 56, is a carpenter. They have 4 adult children who are also living with them.

Reny is a tireless entrepreneur. She owns a variety store located on the ground floor of her house. She is also a seamstress, and she maintains a small apartment for rent. Combined, she earns more than P80,000 a month and she has 3 assistants tending her businesses.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in the summer of 2006. She has been enjoying the camaraderie of her fellowship group since then. She is now on her ninth loan cycle. She has just finished repaying her loan of P20,000, and she has applied for a new loan of P22,000. She will use the loan proceeds to purchase more items to sell at her store.

Reny aspires to see her store to grow big so she can employ more people in her community.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This response is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Zaujath

texts.en:
Zaujath is a member of the Upendo North borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 29 years old, married, and the mother of 2 children. Her children are aged 8 and 3 years. She also cares for 2 other dependents.

Zaujath started her own business selling chicken 5 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Zaujath’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more chickens. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Zaujath hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

loans.name: Jeni

texts.en:
Jeni is a member of the Mgodi North borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 30 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children. Her children are aged 14, 7, 5, and 1 years.

Jeni started her own business selling clothes 4 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Jeni’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Jeni hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Muhammad Ahman Group

texts.en:
Muhammad Ahman is the group leader of the Muhammad Ahman group. There are four members in this group. Each of them wants to take a loan for expanding their businesses, so they are requesting a group of loan 40000 Afghani. 

Muhammad Ahman wants to take a loan for his business of selling mobile-phone cards. Plwasha wants to take a loan for her husband, who is a taxi driver. Bashe wants to take a loan for a stationery shop. Gul Badam wants to take a loan for her husband, who has a general store. 

They are very thankful for Kiva lenders who can support all worlds.

loans.use: For expanding their businesses

loans.name: Soronzonbold

texts.en:
Soronzonbold J. is a 47-year-old married man who has four sons with ages ranging between 5 and 20 years. He currently lives with his wife and two young children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Two oldest sons are both students in universities in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Soronzonbold has a small retail business in clothing. He rents a small stall in the local black market and sells various men's and women's clothes. He frequently travels to purchase clothes from Ereen, China, a border town where many Chinese products are imported from. He started his retail business in 2000 with a small capital of 800,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT). Since the beginning, his business has been quite successful. With his profits, he was able to purchase a house on a small plot of land in the town. His current business capital is now above 2,848,000 MNT. He says that with his business profits, he has been supporting his family and his two oldest sons' university tuitions.

He hopes to expand his business by diversifying the clothes that he offers at his stall. He requests a loan to purchase more clothes from Ereen, China.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Калкыз

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan
Султонкулова  Калкыз женщина в возрасте 44 лет замужем, имеет одного ребёнка. Она домохозяйка, но без дела не сидит.Калкыз имеет пять коров , которые в день дают по 7 литров молока. Также она имеет пятнадцать баранов. В день мониторинга Калкыз не было дома она была в отъезде в город за покупками. Поэтому на снимке её муж , который работает строителем на заказ. На полученный кредит Калкыз хочет закупить ещё несколько баранов и отремонтировать крышу сарая , где она содержит скот.

loans.use: откорм и продажа

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina is a member of the Mgodi West borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 32 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children. Her children are aged 14, 13, 8, and 1 years old.

Penina started her own business selling electric tools four years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 400,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Penina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more goods. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Penina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more eletrical goods

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy S., separated from her husband, is an example of a woman who can thrive and make a living without a man. A 30-year-old mother of a boy and a girl, she lives in the town of Angono, Rizal Province, in the Philippines.

Because Joy’s primary goal is to build a sustainable business to meet the needs of her children, she was thus motivated to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2001. The loans she received were carefully invested in her sari-sari store, but years ago she decided to turn her business into a restaurant and karaoke bar. Since then, the restaurant has been performing well and earning her sufficient profit. Now requesting her fifth loan, she is asking for 40,000 pesos as additional capital for her restaurant, to be used to pay for cases of beer, liquor, cigarettes, sacks of rice, rental of the building, business permit and groceries for her enterprise.

Joy is hopeful that she can achieve her dreams of providing a good life for her children and being able to send them to school until they finish college. She also hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional supplies for her restaurant.

loans.name: Кундуз

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan

Кундузой- женщина, которая занимается откормом и продажей скота. Ей 44 года, замужем имеет троих детей. Муж на заработках в Алма-ате. Кундузой вместе с сыном  имеет хороший доход с этого бизнеса. Прибыль Кундузой тратит на расходы семьи, а деньги , которые присылает её муж она использует на строительство своего дома. Кундузой на полученный хочет закупить несколько молоденьких барашков и корм для них.

loans.use: откорм и продажа скота

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en: Geraldine Iñesa, 32, is one of CCT’s youngest successful entrepreneurs. She lives in Parola, Binondo, Manila, with her husband, Darwin, 34, her business-partner, and their two children who are both in grade school. Geraldine owns and manages a soft drinks depot and distributes/retails to small stores in the community. She attributes her business acumen to her mother, who is one of CCT’s pioneer members in Parola. Five years ago, Geraldine joined CCT and established her own small store. Now, her soft drinks dealership earns for her a daily income of P25,000. She has also employed the services of two assistants who attend to deliveries. Geraldine has just finished repaying her previous loan of P50,000 and is now applying for a new loan of the same amount. She will use her new loan to purchase additional inventory and will also embark on marketing soft drinks in cans. Geraldine believes that with her hard work and perseverance, she will soon realize her dream of establishing branches in other areas. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Nasir Ahmad Group

texts.en: Nasir Ahmad is the group leader of Nasir Ahmad group. There are three members in this group. Each of them wants to take a loan to progress his business and make it larger. So they are requesting a group loan of 30000 Afghani. Nasir Ahmad wants to take a loan for his car washing business. Zakiu wants to take a loan for the business of embroidery. Hasena wants to take a loan for her son who has a P.C.O and mobile selling card business. They are very thankful for AFS and Kiva lenders who can support all worlds.

loans.use: To progress his business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn was born in a family bearing the hardships in life. She really wants to jump out of the wall of poverty that hinders her and her family’s way to success. She is the 37-year-old mother to three. She is married to Edmundo, who is 32 years old and is a jeepney (small bus) driver. They live in Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines.
