With her aspiration to break out from poverty, in 2006 Jocelyn joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. Her previous loans were prudently used as capital in her business reselling chickens. She has been doing the business for three years already and she is happy with the profit it brings her.

Now on her 7th loan, Jocelyn requests the amount of 20,000 pesos as rolling capital for her resale of chickens. The loan will be used to pay for kilos of live chickens, payment for labor, and payment for transportation. She is confident that her business will continue to grow and bring them good proceeds as it is well-managed.

loans.use: To pay for kilos of live chickens, payment for labor, and payment for transportation

loans.name: Nidal

texts.en:
Nidal is a 40-year-old man who is married with five kids. He owns a business selling car parts and accessories in the downtown Nablus market. Nidal is full of ideas. He has rich experience working in this business. Moreover, he is very enthusiastic about his own small enterprise and has a good attitude. 

Nidal would like to get a loan of 3000 USD to increase his working capital. Nidal is hoping to generate more profit and provide for his kids.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Мавлюда

texts.ru: Сангинова Мавлюда женщина , которая кредитуется уже шестой год. Каждый свой кредит она использует на расширение бизнеса. Её ассортимент товара составляет детская одежда и обувь. Следующий кредит на хочет использовать на завоз школьного ассортимента детской одежды и обуви.Мавлюда является активным клиентом в Микроинвест.

loans.use: на завоз детской одежды и обуви

loans.name: Moeun

texts.en: Moeun S. is a 26-year-old fish vendor and the mother of three school-aged children. Every day in early morning, Moeun S. and her husband always go to buy fish from the fishermen and they hurry up and bring their fish by motorbike to the market for resale. In addition, Moeun S.’s husband also uses his existing motor to pick up passengers for fees. Moeun S. is leading her investment more smoothly. She has a lot of regular customers who buy and eat her fish. She hopes to be able to look for extra income by using a Kiva loan to purchase a large quantity of fish to sell. She proposes to use the remainder of the loan to purchase equipment for her husband to begin fishing.

loans.use: To purchase  a large quantity of fish to sell

loans.name: Zalmai Group

texts.en:
Zalmai is the group leader of the Zalmai group. There are three members in this group. They want to take a loan to progress their businesses and to make the businesses larger. They have requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani. 

Zalmai wants to take a loan for his taxi business. Shaema wants to take a loan for her husband, who has a fruit and vegetable shop. Raema wants to take a loan for her husband, who has a general store. They are very thankful for Kiva lenders who can support all poor people.

loans.use: For expanding the businesses

loans.name: Maricor

texts.en:
Maricor is the 40-year-old mother to Ezra who is five years old. She lives in Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is married to Roel who is 31 years old and is a jeepney (small bus) driver. She believes that poverty is not a hindrance to success, it is in the person to strive hard to reach her dreams.

In 2007, Maricor joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, hoping that she could have access to capital for her business retailing rice, charcoal and chickens. She been running the business for three years already and she is happy that she receives enough profit from it.

Now on her 3rd loan, Maricor requests the amount of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for sixty sacks of charcoal, five sacks of rice, and live chickens, all for resale.

With the opportunity and trust given to her by ASHI and Kiva, Maricor believes that she can reach her dream for her children, to send them to school and to expand her business. She is looking forward to having a space in the market for her business.

loans.use: To pay for 60 sacks of charcoal, 5 sacks of rice, and live chickens

loans.name: Saveniana

texts.en:
Saveniana N. is a 44-year-old single mother of 2 adult children who both live with her. Her oldest son is already earning for himself and the other one has just finished a nursing degree in college.

Saveniana and her husband parted ways almost two decades ago. She was left to care for and rear her 2 sons. But this never hindered her from moving forward. She went into business. She owns a general store, which has been running for the last 7 years. And just last year, she opened a store for RTW (ready-to-wear) clothes in Cartimar. She used her savings as capital for this new business. She makes P25,000.00 a month out of the combined proceeds of her businesses.

Saveniana joined Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2002. Since then, she has been enjoying the benefits it provides to its clients. Through the years, she became an inspiration to CCT members, old and new, especially by showing her endurance to her trials and challenges as she raised her sons and supported their education.

Saveniana has applied for a new loan of P17,000.00. She will use these funds to purchase additional inventory (clothes and beauty accessories) for her bazaar. At this point of her life, Saveniana could never ask for more. She is very thankful to the Almighty for giving her the strength to move on.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This response is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To buy clothes and beauty accessories for her bazaar

loans.name: Maqbol Group

texts.en:
Maqbol is the group leader of Maqbol group. There are four members in this group and each of them wants to take a loan to progress their business and make it larger. So they are requested a group loan of 40,000 Afghani.

Faridon wants to take a loan for his business as a butcher.

Sarder M. wants to take a loan for his shop selling fruits and vegetables.

Bibi Saeb wants to take a loan for her husband who has a general store.

They are very happy with this process of loans in Afghanistan and around the world.

loans.use: To progress their businesses

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun T. started selling fish in her busy local market a number of years ago and has gained a lot of customers from this business. She is a single mother blessed with four teenage children; most of them help meet the family’s expenses by working in a restaurant. With a loan, Bun T. hopes to be able to buy fish in greater quantities for resale. With the extra profits, she hopes to improve her and her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fish in greater quantities for resale

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a member of the Kisiwani borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is 23 years old and single.

Agnes started her own food business selling poks one year ago. She works 10 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Agnes’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to to expand her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Agnes hopes to save money and pay school fees.

loans.use: To buy more poks (a food item) to sell

loans.name: Бароат

texts.ru: Мирмамадова Бароат женщина которая имеет бизнес продажи детской обуви. Она товар привозит два раза в месяц с оптового рынка Истаравшана. На следующий кредит она хочет привести школьные ботинки для мальчиков и туфельки для девочек.Бароат является шестой год клиентом в Микроинвест, она довольна условиями организации.

loans.use: на закуп школьной обуви для детей

loans.name: Хомид

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan

Хомидчон парень, который торгует на рынке Худжанда  сахаром  в розницу. Он закупает у поставщиков оптом сахар и продаёт в развес в розницу. Хомидчон имеет постоянных клиентов , потому что торгует уже десять лет. На следующий кредит Хомидчон хочет оптом закупить несколько мешков сахара по оптовой цене.На снимке Хомидчон в час пик , когда торговля кипит.

loans.use: на закуп сахара  оптом

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Pov Y is a local vendor who sells different kinds of vegetable in Savy Tom Market in the province of Siem Reap. In season, she also sells vegetables that her husband has grown. Pov Y has been married to her husband for many years and is blessed with three teenage children who are students and dependent on her. She says that she had to stop her fish-selling business because her motorbike broke, leaving her without a means to transport her fish to market. To solve this problem, she would like a loan to repair her broken motorbike.

loans.use: To repair her broken motorbike

loans.name: Zaba Group

texts.en:
Zaba is the group leader of Zaba group. There are four members in this group and each of them wants to take a loan to progress their business and make it larger. So they are requested a group of loan 20,000 Afghani.

Zaba wants to take a loan for her tailoring business.

Sariu wants to take a loan for her husband who has fruit and vegetable shop.

HA. wants to take a loan for his general store.

Aliui wants to take a loan for her tailoring business.

They are thankful for AFS and Kiva lenders who are able to support all entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand her tailoring business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Upendo borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is 40 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children. Her children are aged 20, 17, 12, and 9 years. She also cares for 3 other dependents.

Joyce started her own cafe business selling food three years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 50,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Joyce’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, wheat, and sugar. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Joyce hopes to save money, get more food for her family, and expand her business. .

loans.use: To buy more rice, wheat, and sugar

loans.name: Eunice Amondi

texts.en:
Eunice sells paraffin, which is used to light many homes in her community. She also sells hair products such as wigs, weaves, and braids at her shop, which is called 'Club Metro.' She has been running her business for about three years, and it is going very well. She says that she has lots of customers, but still has problems with cash flow. She currently has a lot of money tied up in her inventory of items to sell. She would like to use her loan to buy more products and help ease the ups and downs of her cash reserves each month.

In addition to running her business, Eunice works as a community health worker with K-MET, the field partner providing this loan. She visits people in her community who are sick, and refers them to the appropriate medical service providers. She also educates her community on best practice in health-related issues, and tries to take care of those who need help with basic tasks. She does this on Mondays and Thursdays from 11am until 2:30pm. She is also raising three children of her own and two orphaned children. She is carrying the full burden of paying for their school fees, food, clothing, and medicine. Her husband is currently out of work, but is hoping to get a bicycle soon and start operating a 'boda boda' business – giving people lifts on his bicycle taxi.

loans.use: To buy more stock

loans.name: Pamella Atieno

texts.en:
Pamella sells small dried fish called omena at the Oile market in Kisumu. She buys them at a nearby beach on Lake Victoria and transports them back to town to sell. A 40-year-old woman, Pamella has been selling omena for about 14 years. She will use the proceeds from her loan to buy more stock so that she can increase the volume of fish going through her business every day.

Pamella is a widow who is currently caring for ten children – six are her own, and four are orphans left to her care. She says that she currently has a hard time earning enough money to pay for all of their expenses – food, clothes, school fees, and medicines. She does not have anyone to look after the children while she is working, so is forced to bring those that are not in school along with her. Pamella says that with the money from her loan, she can diversify her suppliers and be more certain of getting a fair price on her purchases.

In addition to running her business, Pamella works as a community health worker with K-MET, the field partner providing this loan. She visits people in her community who are sick, and refers them to the appropriate medical service providers. She also educates her community on best practice in health-related issues, and tries to take care of those who need help with basic tasks.

loans.use: To purchase a larger stock of fish to sell

loans.name: Eunice Anyango

texts.en:
Eunice is a 23-year-old mother of one four-month-old girl. She sells vegetables, primarily cabbage and tomatoes, from a small stall in the neighborhood of Nyamasaria. She also sells charcoal, a popular item with her customers. She has been in business for five years, and things are going well. However, there are times when things are difficult. The rainy season in Kisumu lasts from January through May and the rains make it difficult to get in a full day’s work outside. Eunice would like to put a waterproof shelter over her stall so that she can sell even when it’s raining.

Eunice has been married for five years. Her husband is a mechanic in town and helps her to provide for their daughter. She hopes to buy more charcoal with her loan proceeds.

loans.use: To buy charcoal for resale

loans.name: Humphrey Amonde

texts.en:
Humphrey owns a small shop called 'Stebats', which is a combination of his wife, Stella’s, name and his nickname, 'Batson.' His stall is located in a market north of Kisumu, and he sells omena, the small dried fish that come from Lake Victoria. He sells to retailers and to customers directly. Humphrey has been married for two years, and he has a young child. Sometimes when the full moon is out, the fish are scarce, and the price to buy them goes up. With his loan, Humphrey would like to buy a large quanitity of omena so that he can better ride out the ups and downs of the market.

Humphrey is also a minister and community health worker in his neighborhood of Nyamasaria. He is no longer a full-time minister, but is still very active in his church. He says that he loves business as it comes very naturally to him. As a community health worker with Kiva partner K-MET, Humphrey visits his neighbors who are sick, refers them to doctors, brings them basic supplies, and educates them on best practice in health-related issues.

loans.use: To buy a larger supply of fish

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is a member of the Uwasobo borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is 49, married, and a mother of four. Her children are 32, 29, 26, and 16 years old. She also cares for 3 other dependents.

Mwanaisha started her own business selling bicycles 3 years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 45,000 Tanzanian Shillings (about $34 US).

This is Mwanaisha’s First loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 shillings in order to buy more bicycles. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Mwanaisha hopes to pay school fees, save money, and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bicycles for resale

loans.name: Conslala Achieng

texts.en:
Conslala is a 38-year-old married woman who has seven children. She also cares for three orphans. Conslala sells small fish and vegetables that she buys in the city and carries to market on her head. Her husband does not have steady work.

Conslala hopes to expand her business so that she can feed her orphans well and enrol them in school. Right now she does not have enough money to pay their school fees. She also tries to help support her neighbors’ orphans as well. Conslala is a volunteer community health worker with K-MET, the NGO giving the loan. K-MET is unique in that it is not a traditional microfinance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. Many of the loan recipients from this organization are volunteer community healthcare workers like Conslala. For more information about K-MET, see the partner link on the lower right side of this web page.

loans.use: To buy a large stock of vegetables and fish

loans.name: Lillian Auma

texts.en:
Lillian is 26 years old. She has a business selling fresh fruit, including paw paw (papaya), avocado, bananas, and oranges. She buys the fruit at a market and sells it at a different market in town.

Lillian will use her loan money to buy more fruit for her shop. She is also considering buying clothes or vegetables to sell, if they will bring in good money. She will use the proceeds to support her three children and the four neighboring orphans for whom she cares. Whatever Lillian brings home she shares with these vulnerable children. Lillian is also a community health worker. This means that she visits sick people in her community and counsels their caregivers.

Kiva partner K-MET, the NGO giving this loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional microfinance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. Many of the loan recipients from this organization are volunteer community healthcare workers like Lillian. For more information about K-MET, see the partner link on the lower right side of this web page.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Abdukayum

texts.ru: Кадыров Абдукаюм  является нашим активным клиентом более 3 лет. Он торгует тканью  на рынке. Его сын привозит товар с Урумчи и Каросу.   Также в торговле помогает его жена. Она советует им покупать модные современные материалы. Она знает, какой цвет и какая ткань модна в этом или другом году. Кредит получил на покупки материалов из Каросу. Сейчас сезон свадеб и все покупают и шьют дорогой материал.  Также покупают на приданное дочерей и будущих невест.

loans.use: покупка тканей

loans.name: Peres Akinyi

texts.en:
Peres is 34 years old. She is married with four children, aged from seventeen to two. She also cares for orphans that deceased family members have left behind. Peres has had a small hardware shop in Kisumu, Kenya, for seven years. She wants to use this loan to expand her hardware selection.

Peres says that before the post-election violence in 2007 and 2008, her hardware store was large. “I even had to transport things on lorries,” she explained. Unfortunately, during this period her store was looted and her stock was stolen. She is now working hard to grow her business back to its previous level.

Peres wants to work hard to pay back this loan so that she can take another, larger loan for her business. She also wants to help her children go to school.

loans.use: To expand her hardware selection

loans.name: Pheobe Akoth

texts.en: Pheobe is a mother of six children, and also looks after orphans in her community. She has a business selling vegetables in a kiosk at the market.  Pheobe would like to use her loan money to improve her business by adding new produce to her stock of vegetables. Pheobe’s main goal is to feed her children and the orphans she cares for, and to try to pay their school fees.

loans.use: To buy a wider range of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Petronalo

texts.en:
Petronalo is a 47-year-old widow from Kisumu, Kenya. She buys small fish (called omena) from Lake Victoria and sells them at a market in town. Petronalo wants to expand her business to include larger fish such as tilapia and mud fish. Her dream is to have a large fish company that exports fish all over the country.

Petronalo explains that she finds life difficult. Her husband passed away, and she suffers from asthma. This business is all she has to help feed her four children and one grandchild.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Абдумурод

texts.ru:
Абдумурод – мужчина  который занимается откормом и продажей скота. Кроме этого он работает разнорабочим на заказ. Абдумурод на полученный кредит хочет закупить несколько коз и баранов. Его жена работает в колхозе, вместо денег с колхоза получает продукты питания. На снимке Абдумурод дома рядом с коровой за которой ухаживает его семья. Кроме неё у Абдумурада есть десять баранов, которые пасутся на пастбище.
Следующий кредит Абдумурод получит с Микроинвеста.

loans.use: откорм и продажа скота

loans.name: Dilshod

texts.ru: Дилшод Урунов 1984 года рождения . Работает мастером ремонтных работ. Ремонт проводит сам как частник.   У него есть также  работники которые помогают штукатурить и  проводить ремонты.  Кредит получает для проведения свадебного мероприятия. Он жениться, но накопленная прибыль не достаточно для проведения свадьбы. Родители часть покупки и  проведения мероприятия взяли на себя. НО этого было мало и он решил поучить кредит . Узнав что так ему удобно он получил кредит.

loans.use: weedding party

loans.name: Карим

texts.ru: Карим мужчина , который занимается откормом и продажей скота. Карим имеет высшее образование , но из-за отдаленного района  проживания Карим работает бригадиром в строительной бригаде на стройку крупных объектов. Карим кредитуется на расширение оборотного капитала бизнеса животноводства, хочет закупить три молодых быка.Кредитная история Карима в Микроинвесте положительная, он ни разу не нарушал условий Фонда.

loans.use: откорм и продажа скота

loans.name: Murod

texts.ru: Мурод Рахмонов  1980 года рождения женат, имеет 2 детей. Он работает    водителем такси . В день он делает до 8 рейсов .   Живет с родителями и братьями. Но жена настаивала на переезд. Несколько лет копили деньги что бы купить квартиру. Настал долгожданный момент, но все таки нахватало несколько тысяч. Родители немного добавили . Жена также посоветовала обратится за кредитом .

loans.use: покупка квартир

loans.name: Масума

texts.ru:
Масума, женщина которая занимается продажей мужской одежды по воскресным базарам. 
В остальные дни она работает учительницей в средней школе по урокам русского языка. Из-за не хватки дохода на проживание Масума привозит товар с Истаравшана и продаёт с наценкой , с чего и имеет дополнительный доход.  На полученный кредит с Микроинвеста Масума планирует привезти брюки и рубашки.

.

loans.use: продажа  мужской одежда

loans.name: Kayi

texts.fr:
Cette dame exerce un commerce qui lui réussit bien il s’agit du commerce de détail de trousseaux bébé, elle a associé plus tard à ce commerce la vente de produits de beauté. elle dispose d’une clientèle composée à majorité de jeunes maman. elle a remarqué une rentabilité du commerce de produits de beauté, elle veut l’agrandir et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour augmenter son stock de produits de beauté et acheter quelques trousseaux pour bébé.
Elle est mariée et est mère de 05 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman runs a business that has been very successful for her. It is a retail baby clothes business. Later she added beauty product sales to this business. Her clientele is composed mainly of young mothers. She has noticed profitability in the beauty product business. She would like to increase it, and is requesting a loan from WAGES to augment her stock of beauty products and to purchase some baby clothes. She is married and is the mother of 5 children.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase baby clothes and beauty products

loans.name: Mrs. Leang Chhum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of twenty-two members, is located in Preak Ta Kaev village in the province of Kandal. The members plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Leang C., who has been selected by the members as the village bank president, is a fish seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Kheng Huot, is a fisherman. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Leang C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat for her husband’s fishing. This couple has three children; two are employed in a garment factoR., while the other is a fisherman who helps with his father’s work.

Twenty one members in this group have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the veR. end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows thE. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a boat for her husband’s fishing

loans.name: Ayawa

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes, elle a commencé ce commerce depuis trois ans, ce commerce est très rentable à Lomé, ce commerce connaît  un essor remarquable au grand marché de Lomé où elle s’approvisionne. Elle dispose d’une grande clientèle. Son stock actuel a baissé, voulant se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 20 pièces de pagnes de grande qualité. Elle est mariée et a un enfant.
texts.en:
To generate income, this woman sells pagnes (lengths of printed fabric). She began this business 3 years ago. This business is very profitable in Lomé. This business is booming in the large market in Lomé where she gets her supplies. She has a large clientele. Her current stock has decreased. Wanting to restock, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase 20 high quality pagnes. She is married and has one child.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase pagnes (lengths of printed fabric)

loans.name: Умри

texts.ru: Ачилова Умри женщина , которая кредитуется в организации несколько лет. Она занимается бизнесом продажи продуктов питания на маленьком базарчике 27 микрорайона города Худжанда, где сама и живёт. Т.к. сейчас сезон арбузов, Умри  на полученный кредит с Микроинвеста хочет завести партию арбузов и продавать около своего ларька.

loans.use: на завоз арбузов

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.ru: Бахтиёр Гафаров  делает мебель.  Начинал он с ремонтов мебели и разных мелочей. Постепенно научившись делать различную мебель решил сам строить фурнитуру. Со  временем  он     перешел на постройку только кроватей и диванов. Его профиль по стройке  кроватей начала развиваться. Кредит необходим для получений  досок и других необходимых строительных материалов.

loans.use: покупка сырья для мебели

loans.name: Yao

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur exerce dans la restauration, il a ouvert en 2007 son cafétéria. Beaucoup de jeunes viennent prendre chez lui leur petit déjeuner, d’autres sont plus fréquents les soirs. Son activité de restauration a ralenti parce que les matières nécessaires à son activité de restauration sont presque finies. Il veut se réapprovisionner, il sollicite donc de WAGES un crédit pour acheter divers condiments et des produits nécessaires à l’activité de la restauration.
Il est marié et père de 04 enfants, c’est avec le revenu de ce commerce qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman runs a restaurant. He opened his cafeteria in 2007. Many young people come to eat their breakfast at his place, others come more frequently in the evening. His restaurant's business has slowed down because he is almost out of the materials necessary to run a restaurant. He wants to restock, therefore he is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase various condiments and products necessary for the restaurant. He is married and is the father of 4 children. It is with the revenue from this business that he meets the family's expenses.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of products necessary for his restaurant

loans.name: Mrs. Khom Crech Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan which consists of sixteen people is located in Tranh village in Kandal province. Mrs. Khom C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members.

Mrs. Khom C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice to earn for living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to produce rice on the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to cultivate rice on her field. Her husband, Mr. Huot Phoeun, is a hardworking man. Mrs. Khom C. has two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is a farmer who helps with his parents’ work. 

Ten members in this group loan are end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those having EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To finance the cultivation of rice on her field

loans.name: Mrs. Thou Nem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Seventeen people living in Tranh village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes.

Mrs. Thou N. is the 41-year-old village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. In her plantation, she has some problems because her field is infertile and it is far from the irrigation system. In order to solve these problems, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. She would use the rest of money to hire a laborer to plow the field. Her husband, Mr. Chuk Touch, is a hardworking man. This couple has four children, two of whom are construction workers and the other two are attending the local school. 

Fifteen members in this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those having EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline and to hire a laborer to plow the field

loans.name: Aun

texts.en:
Mrs. Aun S. lives in Doem Pour village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces some problems because her field is infertile and it is far from the irrigation system. Additionally, she does not have enough money to cultivate rice. In order to deal with these problems, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticides, and gasoline to pump water to support the field.

Mrs. Aun S. is 42 years old and the mother of three children who are employed in a garment factory. Her husband, Mr. Meas Yorn, is a security guard in the garment factory.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticides, and gasoline to pump water

loans.name: Erna

texts.en:
ERNA B., is a resident of Hda. San Jose 2, Brgy. Luna, Cadiz City in Negros Occidental. She is 54 years old, and married with 9 school age to adult children.

Because of her large family, life has not been very comfortable for the B. family, and Erna dreams of providing her children with a better life. This is why in 2005, Erna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could also start her own business and become financially stable.

She now owns and operates a General Store which earns on the average PHP 2,000.00 for her family.

This is Erna's 7th loan cycle and she wants to borrow PHP 17,000 to add to her working capital so that she could add more stocks to her General Store and have more goods to sell to her neigbors.

With some of her children still going to school, Erna hopes that by striving hard, she will be able to provide a better life for her children, and save enough so that they could attend college and have comfortable lives in the future.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL CAPITAL FOR THE BORROWER'S GENERAL STORE

loans.name: Уктам

texts.ru: Уктам 1958 года рождения, женат имеет пятерых детей. Он занимается откормом и продажей скота. Так же Уктам работает на вода-насосной станции Сумчака. Жена помогает ему ухаживать со скотом. После откормки скот продается на скотном рынке. Уктам кредитуется в нашей организации более 3 года. Он успешно закончил предыдущих займов и теперь хочет взять очередной займ. Он планирует увеличить количество поголовье своего скота и тем самым увеличить прибыль своей семьи. Ему очень нравятся условия нашего кредитования и он рад, что есть такие организации поддерживающие общество.

loans.use: на закупку несколько голов крупно рогатого скота

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhom K. lives in Doem Pour village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. In her plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field is far from the irrigation system. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy a pump in order to support the field and to use the rest of money to buy fertilizer and pesticides. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s living standard with this loan.

Mrs. Sokhom K. is 32 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, two are attending the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Yen Ry, uses a horse and cart to transport goods and passengers. He is shown with her in the photo.

loans.use: To buy an irrigation pump, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn R. is 49 years old and is happily married to her husband, Melchor. Together with their 16-year-old child, Marilyn and her husband reside in a remote village in the municipality of Dao which is located at the southwest part of the Province of Antique.

Even before Marilyn became a member of ASHI she was a dressmaker and a cosmetician while her husband was a chainsaw operator for someone who owns the machine in their village (a chainsaw is a motorized machine used for cutting down big trees). When Marilyn joined ASHI during the second half of 2008, she used her loan to support her dressmaking and cosmetology business.

After Marilyn had repaid her first loan, her husband expressed a need to have his own business. Marilyn agreed to her husband's plan considering that her husband works hard being a chainsaw operator yet the owner of the machine benefits much, much more than her husband is being paid. For this reason, Marilyn intends to use her second loan to purchase a secondhand chainsaw for her husband to increase their income. The said machine can be for rental in addition to the service charge people would need to pay for the employment of her husband.

Marilyn hopes that someday, through her loan in ASHI, she can buy a brand new chainsaw and a service vehicle to serve people in more distant places, since wood for furniture making and house building is in demand in the province. When her business grows, she would like to employ other people in their community to work with her husband and to have their own source of income.

Marilyn also dreams of sending her only child to college to ensure a better life in the future.

loans.use: To buy her husband a used chainsaw to start his own business

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarom H. lives in Prey Mei Lang Thboung village in Takeo province. She is a 31-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other one is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Thorn Kimsoeun, is shown in the picture with her.

Mrs. Sarom H. is a pig breeder and also a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband owns a machine to plow fields and is hired by the other farmers.

Mrs. Sarom H. is requesting a loan to buy more piglets and pig food. The rest of loan will be used to repair her husband’s plowing machine.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig food and to repair her husband's plowing machine

loans.name: Nova

texts.en:
Nova O. is 39 years old, married with 7 children ranging from school age to young adults. Nova's family lives in Hacienda San Jose 2, Brgy. Luna, Cadiz City, in the province of Negros Occidental.

Nova owns and operates a "sari-sari" store - the Filipino equivalent of the neighborhood General store. She opened the store soon after she became a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005. Now, her General Store earns PHP 5,000.00 per month for the O. family.

Nova has invested all of her previous loans to expand her General Store so that she could offer a wider variety of goods to her neighbors and to stay ahead of her competitors. 

For this, her 7th loan cycle, Nova is borrowing PHP 19,500 to again invest in her General Store in the hope that if she offers a wider variety than her competitors, her customers will stay loyal to her. Her business acumen is obvious in that for the past four years, her choices have always paid back for her and her family.

Erna is determined to work hard and build her business so that her family's financial standing will be on stable ground that can provide a good life for her and her family.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL CAPITAL FOR HER GENERAL STORE

loans.name: Sareon

texts.en: Mr. Sareon R. is a villager in Tuol Meas village in Kandal province. He is a fisherman. His wife, Mrs. Yim Samai, is a fish seller in the local market. Now Mr. Sareon R. is requesting a loan to buy a boat and fish food for her fish-farming business. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living conditions with this loan. She is 49 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a fisherman while the other is attending the local school. His wife is present in the picture with him.

loans.use: buy a boat and fish food for their fish-farm

loans.name: Lorna Awuor

texts.en:
Lorna is 23 years old, and she runs a small shop that sells basic goods like bread, soap, salt, and sugar. Lorna buys the products from a wholesaler in town and sells them near her home in Nyamasaria. She will use the loan to expand the room in which she is selling goods; she will also buy a larger variety of products to sell.

Lorna is well-educated; she finished high school, and hopes to save up enough money to go to university part-time for accounting. She is an unwed single mom who supports her daughter as well as her three younger siblings.

Lorna wants to open a health support group in her area, because she believes that the people in her community don’t know how to help each other. She is a community health worker already, and someday hopes to be able to expand her influence to help more sick people in her community.

K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional micro-finance institution. Rather, it is a development organization focused on raising health standards in Kenya. Many of the loan recipients from this organization are volunteer community healthcare workers like Lorna. For more information about K-MET, see the partner link on the lower right side of this webpage.

loans.use: Renovations and more supplies

loans.name: Ren

texts.en:
Mrs. Ren K. lives in An Doung Samreth village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Tom Rorn, is a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates rice. He is also a palm juice collector.

Mrs. Ren K. is asking for a loan to buy more piglets, fertilizer, and a pump to support the field. This couple has six children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while another stays at home to do housework and the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is present in the picture with her.

loans.use: to buy more piglets, fertilizer, and pump  to water the field

loans.name: Sa Rorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sa Rorn H. lives in An Doung Samreth village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to cultivate rice. In order to solve this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and to hire laborers to work on the field.  Her husband, Mr. Hean Hoeun, is a fish middleman. Mrs. Sa Rorn is 28 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and to hire laborers to work on the field

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene A. is 49 years old, married with 3 school-aged children and a resident of Brgy. Banquerohan, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental.

Arlene has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and the General Store that she owns and operates for the same length of time now earns her PHP 7,000.00 per month on the average.

As member no. 41-245-3 of the Cadiz City Branch of NWTF-Project Dungganon, Arlene has consistently paid back the loans she has taken to expand her business for the past ten years. Now on her 19th loan cycle, Arlene intends to borrow PHP 10,000.00 for additional working capital so that she could stock her store with more goods to sell.

Arlene is one of many women entrepreneurs in the island of Negros who strive hard to be financially independent and to help their families achieve economic stability, and not to remain dependent on the still pervasive mono-crop sugar industry in the province.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: MORE STOCKS TO SELL IN HER GENERAL STORE

loans.name: Margaret Kanini

texts.en:
Margaret Kanini M. is a dairy farmer in Muguga, Kikuyu, a suburb of Nairobi. She is married and has three children. She has been in the livestock and dairy business for the past 10 years. She sells milk and this includes delivery to the local cooperative society.  She has been getting a profit of about 25,000 kshs per month.

Kanini has never borrowed from any other MFI. It is her dream to own a dairy processing firm and sell hay on a more commercial scale.


About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: purchase two cows, increase stock of hay (animal feed) and repair cow shed

loans.name: Beatrice Akinyi

texts.en:
Beatrice is in the food business and has been for over 24 years. She runs a small take-away café in the center of the Nyamasaria area of Kisumu. Her business has been very successful—there have been times when she has tried to stop selling food, but her customers keep coming, wanting her food.

At times, Beatrice has trouble keeping up with the demand for her meals: 'ugali', meat, fish, and cabbage. She would like a loan to purchase more supplies so that she can keep up with the flow of customers. She can be heard in the video above saying, “I will always bless God if I can get this loan so that I can boost my business so that I can go on well with all my family.” As a mother of eight children, she hopes to earn enough income to provide for their meals and school fees.

loans.use: Supplies to make food

loans.name: Alice Muthoni

texts.en:
Alice Muthoni N. is a 39-year-old seamstress; she is married and they have three children.  She is a seamstress specialized in making bed covers and curtains. She has been in the market for about 20 years making a monthly profit of about kshs 30,000.

Alice was introduced to KADET by a friend. She was a client of another MFI but moved to KADET after relocating to Nairobi.  With her loan, Alice intends to add more materials in order to meet her  increasing client needs. She hopes to scale up the making of bedding and upholstery, targeting urban clients.



About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: Buying more materials for sewing

loans.name: Samuel Muiruri

texts.en:
Samuel Muiruri N. is a petty trader who runs a retail shop in Nderi shopping center, on the outskirts of Nairobi city. He has been running this business for over four years. He estimates that he has been posting a profit of Kshs 16,000 per month.

He has not borrowed from any other financial institution before, but this will be his second loan with KADET. He hopes to expand his retail shop into a wholesale business and grow his current client base.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: Procurring additional stock for his retail business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increasing her stock of hairdressing and beauty products at her salon

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This borrower has asked to be visually removed from the Kiva website

loans.use: to increase her assortment of goods

loans.name: Rose Nyambura

texts.en:
Rose Nyambura W. is married with 2 children.

She has been carrying out research and consultancy services for various companies and also auditing their books for the last one and a half years. In her enterprise Rose has employed two staff persons. Her office is situated in the busy Woodley Estate, in Nairobi, which is easily accessible to her clients.

She was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a client. Previously she had serviced a loan with a local bank. She estimates that her monthly income is Kshs. 250,000. In order to increase her earnings, she intends to increase her research network.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: Increasing  network to expand her research and consultancy services business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For expanding the offerings of her produce stand.

loans.name: Peter Nyange

texts.en:
Peter Nyange M. is a 32-year-old businessman, married with two children.

He owns a small retail shop (kiosk) where he sells different household goods. He plans to expand his business by purchasing  a motorbike that will enable him diversify his sources of income.

Peter has been running this business for over ten years.  He has not borrowed from another MFI and was introduced  by a friend who is a KADET client. 


About KADET

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorbike for use as a taxi

loans.name: Maria Angelita

texts.es:
Señora María vive en el barrio la Playa, es un barrio ubicado  en el sector rural Cruz del Camino en la Comunidad del Valle, a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Cuenca, su clima es bonito  y variado, las tierras son buenas para las siembras, cosechan maíz, fréjol, papas, verduras, no en gran cantidad porque la gente sale a la ciudad a trabajar, pero si para abastecer al sector, y para consumo propio de los dueños, además se dedican a la cría de animales como vacas, borregos, pollos, gansos, cuyes, y otros.

María tiene 40 años de edad, es casada, tiene 4 hilos de 21, 18, 16 y 15 años, el de 21 estudia en el SECAP(es un centro de capacitación profesional en Cuenca), los tres restantes estudian en el colegio del Valle, el esposo trabaja de albañil en la ciudad de Cuenca, cuenta que el barrio es tranquilo y unido, viven en armonía con su familia,  Es presidenta del Banco Comunal, se dedica al comercio de ganado hace unos 10 años, asiste a las ferias de ganado los días Jueves, Sábados y Domingos, en diferentes partes de la provincia, cuenta que el negocio si es rentable ya que casi nunca pierde, cuando esta tan mala la feria solo recupera el capital, pero por lo general gana un aproximado de 30 a 40 dólares por cabeza de ganado, y cuando no se puede vender para no perder los lleva a su casa para sacarlos la próxima semana.
Es socia ya hace mucho tiempo,  este crédito que solicita es de 1100 dólares, que es para invertir en el negocio, dice que cada cabeza de ganado compra más o menos a unos 250 a 300 dólares, el único inconveniente que tiene es que al realizar el préstamo  tiene que pagar intereses y es lo que le hace pensar mucho según ella que el monto es alto y la meta que tiene es poder tener su propio capital para trabajar y no tener que estar pagando intereses.
texts.en:
Ms. Maria lives in the neighborhood of La Playa, located in the rural sector of Cruz del Camino in the community of Valle, which is 45 minutes from the city of Cuenca. The climate is lovely and varied. The land is good for crops. They grow corn, beans, potatoes, and green vegetables. The harvest is not large because the people are leaving to work in the city, but is enough to supply the farmers and the community. They also raise their own animals, as well as those of others, such as cattle, sheep, chicken, and geese. Maria is 40 years old, is married, and has 4 children aged 21, 18, 16, and 15 years. The 21 year-old studies at the SECAP, a professional training center in Cuenca. The remaining three children study at the high school in Valle. Her husband works as a bricklayer in the city of Cuenca. She says that the neighborhood is peaceful and united and her family lives in harmony there. She is president of the Communal Bank, has raised livestock for 10 years, and attends livestock markets on Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays in different parts of the province. She says that the business is profitable and almost never loses money. When the fair goes badly her only returns are the original capital, but in general she earns approximately $30-40 per head of cattle. When she cannot sell the cattle above a losing price she brings them back home so that she can sell them at a profit next week.

She has been a partner for quite a while. She is asking for a loan of $1100 to invest in the business. Each head of cattle costs about $250 to $300. The only drawback of the loan is that interest has to be paid and seems high, so her goal is to develop her own capital to invest so that she will not have to pay interest.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in a business that buy heads of cattle

loans.name: Emerita

texts.en:
Emerita is a 48-year-old mother to two; a boy and a girl. She is happily married to Din-Din who is a jeepney driver and is 48 years old. She lives in the town of Angono, Rizal province in the Philippines. She has strong determination to bring her family out from poverty.

In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.),an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with hope to have access to capital for her business: a sari-sari store (general store). Her previous loan was prudently invested in her sari-sari store and it brings her enough proceeds for her family.

Now on her 2nd loan, she proposes the amount of 10,000 pesos to pay for sacks of rice, gallons of cooking oil, liquors, beverages and groceries for her store. She is hopeful that her business will continue to grow and she is looking forward to saving for the future of her two kids. She intends to be able to send her children to school until college and also to expand her store into a much bigger one.

loans.use: To pay for sacks of rice, gallons of cooking oil, liquors, beverages, and groceries for her store

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
JOCELYN DINXON is a 46-year old mother of 2 who lives in the village of Chambery in the town of Manapla, Negros Occidental with her husband and young adult children.

For a good portion of their married life, Jocelyn and her husband managed to eke out a living by fishing and selling the catch in the local market. In 2002 JoCelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in the hope that with the much needed capital her family could finally become self-reliant.

By wisely handling the profits they earned from previous loan cycles, Jocelyn's family was able to finally own a motorized pumpboat which dramatically boosted their earning capacity. Their fishing venture nets about PHP 3,500.00 per month.

For her 8th loan cycle, Jocelyn wants to borrow PHP 9,500.00 as additional working capital for their fishing and fish vending activities.

With her 2 children grown into adulthood, Jocelyn feels that with the additional capital, the business expansion will be able to accommodate and support more members of her family so that they can all earn a comfortable living from this business activity that they have become experts in.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: ADDITIONAL WORKING CAPITAL FOR EXPANSION OF BUSINESS

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene has owned and run a small retail shop for the past six years. A 25-year-old mother of two, Irene has requested her first loan of Ksh. 20,000 in order to buy a stock of cereals, wheat and maize flour. She hopes that this loan will help to raise her income and allow her to pay school fees for her children. One day, Irene wants to buy a plot of land and build her own home away from the Mukuru slums where she currently lives and works. Irene describes herself as sincere and loving.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a deposit-taking microfinance company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Buy stock of cereals

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Eden is happily married to Noel who is 54 years old. She is mother to five; four of her children are already adults and her youngest child is only 6 years old. She lives in the town of Angono, Rizal province in the Philippines.

Her ambition to rise above poverty brought Eden to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2008. Her previous loan was fully utilized for her business: a sari-sari store (general store). And the store as properly managed, brings her good income that can sustain the basic needs of the family.

Now she is excited to receive a loan of 10,000 pesos to pay for 4 sacks of rice, liquors, beverages, cigarettes and groceries for her store. She has hopes of expanding her business into a bigger store and also to be able to save for the school fees of her youngest son. She also aspires to having a house of her own.

loans.use: To pay for 4 sacks of rice, liquors, beverages, cigarettes and groceries for her store

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy Muthoni is a 38-year-old mother of 4 who lives and operates her small business in Mukuru  slums. She previously worked as a temporary worker in a biscuit manufacturing company until she started her business of selling clothes, shoes and household items. She is asking for her first loan of Ksh. 20,000 so as to add stock of new clothes. She hopes that one day she will have financially independent children and a happy family. She describes herself as happy and jovial.


Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a deposit-taking microfinance company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: add stock of new clothes

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
MERIAM F. of Brgy. Chambery, Manapla, Negros Occidental, is a 36 year-old married woman with 3 school-age children who owns and operates a fishing business.

Fishing has been the main source of income for the F. family for the last 10 years, and since Meriam joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000, profits from their business and additional loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon has allowed Meriam and her husband to own 2 fishing vessels which they use to catch crabs. This earns them approximately PHP 15,000.00 per month.

Now for her 14th loan with NWTF-Project Dungganon, Meriam wants to borrow PHP 19,500 as additional capital to expand her fishing business even further. Even though the 2 fishing boats already earns them quite a comfortable living, Meriam is striving even harder so that her children will have a better life, and better education.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: BUSINESS EXPANSION

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is a woman determined to rise above poverty. She is a 35-year-old mother to five children; all young and still dependent on her. She lives in Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines.

She is an opportunity seeker. In 2008, when she heard about ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, she grabbed the opportunity of joining it. Her previous loans were used as capital for her resale of assorted biscuits that she sells in schools and in public places.

Now on her 3rd loan, she proposes the amount of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. The loan will be used as rolling capital for her resale business. She is hopeful that with the opportunity and trust given by ASHI and KIVA, she will be able to make her business grow so it will bring her enough proceeds for her living. She dreams of sending all her children to school until they finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: as rolling capital for her resale business

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is a business manager of her own enterprise. She is 36 years old and mother to four children: two girls and two boys. She is happily married to Noel, a rickshaw driver, who is 39 years old. She lives in Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines.

She believes that it's not poverty that can hinder her way to success if she knows how to fight it. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with hope to have access to capital to finance her business, resale of rice.

Now on her 3rd loan, she proposes a loan of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. Specifically to pay for 10 sacks of rice and for the transportation expenses. Since rice is the staple food for Filipinos, she is positive that her business will click and will always be in demand.

She is hopeful that she can save for the future of her children and aspires to building a house of her own.

loans.use: To pay for 10 sacks of rice and for the transportation expenses

loans.name: Vista Al Mar 1 Group

texts.en:
Ana D. L. R. (pictured middle) is a hardworking mother of five who sells clothing in her neighborhood close to the Dominican Republic city of Samaná. Ana recently paid off her first loan, and is taking out this loan to continue to expand her clothing sales.

Ana first began selling fruit a few years ago, but found sales to be slow. When Kiva partner, Esperanza, approached her earlier this year, she took advantage of her first loan to start a clothing business. She now travels to the capital of Santo Domingo to purchase clothing to sell, and has found business to be brisk.

Though her business is less than a year old, Ana has found it possible to not only support her five children still living at home, but also to raise her two-year-old grandson. With the earnings from her business, she has been able to buy a grill to cook food, and various items for her kitchen. She hopes in the future to build her home from concrete rather than wood, and to support her children in college.

Thank you for giving to this Kiva loan! Ana and the rest of her group are dedicated to using it to grow their respective businesses and to improve their families' standard of living.

loans.use: To buy clothing and shoes for resale

loans.name: Volonte Plus Group

texts.fr:
Volonté est un groupe basé à Kisangani en République Démocratique du Congo constitué de 30 membres.  Un de ces membres est Joseph B..

Joseph est infirmier de formation et gère sa propre pharmacie depuis 2007. Il exerce son activité commerciale à l’est de Kisangani, une ville qui a été détruite par des affrontements meurtriers des armées étrangères en l’an 2000. Kisangani se situe au nord-est de la République Démocratique du Congo dans la Province Orientale qui fait frontière avec l’Ouganda et le Soudan. Joseph a commencé son activité entant qu’infirmier ambulant qui soignait des malades dans son milieu. Soucieux de desservir la population son quartier en médicaments, il décide en 2007 avec l’appui financier de Hope Kisangani à travers des crédits, d’ouvrir une pharmacie qui lui génère aujourd’hui un bénéfice de $350 par mois. Pour réaliser son rêve d’ouvrir un jour un Centre de Santé, Joseph a décidé en 2007 d’intégrer un des groupes de Hope Kisangani dénommé « Volonté Plus  Kis ». Il y est vice-président. Ce groupe « Volonté Plus  Kis », est le premier groupe de Hope Kisangani à bénéficier des prêts de Kiva. Le prochain prêt que Joseph recevra lui servira d’acheter des produits pharmaceutiques qui renforceront le stock de sa pharmacie en vue d’accroitre le revenu.  Il est âgé de 41 ans, marié et père de 5 enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 6 et 21 ans. Deux d’entre eux sont scolarisés.
texts.en:
Volonté is a group based in Kisangani in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The group is comprised of 30 members. One of those members is Joseph B.. Joseph is trained to be a nurse and has owned his own pharmacy since 2007. He does his business east of Kisangani, a city that was destroyed by deadly clashes of foreign armies in the year 2000. Kisangani is located in the north-east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, in the Province Oriental which borders with Uganda and the Sudan. Joseph started his business as an independent nurse who treated patients from his home. Concerned with serving his neighborhood’s community’s needs for medicines, in 2007 he decided to open a pharmacy with the financial support of loans from Hope Kisangani. Today that pharmacy generates a profit of $350 per month for him. In order to realize his dream of one day opening a Health Clinc, in 2007 Joseph decided to join one of Hope Kisangani’s group – the group is called “Volonté Plus Kis”. He is the vice president of the group. The group “Volonté Plus Kis” is the first of Hope Kisangani’s groups to receive loans from Kiva. Joseph will use the next loan that he receives to buy the pharmaceutical products that will increase his pharmacy’s stock and therefore grow his revenue. He is 41 years old, married and the father of 5 children; the children’s ages range from 6 to 21 years. Two of the children are attending school.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Top buy pharmaceutical products

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Ana Julia

texts.es:
la señora Ana Julia P. Z. tiene 28 años de edad, tiene dos hijos y esta casada con el señor Adolfo Enrique Barahona quien labora como guardia de seguridad en almacenes el compadre.
ella se dedica a la produccion y venta de tortillas desde hace 05 años, su negocio esta ubicado en el barrio san jose y ademas trabaja en una clinica por la noche ya que ella es tambien enfermera
 
Ana necesita el prestamo para comprar 12 cargas de maiz 800 de leña, carnes, huevos, repollo, tomate etc porque ella esta vendiendo golosinas los fines de semana, con esta actividad acaba de empezar y le esta llendo muy bien.
 
su sueño es tener un taller de tortillas bien acondicionado.
texts.en:
Ana Julia P. Z. is 28, and she has two children. She is married to Adolfo Enrique Barahona. He works as a security guard in a friend’s establishment. She makes and sells tortillas. She has been doing this for five years. Her business is located in the San José neighborhood. She also works as a nurse in a clinic in the evening. Ana needs a loan to buy 12 loads of corn, 800 of wood, meat, eggs, cabbage, and tomatoes. She sells sweets on the week ends. She just started this activity, and it is going very well. Her dream is to have a well equipped tortilla shop.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wood, lime, corn flour, water, meat, eggs, cabbage, and tomatoes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Dos De Mayo Group

texts.en:
The communal bank "Dos de Mayo" (Second of May) was founded on July 13th, 2009. The bank members live in Yarinacocha, a small town next to the city of Pucallpa. This will be their first loan from Kiva partner Manuela Ramos. Ynes V. L. is the official president of "Dos de Mayo" and has a business selling soft drinks and fruit.

This communal bank has 10 members (the extra person in the photograph, second from the left in the top row, is not a member; she attended the meeting together with her daughter, who is a member). The members of "Dos de Mayo" are requesting a total loan of 2800 Nuevos Soles; each member will invest her share in her respective business. The women dedicate themselves to selling the following different items: candies, charcoal, cooked food, fruit, hot dogs and French fries, fish, soft drinks, cheese, and basic grocery goods.

The members of "Dos de Mayo" are grateful to Manuela Ramos for their loan and are pleased that the organization has confidence in them. They are dedicated to furthering their businesses and making their loan payments responsibly and on time.

loans.use: Goods for respective businesses of the communal bank members.

loans.name: Jairo

texts.en:
Jairo came to the United States from Colombia 24 years ago; he is married and has two children. After the loss of his job and with 500 dollars, Jairo started his own office furniture business. Eight years ago, he began by visiting offices to make sales; now he runs his business selling products on E-Bay as well. 
 
For a long time, Jairo couldn’t find any funding for his business, he tried a bank but they considered his business too informal. To purchase inventory, he needed to rely on his savings, business profits, and the income from his full-time job. He came to ACCION USA and has been approved for a loan to purchase “previously owned” cubicles and chairs to sell through his E-Bay business. 


With the loan he is hoping to increase his profits; with the extra income he wants to make improvements to his family's home. Jairo plans to continue formalizing his business over the coming years. Eventually he would like to expand his business internationally.

loans.use: Used cubicles and chairs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Advertising

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela C. G. is 48 years old and lives in the city of Pucallpa. Adela is married with two children. Adela, her husband, and their daughter Claudia Pamela are co-owners of "Hospedaje Orquídea" (The Orchid Hostel), which is located near their home.

Adela belongs to the communal bank "Las Guerreras" (The Warriors) and has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about two years. She and her family will soon open a billiard room in addition to running their hostel. Adela invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in the hostel, supporting the family business. Adela is currently requesting a loan of 3,000 soles, which she plans to invest in maintenance of the hostel as well as in opening the new billiard room. Adela's daughter, Claudia Pamela, is also a co-owner of this new business.

Adela is grateful to Manuela Ramos for the financial support, which will help her and her family move forward with their businesses. She is also pleased to be able to learn from the organization's loan officers, who give educational sessions at her communal bank's monthly meetings.

loans.use: Maintenance work on a hostel; opening a new billiard room

loans.name: Norma Gladys

texts.en:
Señora Norma is a 49-year-old single mother with one daughter. She lives just outside the city of Pucallpa. Norma is an independent businesswoman, dedicating herself to the sale of beauty products, kitchen supplies, purses, and other items.

Norma has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for nine years and belongs to the communal bank "Las Guerreras" (The Warriors). She used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to purchase sandals to sell. Eventually, the sale of sandals and other goods replaced the laundry business that she had at that time. (Norma used to take clothes in for washing).  

At this time, Norma is requesting a loan of 2,500 soles, which she will invest in her business. Norma plans to use the funds to construct a small store space within her home where she will display her goods. Norma is grateful to Manuela Ramos for the financial support. With her loans, her earnings from her business, and a lot of hard work, Norma has been able to purchase land for her home, construct her house, and create her own business. She plans to continue working with Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Construction of a small store space to display goods for sale

loans.name: Luz Divina Group

texts.en:
Diana G. D. L. R. is the coordinator for Luz Divina, a microfinance group in Sosua. Her neighborhood is deeply impoverished, but is located amidst the lush hills of the Dominican north coast. Diana is 40 years old and lives with her husband, Orlando, and two of her three children – Rolando, Ronaldo, and Franklin – who are aged 24, 21, and 19 years respectively. Rolando lives by himself and runs a baseball field near his mother’s neighborhood. Ronaldo and Franklin both enjoy playing basketball and hiking through the beautiful wilderness that surrounds their home. They both attend a local public school.

Diana says that she enjoys listening to music and is especially fond of cooking. With this in mind, she opened a small food shop in her house. There she sells bread, beans, rice, sugar, ham, and other basic ingredients. Diana owned the business before coming to Kiva partner, Esperanza, for a loan, and was able to make about 4,000 DOP a month. Since then, she has taken three loans (including this one) to purchase increasing amounts of inventory. Diana says that with Esperanza, she has managed to increase her monthly income by 5,000 to 6,000 DOP.

This additional money has given Diana breathing room to start thinking about her future. She has been experiencing a great deal of chest pain recently and would like to hire a doctor. Additionally, she would like to renovate the walls of her home. Diana currently has untreated wooden walls that gather termites and rot. She would like to build cement walls to solve this problem. Diana relies on loans from Esperanza to continue the growth of her business. With access to microcredit, she has the power to bring these dreams into reality.

loans.use: To purchase food items for resale

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is a 44-year-old father of 6, who owns a pharmacy and clinic in the Mukuru slums of Nairobi. Elijah has requested a loan of 25,000 KES in order to increase his stock of medicine, as well as purchase airtime to sell. He believes this loan will allow him to expand the business, boost income, and improve his family’s situation. Elijah hopes to one day become a wholesaler and purchase a plot to build on. He also wants to build a home, move his family to a place with more security, and eventually help others in need. 

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of drugs and airtime

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase shoes for resale

loans.name: Justus

texts.en:
Justus owns a tailoring and embroidery shop. He is 32 years old and married, with two children ages 10 and 6. Justus has already successfully paid off two loans, purchasing three embroidery machines. Justus has now requested a third loan of 40,000 KES in order to purchase an additional sewing machine and materials. He hopes these investments will allow him to increase production, thereby increasing income to meet the needs of his family. In the future, Justus hopes to open additional shops to meet the demand of his customers, and to succeed in an environment of increasing competition. He dreams of owning a home. Justus describes himself as generous and friendly.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine and stock materials

loans.name: Randolfo De La Cruz

texts.es:
En el municipio El Viejo de la ciudad de Chinandega, el señor Randolfo E. se dedica a su actividad de venta de repuestos de bicicletas las cuales son comercializadas por el mismo en su propio local fijo donde a diario le visitan clientes para la compra de repuestos. También es importante destacar que él tiene muchas habilidades para reparar las bicicletas. 

La razón por la que el señor Randolfo ha acudido a Ceprodel es para solicitar un crédito para la compra de los repuestos y de esta manera ofertarlos en su establecimiento con el fin de obtener ingresos para continuar manteniendo su núcleo familiar.
texts.en:
Randolfo E. sells bicycle replacement parts in the El Viejo municipality of the city of Chandega. He sells them from his own fixed location. Every day customers come to buy replacement parts. It is important to note that he is very talented at repairing bicycles. The reason that Randolfo has come to Cerodel to ask for a loan is to buy replacement parts. This way he can sell them in his establishment and get the income to continue supporting his nuclear family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bicycle replacement parts

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Supply her store

loans.name: Lili

texts.en:
Señora Lili is 62 years old, single, and has one child. She lives near the center of the city of Pucallpa. She is one of three co-owners of a restaurant called "Chicharrones Porkys", which is located next to her house. The other two co-owners are Lili's siblings.

Lili has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about nine years and is a member of the communal bank, "Las Guerreras" (“The Warriors”). Lili invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in the sale of fruits and juices. Later, she and her siblings set up their restaurant, which specializes in chicharrones (fried pork rinds).

Lili is currently requesting a loan of 3,000 soles which she will invest both in her restaurant and in the production of corn and papaya on her farm outside the city.

Lili has worked well with Manuela Ramos over the past nine years. The organization has helped her through some difficult times. She was even able to construct her house with the help of loans from Manuela Ramos and earnings from her business.
