Lili is committed to making her loan payments on time and to being a responsible member of her communal bank.

loans.use: To invest both in her restaurant and in the production of corn and papaya on her farm

loans.name: Amanda

texts.en:
Amanda’s extensive legal knowledge and passion for helping people from El Salvador have provided her with the perfect recipe for starting her own business.

A licensed attorney in her home country of El Salvador, Amanda has been working for years at an office that specializes in providing legal advice to Salvadorians living in the U.S. However, she realized she could provide more help to the Salvadorian community by opening her own office and providing additional services.

Servicios Internacionales Salvadoreños will provide legal document preparation, legal consultation, and attorney locator services for clients seeking assistance with legal matters in or pertaining to El Salvador. Amanda hopes that her expertise in El Salvador law will provide much-needed advice to individuals with property or business in El Salvador, as well as the Salvadorian community of the Bay Area.

Amanda will continue to work at her existing job at a money-transfer company and run her business in the afternoon and evening. With deep connections to the Salvadorian community, she is confident that her network will provide a steady client base. 

A $2,000 loan will help Amanda with many of the start-up costs for her business including rent, marketing, licenses, and supplies.

loans.use: Business start-up costs

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 38-year-old mother of six who owns a chemist shop (pharmacy) called Stewards Medical Care in the Mukuru slums of Nairobi. Margaret began her business hawking medicine (going door-to-door) for three years before opening her shop.

Margaret has requested a loan of Ksh 20,000 to increase her stock of medicines. She hopes to one day open another pharmacy. She dreams of educating her children, owning her own home, and learning to drive a car. Margaret describes herself as hard-working and jovial.


About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To increase her stock of medicines

loans.name: Nubia

texts.en:
Nubia sells gold and bronze jewelry such as chains, bracelets, charms, rings, and earrings at a flea market in San Jose, California.

Prior to renting the booth at the flea market, Nubia worked for her friend’s business, selling jewelry at shows, fairs, and hospitals for over two years. She decided she wanted to pursue her own business, and her friend encouraged her to do so. Nubia is excited to purchase her own stock of inventory and become a business owner using the skills learned from her friend’s business and from a business training course she recently attended.

In time, Nubia hopes her business will grow and provide enough income to support herself and her husband, who is a retired engineer. Both Nubia and her husband currently work part-time to make ends meet. A $5,000 loan will enable Nubia to purchase her stock of inventory to be sold at the flea market.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her jewelry sales

loans.name: Alfayo

texts.en:
Alfayo is a 25 year-old father of one who sells charcoal in the Mukuru slums of Nairobi. Previously, Alfayo worked as a security guard for two years before starting his own business with one sack of charcoal. Today, Alfayo has grown to own a stock of 8 sacks of charcoal. He has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenyan Shillings in order to purchase a new business premises and add stock. This will be Alfayo’s third loan, and he has seen his business grow immensely since becoming a Faulu Kenya client. He hopes to one day diversify his business to also sell cereals.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Buy a new business premises and add stock

loans.name: Mujeres De Debora Group

texts.en:
Marta P. is the group leader of Mujeres de Debora in Llano de Perez, a small town west of Puerto Plata. At the age of 48, Marta is happily married to her husband, Elvis, and is the proud mother of two boys, Emmanuel and Laurie. Recently, Emmanuel began studying at a university in Puerto Plata. Marta is grateful that her son was accepted into a university; however, the costs are a substantial burden on her family.

Marta believes that the best way for her to ease the financial load is by expanding her small but successful underwear business. Once a month, Marta’s niece drives six hours from La Romania to Llano de Perez and delivers clothes to Marta. After receiving the clothes Marta spends a couple of hours a day selling them until she is out of inventory. With the help of Kiva partner Esperanza, Marta hopes to be able to buy more clothes for resale. She believes that although she will have to spend more time working, the extra profit she will make from having a larger inventory will be worth it.

Marta is excited at the thought of borrowing from Esperanza. She hopes that with the money Esperanza provides she will eventually be able to open a clothing store. Although she believes that owning her own store will take a while, she says that if she works hard she knows her dreams can come true.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Luciola

texts.en:
Señora Luciola is a 52-year-old married mother of three children.  She lives in the city of Pucallpa.  Her husband works as a driver, and Luciola has a workshop where she designs and sews clothing for sale.

Luciola has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about nine years and belongs to the communal bank "Las Guerreras" (The Warriors).  With her first loan of 300 soles (about $100), Luciola invested in materials for making undergarments, and also for seamstress studies.  Later on she was able to construct her own workshop.  With this loan of 1500 soles, Luciola hopes to purchase more fabric and other sewing materials, items which will enable her to continue developing her small business bit by bit.

Luciola is grateful for the support she receives from Manuela Ramos.  The organization has helped her during times of financial difficulty and has educated her about business.  She is committed to being punctual in her loan payments and to being a responsible member of her communal bank.

loans.use: To buy fabric and other materials for sewing.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina will be the first to tell you that she runs her day-care business out of love, rather than money. Establishing a day-care business out of her home, she is most proud of the fact that children remain at her center for an average of 1-2 years, much longer than the 3-6 months they spend on average at other home-based centers. Christina is passionate about making it her life's work to be a positive influence in these children's lives.

Having taken out a number of loans with ACCION USA, Christina has been able to purchase supplies and toys that enable her to provide a richer educational experience for children than those of competing businesses. Christina will use her latest loan to purchase an outdoor playhouse and picnic table so that her children can take advantage of the warm weather in the summer months to play outside. She would like to take out future loans to purchase a computer that her kids can use to play educational games.

Christina dreams of expanding her business from her home to a day-care center. She is confident that she will be able to do this with ACCION USA's help, as she builds her reputation in her community by providing a loving and comfortable learning environment for children.

loans.use: To buy an outdoor playhouse and picnic table

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en: Rose N. is a hardworking and devoted 45-year-old single mother of 4 children ages 23 – 29.  All of her children have finished school and she cares for 6 other dependents. Rose is a farmer with 5 years experience and her main business challenges are climate changes, being able to find high quality seeds, pests and diseases, and the monkeys that eat up the crops before harvest. At the moment, Rose is able to make weekly profits of 40,000 UGX as a result of the high quality produce she gets from her farm. She has a dream of buying more land for additional farming so that she can earn more profits. With this loan she needs to buy more seeds.

loans.use: To buy more seeds for farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more stock of sausages, bacon, hot dogs and chicken.

loans.name: Fabio

texts.en: Mr. Fabio is from the City of Carapeguà. He is 58 years old and is married to Mrs. Juana Sànchez. Together, they have 2 adult daughters.  For more than 10 years, he has worked as a building contractor and is well known in his area.  He did not have the opportunity to attend school, so he had to look for an alternative to support his family and chose to work as a bricklayer.  Thanks to the income generated from his work he was able to feed his family and put a roof over their head, working with integrity.  With the loan he will buy a construction machine.

loans.use: The purchase of materials and equipment for construction.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 24-year-old father of one child.  He owns a food kiosk serving beef, beans, chapati, ugali, and other traditional Kenyan food. Previously, Peter ran a general produce stand for two years. He has requested a loan of 40,000 KES in order to add stock and boost his income. This is Peter’s second loan; his first loan of 20,000 KES allowed him to open the food kiosk, as well as a stall to sell CDs. In the future, Peter hopes to diversify his business, purchasing transport vehicles and rental homes. He also hopes to educate his children in a good school, and live a comfortable life. 

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Purchase more stock for his food kiosk.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a 42-year-old father of 2 living and operating his food kiosk business in the expansive Mukuru Slum in Nairobi Kenya. He began his food kiosk business 8 years ago after working as house help for some time. He is asking for a first loan of Ksh. 10,000 to buy supplies for his food kiosk. He hopes that one day he will buy land and build his own house. He also desires to give quality education to his children. He describes himself as a good, diligent manager.
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his food kiosk

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob is a 30-year-old father of one child.  He runs a kiosk in the Mukuru slums of Nairobi. Before opening his business, Jacob worked as a supervisor on a flower farm. He has requested a loan of 20,000 KES in order to purchase additional stock of flour, sugar, and cooking fat. He hopes to grow his business and continue taking out larger loans. Jacob hopes to one day build a home and educate his family. He describes himself as a diligent businessman.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Buy more stock of flour, sugar, and cooking fat.

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en: Josephine N. is the leader of her subgroup of Suubilyamukama. She is a married lady with a business of selling both new and used clothes. Before, she dealt in only new clothes but diversified to make more profits.  She earns about 150,000 UGX at the moment. Josephine says that her main challenge in the business is the competition but because she always has enough stock and delivers good customer care, her customers keep coming back to her. She hopes to one day start a wholesale clothing selling business as well as buy her own house. Apart from her business, the loans have always helped in paying school fees for her children and dependents. She is a mother of 5 children and she cares for other orphaned children also in school.

loans.use: Restocking her clothing business.

loans.name: Rinconcito Del Cielo Group

texts.es:
“Rinconcito del cielo” es una Asociación Comunal que pertenece al Centro Focal “Panamericana”, están juntas hace aproximadamente 5 años, una de las fundadoras del grupo es Sofía M., que actualmente es la presidenta, cuenta que se agruparon por la necesidad de acceder a un crédito y de iniciar un negocio propio que les permita generar ingresos para darles alimentación, vestimenta y techo a sus familias. Actualmente todas tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de comida, zapatos, velas, papa, queso, maletines, fruta y confección de faldas y necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería (zapatos, velas, papa, queso, maletines, mandarina, naranja y tela).

A ellas les agrada mucho compartir, dicen que se olvidan de sus problemas.
texts.en:
“Rinconcito del cielo” (a little corner of heaven) is a community association that belongs to the Centro Focal Panamericana. They have belonged for approximately 5 years. One of the founders of the group is Sofia M. who is currently the president. She says that they joined together for the need for access to credit and to begin their own business that will allow them to generate income to provide food, clothing and shelter to their families. Currently all of them have their own businesses such as selling food, shoes, candles, potatoes, cheese, bags, fruits and sewing skirts. They need the loan to buy merchandise (shoes, candles, potatoes, cheese, bags, tangerines, oranges and fabric).

They are very pleased to share and say that they are forgetting their problems.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise (shoes, candles, potatoes, cheese, bags, oranges, fabric)

loans.name: Victor Hugo

texts.en: Señor Victor V. is from the city of Quiindy. He is married to Señora Carmen Venegas Ojeda, and they have 2 adult children. They live in their own house and own a taxi servicing people in the city of Quiindy and surrounding rural areas.  He wants to support his family and have a good life.  With the loan, he will purchase a cover for his vehicle.

loans.use: The purchase of a cover for his vehicle.

loans.name: Viola's Group

texts.en: Viola K. is the leader of Suubilyamukama group in Lugazi. She is a married mother of 3 children ages 1-4 and she cares for 3 orphans. Viola is a fish monger who started with silverfish but 2 years ago started dealing in dried fish and as a result, she was able to make more money. She says that she is able to earn a profit of 160,000 UGX a month because of the quality of her fish, and also she provides good customer care.  She hopes to use her savings in the future to build a house for her family, as well as expand her business further. Viola will use the loan to buy more fish for resale.

loans.use: Buy more fish for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To develop a cushion to pay her employees weekly and to purchase tools and equipment

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a 34-year-old husband and new father who sells items on the street in the Mukuru slums of Nairobi. Previously, Stephen worked in a garage for 6 years before setting up his own business. Stephen has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase additional stock including plates, cups, pegs, hair buds and beauty items. He hopes to one day own a shop, as well as a vehicle to transport stock. 

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add stock of cups, plates, pegs and beauty items.

loans.name: Gladis Alvarenga De

texts.en:
Señora Gladis Alvarenga is a 46-year-old mother of 2 adult daughters who lives with her family in the city of Carapeguá.  She started her business in 1992 with a small shop in the local city market together with her husband, using their own capital. Because of growing demand, she later worked with the Kiva field partner lender Fundación Paraguaya which was recommended by her brother who was also a client of the institution.

It is worth pointing out that thanks to her effort, she was able to achieve goals such as building her own house, giving her daughters the opportunity to become college graduates, and also expanding her business since she has already built a great number of market shops to sell at.

She is requesting a loan to purchase shirts, pants, jerseys, and coats.

loans.use: The purchase of shirts, pants, jerseys, and coats.

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en: Betty N. is the leader of her subgroup of Suubilyamukama. She is a mother of 6 children ages 10-25 and all are in school, and she cares for other orphans. She has a business selling secondhand children's clothes in the town center and because she has done this a long time she has many customers. Betty says that she started very small due to lack of enough capital but now that she has access to loans to buy more stock, she makes more sales hence more profits. She dreams of building a permanent house as well as educating all her children at the university level. She needs to buy more stock for her business to increase profitability and sustainability. Betty is a determined and hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her stock.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is a 29-year-old father of two who runs a small cinema. He previously worked in the welding business for two years. Henry has requested a loan of 40,000 KES in order to buy DSTV (cable television). He believes the loan, and subsequently expanded business, will allow him to prosper and live a better life. Henry describes himself as polite and quiet and says he loves his work.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy DSTV for his cinema.

loans.name: Julia Angelica

texts.en:
Julia is 29 years old, married, and has two children with whom she is pictured here. Julia lives in the city of Pucallpa and her husband works as a bricklayer. Julia has a small business selling foods typical of the region from the front porch of her house in the evenings.

Julia has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about 1.5 years and is a member of the communal bank "Las Guerreras" (The Warriors). Julia used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to invest in basic food items with which to prepare her meals. She plans to use this loan of 1000 soles for the same purpose. Julia runs her business independently and hopes that this loan will help her to continue to grow, little by little.

Julia is pleased with the financial assistance she has received from Manuela Ramos. She also enjoys the educational sessions given by Manuela Ramos loan officers at the monthly meetings of her communal bank. With the assistance of her loans and the profits from her business, Julia purchased a piece of land and is constructing her home there.

loans.use: Basic food items for a restaurant business.

loans.name: Isaiah

texts.en:
Isaiah owns an automotive spare parts shop called Gatumah Enterprises which he has been running for the past 6 years. He is 30 years old and married. Isaiah has requested a loan of 60,000 KES in order to expand his business and purchase new products such as water pumps, pressure plates, and clutch plates. He hopes to one day open a second branch of his shop, as well as help his wife open her own clothing boutique. Isaiah describes himself as patient and industrious.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Buy pressure plates, water pumps and clutch plates for automotive shop.

loans.name: Rebecca's Group

texts.en: K. Rebecca is a businesslady who has been involved in the sale of fishnets to fishermen in Mukono District for over 10 years. She buys the nets in Uganda and, in most cases, delivers them to her customers’ homes – hence staying in close contact with them. Rebecca is a married lady and the mother of seven children, ages 8 - 20 years and all in school. She needs a loan to be able to buy more fishing nets since, whenever she buys in bulk, she is able to make more profits. This enables her to pay school fees for her children and for general upkeep.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets to sell

loans.name: Las Sembradoras Group

texts.es: “Las Sembradoras” es un grupo de señoras que se agruparon recientemente para poder acceder a un crédito ya que todas tienen diferentes negocios como la venta de verduras, muebles, ropa, gelatina y otras se dedican a negocios de producción como la costura/tejido de chompas, faldas, mantas, tallado en madera y necesitan el préstamo para la compra de mercadería (ropa de bebe, mesas, gelatina) y materia prima (madera, hilo y tela). Su Presidenta es Silvia M. y espera que el grupo crezca y poder lograr ahorros suficientes.
texts.en:
“Las Sembradoras” is a group of ladies who gathered recently to access a loan. They all have different businesses selling vegetables, furniture, clothing, gelatin and other products. Others sew or weave sweaters, skirts, and blankets. Another member sells wood carvings. Their loan will be used to purchase merchandise (baby clothes, tables, and gelatin) and raw materials (wood, yarn, and fabric). Their president is Silvia M. and she hopes that the group will grow and accumulate sufficient savings.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise & raw materials

loans.name: Catherine's Group

texts.en: A. Catherine is the leader of Khaki group in Jinja. She is 38 years old and a married mother of five children, including two sets of twins. She is a business lady involved in a drug shop business that is located in Lira District. There she employs a nurse to run the business as she buys the necessary drugs twice every month and sends them on a bus. Here in Jinja, she works as an employee in a boat-making workshop. This is her sixth loan and the previous ones have helped in paying school fees and enabling her to save for the future. She needs to buy more drugs for her drug shop.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her drug shop.

loans.name: Las Amigas Group

texts.en:
The Mujeres Emprendedoras committee “Las Amigas” live in the neighborhood of Kennedy in the city of Caacupé. The committee is composed of 18 members, all from the same area, and they are actually in the twelfth cycle of the program Committee of Mujeres Emprendedoras at Foundation Paraguaya. 

They benefit from the training each cycle where they learn themes of integration: self-esteem, savings, and budgets. The institution also benefits from the operative capital that increases to an average daily amount of 860.000 Guaraníes from each member. The money spent by the Fundacion goes directly towards the accompaniment and growth of each business mentioned above. 

All the members are thankful that the Fundacion has given them so much support despite the fact that these women have very little resources and belong to a marginalized group that limits their opportunities.

loans.use: The purchase of goods for a grocery; ingredients and materials for the production of delicacies, chipa (famous Paraguayan bread), meat, and other food; materials for the dressmaking; and wood for carpentry work.

loans.name: Leyla Marina

texts.es:
la señora leyla marina A. tiene 25 años de edad es residente del barrio san jose san lorenzo valle, esta en union libre con el señor edwin antonio N., no tienen hijos, su casa es muy bonita vive muy comoda, su sposo se dedica al transporte, negocio propio. 
 
la señora leyla tiene una pulperia en su casa, ese es su negocio desde hace 05 años,  esta ubicado en un buen lugar, es muy transitado por muchas personas, ella nos comento que le esta llendo muy bien, pero que quiere que le vaya mejor. 
 
esta solicitando el prestamo para comprar mercaderia para poder surtilo mas.
 
hace unos dias fallecio su tia  y esta muy triste, su sueño es tener un negocio mas grande.
texts.en:
Leyla Marina A., 25, lives in the San José neighborhood in the San Lorenzo Valle. She is in a common law marriage with Edwin Antonio N.. They do not have children. Her house is very pretty, and she lives very comfortably. Her husband works in his own transportation business. Leyla has a mini market in her house. She has had this business for five years. It is in a good location, which is well traveled by many people. It is going very well for her, but she wants it to go better. She is asking for a loan to buy more merchandise to stock. A few days ago her aunt died, and she is very sad. Her dream is to have a bigger business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy eggs, soft drinks, soup, toilet paper, juice, rice, beans, tortillas, corn and wheat flour

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Los Tres Amigos Group

texts.es:
el grupo solidario los tres amigos son personas que ya tiempos se conocen y siempre han trabajado juntos y son residentes de la colonia la nueva caucara.
a continuacion se detalla lo que cada uno de ellos realiza para ganarse la vida:
 
el señor Omar Abel A. tiene 33 años de edad, vive en la colonia la nueva Caucara San Lorenzo,  el viven en union libre con la señora Daysi Yamileth Avila,  dependen de ellos 04 hijos de los cuales todos estan en la escuela de la comunidad, el se dedica a la venta de chineria desde hace 06 años, negocio con el cual a podido sacar adelante a su familia necesita el prestamo para surtir un poco mas su negocio.
 
el señor Edilberto F. radica en la aldea la Criba  a 2 kilometros de la carretera panamericana su casa es de adobe repellada color blanca, esta viven en union libre con la señora Lesbia Mendez tienen dos hijos, ella es ama de casa y el se dedica al negocio de la chineria desde hace 03 años,necesita el prestamo para surtir mas su negocio.

el sr. Nelson Yovany C. A. tiene 36 años de edad, el vive en union libre con la señora 
Norma Yesenia Mendoza, tienen dos hijos, ella es ama de casa y el se dedica al negocio de venta de chinerias desde hace 07 años, sus ventas las relizan en la frontera del Amatillo, el necesita el prestamo para comprar mas mercaderia.

cabe mensionar que la venta de chineria es venta de productos de vidrio.
texts.en:
The members of the solidarity group “Los Tres Amigos” have always known each other and have worked together. They live in the Nueva Caucara development.

Below are the details of how they earn their living:

Sr. Omar Abel A. is 33 years old and lives in San Lorenzo, which is part of the Nueva Caucara development. He is in a common law marriage with Sra. Daysi Yamileth Avila. They have 4 dependent children, all of whom attend school in the community. For the past 6 years, he has been selling china so that his family can get ahead. He needs a loan so that he can buy more merchandise and generate a little more business.

Sr. Edilberto F. lives in the neighborhood of La Criba, which is 2 kilometers from the Pan American Highway. His lives in a white adobe house with his common law wife, Sra. Lesbia Mendez, and their two children. She works as a housewife and he has been selling china for the past 3 years. He is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise for his business.

Sr. Nelson Yovany C. A. is 36 years old. He and his common law wife, Sra. Norma Yesenia Mendoza, have two children. She works as a housewife and he has been selling china for the past 7 years. His sales are generated along the border in Amatillo. He will use his loan to buy more merchandise. It should be mentioned that these gentlemen also sell glassware in addition to china.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase glasses, plates, cups, bowls and vases

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Getu's Group

texts.en: K. Getu is a welcoming and determined lady and a mother of three children aged 15-7 years. She also cares for one orphan. She is a strong business lady with a wood workshop that she has operated from Bushenyi for eight years now. When she had just started with the business, people thought it was a male job but she has come to disprove all of them. She has wood products like chairs and tables for home & different office requirements – the products feed local populations of motels, schools, and general apartments. The key to her success is treating her customers as kings. She has a dream of owning multiple workshops in town plus seeing all her children attain the highest education levels. She also has a side business selling beans and this time round, she needs to buy more beans for resale using her loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of beans for resale.

loans.name: Gustavo Adolfo

texts.es:
el señor Gustavo Adolfo A. V.  tiene de 39 años de edad, vive en union libre con la señora Aris Mileny Cruz Canales, tienen dos hijos de los cuales estan en la escuela y depende de ellos al 100%, su esposa es enfermera y el se dedica  a la carpinteria, tiene 07 años de estar fabricando todo tipo de mueble de madera, el necesita el prestamo para comprar madera, tiner, lija, colorante.
su sueño es ver graduados a sus hijos y que sean buenos profesionales,. el desea lograr hacer un contrato con alguna empresa distribuidora de muebles para tener una mayor produccion y asi poder emplear personas que le ayuden a realizar su trabajo.
texts.en:
Gustavo Adolfo A. V. is 39 years old and is in a common-law marriage with Aris Mileny Cruz Canales. Gustavo and Aris have two children, both of whom are in school and are dependent on their parents. Aris works as a nurse, while Gustavo makes a living with his carpenter’s workshop. He has 7 years of experience in making all kinds of wood furniture. Gustavo needs this loan so he can purchase wood, paint thinner, sandpaper, and paint for his workshop. Gustavo’s dream is to see his children graduate from school and become successful professionals. He wants to obtain a contract with a furniture distributor so he can increase his production, which would allow him to hire some assistants to help him with his work.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing wood, glue, sandpaper, paint thinner, and paint

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Margarita Pastrana

texts.es:
la señora Margarita Pastrana M. tiene 34 años de edad, vive en union libre con el señor Rigoberto Javier Flores,  tienen un hijo, ellos no tienen casa, estan rentando desde hace 04 años. El se dedica a la albañileria y ella costura en su casa a las personas del barrio, necesita el prestamo pàra comprar una maquina nueva de costurar por que la que tiene casi ya no le sirve.
la meta de ellos es poder coprar una casa y asi tener una mejor calidad de vida, ese es su mayor sueño en esta vida y dice que trabajando duro lo va a poder cumplir.
texts.en:
Señora Margarita Pastrana M. is 34 years old and lives with her domestic partner, Señor Rigoberto Javier Flores. They have one son. They don't have their own house, but have been living where they are renting for four years. He is a construction worker and she works from her home as a seamstress for people from the neighborhood. She needs this loan to buy a new sewing machine because the one she has is almost useless. Their goal is to be able to get a house and thus have a better quality of life. That is her greatest dream in this life and she says that by working hard she is going to achieve it.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine, thread and buttons.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Edivinah's Group

texts.en:
U. Edivinah is a hard working lady with a strong drive to succeed. She is divorced but has managed to take care of her 3 children, all still in school and between the ages of 18 to 3, while she cares for 2 orphans. Edivinah has had a grocery business where she sells vegetables, beans, ground nuts and bananas for 15 years now. She is now able to make weekly profits of 100,000 Ugandan shillings (about $47 US) yet she started with capital of 50,000 shillings.

She has a dream of transforming from retail to wholesale so that she can be able to make greater profits from her sales. She needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for resale since having a bigger quantity of stock works so well for her and her family.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Juana Alberta

texts.es:
la señora Juana Alberta F. C. tiene 34 años de edad, vive en union libre con el señor Saul Martinez,  tienen un hijo pequeño, Saul trabaja en la pesca y Juana produce y vende rosquillas y tambien vende pescado que su esposo trae del mar. Juana necesita el crédito para comprar mas productos y asi tener una mayor produccion y con las ganancias que obtengan poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar. 
ella tiene muchos deseos de superarse, tambien piensa mucho en su hijo, ya que para ella es lo mas importante en su vida, quiere que sea una persona de bien y tambien profesianal.
texts.en:
Juana Alberta F. C. is 34 years old and lives with her common-law husband Saul Martinez, with whom she has a young son. Saul works as a fisherman and Juana makes and sells pastries and also sells the fish her husband brings in from the sea. She is requesting the loan to purchase more production so she can increase her production. With the increase in profits, she can help her husband with household expenses. She has a strong desire to move up in life, and also thinks a lot about her son, who is the most important thing in her life. She wants him to be a good and successful person.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase curd, cheese, flour, fireword, lard, salt and plastic bags for her pastry business.

loans.name: Nuevo Despertar Group

texts.es:
el grupo solidario el nuevo despertar esta integrado por 3 miembros que tienen su propio negocio y se conocen desde hace varios años. las actividades que ellos realizan son las siguientes:

el sr. Jose Lupario F. tiene 24 años de edad, es casado, tiene 1 hija la cual esta pequeña.
el se dedica a la venta de productos de la canasta basica en la pulperia que tiene desde hace 04 años, esta ubicada en la colonia nueva esperanza de la ciudad de Nacaome y tambien tiene su propio taxi.

el sr. Melvin Armando Almendarez tiene 26 años de edad, es casado, tiene 1 hija.
el se dedica a la venta de ropa y electrodomesticos en el barrio san jose de la ciudad de nacaome desde hace 08 años. para cumplir el objetivo tuvo que vender su producto durante varios años en los diferentes  barrios donde el recide de manera ambulante; hoy en dia tiene su propio carro y sale a vender este producto a diferentes barrios y aldeas de esta ciudad.

la sra. Maria Cleofes C. tiene  41 años de edad, vive en union libre, tiene 3 hijos de los 
cuales 01 esta en USA y le manda ayuda desde hace varios años.
ella se  dedica a la venta de repuestos para bicicleta tiene 04 años de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad.su mayor sueño es vender bicicletas al por mayor.

todos ellos necesitan el credito pra salir adelante con sus negocios y familias.,
texts.en:
The group Nuevo Despertar ("New Awakening") consists of three members who have their own businesses and have known each other for a number of years.

The activities each does is as follows: Mr. Jose Lupario F. is 24 years old, married and has a small daughter. He makes a living selling basic grocery items in the convenience store he has had for the past four years. It is located in the colony of Nueva Esperanza in the city of Nacaome, and he also has his own taxi.

Mr. Melvin Armando Almendarez is 26 years old, married and has a daughter. He has made a living selling clothing and household appliances in the San Jose neighborhood of Nacaome for the past eight years. To reach this point he had to sell his products outdoors for a number of years in different neighborhoods of the city. Currently he has his own car and goes out to sell his products in the different neighborhoods and surrounding areas of the city.

Mrs. Maria Cleofes C. is 41 years old, lives with her common-law husband, and has three children, one of whom is in the United States and has sent aid for a number of years. Maria makes a living selling spare parts for bicycles and has four years experience. Her biggest dream is to sell bicycles wholesale.

All the members are requesting the loan to make headway with their businesses and their families.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various supplies for the members' businesses

loans.name: Judith's Group

texts.en:
T. Judith is a very hardworking lady, who mainly sells bananas. She is a divorced mother of three children, ages 3 – 12 years, and she cares for 2 orphans. Her business is mainly situated in Ishaka town. Her main business challenge is debtors who buy on credit.

Her start-up capital was about 300,000 shillings two years ago, but she now has capital of 5,000,000 shillings. Judith hopes to one day move from retail sales to wholesale. She wants to educate her children up to the highest level using profit from her sales and with the help of loans. At the moment, she needs to add more capital to her business so that she can save for her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale

loans.name: Sabiana

texts.en:
Sabiana is a woman who works hard and diligently to overcome poverty. She is a 69-year-old mother to a son. She lives in the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is happily married to Sabiniano, a fisherman, who is 43 years old.
With her desire to overcome poverty, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 1995. For almost two years now, she has been selling of rice and sugar. Her business has really been good and smooth; it brings her enough proceeds for her family needs.
Now on her 12th loan, she proposes a loan of 30,000 pesos as additional capital for her resale business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for nine sacks of white rice, two sacks of second class rice, for transportation expenses and a slice of her loan will be used as additional capital on her secondary business, basket making.
She believes that the business will grow and bring her enough proceeds for her to save for the future of her children, to renovate her house and to expand her loan.

loans.use: To pay for rice and transportation expenses and as additional capital for secondary business

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda is a woman of faith and determination to rise above poverty. She is 54 years old and mother to five children. She is happily married to Vinancio, an electrician who is 57 years old. She lives in the island village in Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines.
With her desire to step out from poverty, in 1997, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with a bagful of hope of having access to capital for her business. For almost three years, she been doing the Sari-sari Store (General Store) business. And the income is not sufficient to sustain the needs of her family.
Now on her eighth loan, she proposes a loan of 40,000 pesos to pay for a tricycle (rickshaw) to be managed by her husband. Since the use of rickshaw as a means of transportation in the village is in demand, she believes that her new business will click and will bring her enough income.
She dreams of sending her younger children to school and to renovate her house into a more durable and spacious one.

loans.use: To purchase tricycle (rickshaw).

loans.name: Magdalena Asuncion

texts.es: Magdalena de 57 años de edad, es soltera, tiene 3 hijos todos mayores de edad, trabaja como docente en la Escuela Nuevos Horizontes ubicada en el Sistema Penitenciario de Juigalpa donde imparte del pan del saber a los reclusos de ahi desde hace 10 años, tiene 34 años de servicio en Educacion, esta solicitando su credito Nº 17 para mejorar su vivienda cambiando el techo que se encuentra en mal estado, y con las lluvias se le moja parte de los cuartos de su casa.  Cabe señalar que doña Magdalena fue beneficiada con el fondo Kiva en el ultimo credito cancelado, pero lo habia solicitado para su pequeño negocio de venta de ropa y cosmeticos.   Su mayor sueño es mejorar poco a poco su vivienda para vivir con condiciones aunque pequeña cuando se jubile.
texts.en:
Magdalena is 57 years old, single, and has 3 adult children. She is a teacher at the New Horizons School located in the Juigalpa prison system. Sra. Magadalena has been teaching inmates for 10 years and has a total of 34 years of experience in education.

She is requesting her 17th loan to replace the roof of her house. It is in such poor condition that the rooms of her house become soaked whenever it rains. Please note that Sra. Magdalena received a previous Kiva loan for her clothing and cosmetics business. Her greatest dream is to gradually make improvements to her home so that her living conditions are adequate when she retires.

Here is the link to Magdalena’s previous Kiva loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=45364&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replace the roof

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is a native of the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is a 42-year-old mother to two children, a boy and a girl. She is happily married to Gregorio, a fisherman who is 41 years old. She believes that poverty is an opportunity to strive for a better living.
In 1996, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, with hope of having access to capital for her business. For almost three years, she has had a fishing business in partnership with her husband. The business brings good income and sound profit for her family needs.
Now on her eighth loan, she proposes an amount of 25,000 pesos as additional capital for her fishing business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for materials needed to renovate her fishing boat like wood, paint, nails, and labor expenses. A portion of her loan will be used as additional capital for her secondary business, a general store.
She dreams of sending her children to school up to college and building a durable and spacious house.

loans.use: To renovate her fishing boat.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina has two business ventures: a small grocery shop where she sells drinks, sandwiches and snacks, mostly to students from the school across the street, and a cart from which she sells fried chicken and french fries in the evenings from her front porch.  Augustina is pictured here in front of her cart. 

Augustina is 48 years old and is married with four children, only one of whom still depends on her.  She also has two grandchildren.  Augustina's youngest daughter, who is 21, has her own little business making hand-beaded sandals to help support her upcoming university studies.

Augustina has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos since the end of 2007 and used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to invest in her small grocery shop.  Augustina bought her cart for selling fried chicken and french fries with her third loan of 700 soles (about $230).  Augustina plans to use this loan of 1200 soles to purchase goods for both of her businesses.  In particular, she would like to purchase some tables and chairs for the customers who come to eat from her cart in the evenings.

Augustina says that her loans have been helping her grow her businesses bit by bit.  She is careful to save 10 soles every day from her earnings in order to make her monthly loan payments.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for a small grocery shop and for a business selling fried chicken and potatoes

loans.name: Eba

texts.en: Eba S. is from the village of Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Eba owns and operates a fishing business, primarily fishing and selling seafoods to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. In 2008, Eba joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Eba is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to expand her product offering. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the business to use as a reserve for future emergencies. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to expand her product offering

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
The people shown in the picture above are Mrs. Yen H. and her husband with their two young children. Yen H. currently stays at home to be responsible for daily housework like, caring for kids, cooking, and cleaning house. It means that all of the family’s daily expense are contributed by her husband who works in construction.

Yen H. hopes to run a new suitable trade as a grocery seller by using her loan to invest more effectively in this business. She proposes to use some amount of loan to repair and decorate her old house.

loans.use: To start a grocery business and to repair her old house

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: Edna T. is from the village of Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Edna owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Edna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Edna is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Melecia

texts.en:
Melecia is from the busy town of Angono, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is determined to remove her family from the darkness brought by poverty. She is widowed and has two children to take care of.
With her desire to earn an income through a business, in 1999 she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Her loans were used as capital for her Sari-sari store (General Store). She is one of the outstanding members of ASHI . As her business is properly managed, it brings her enough income to sustain the needs of her family.
She is now excited to receive her loan of 25,000 pesos as additional capital for her Store. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for cases of soft drinks, beverages, liquors, canned goods, and groceries. She is hopeful that she can earn more and save for the future of her children, and be able to send them to school until they finish college and find jobs. She also aspires to expand her business.

loans.use: To pay for cases of soft drinks, beverages, liquors, canned goods, and groceries for her store

loans.name: Lloyda

texts.en:
Lloyda sells a little bit of everything, including soft drinks, homemade popsicles, ice, beer, juice, and various local fruits.  On Saturdays she barbecues chicken, for which she sells tickets in advance.  Lloyda either sells her goods from her home or from a small stand in front of her sister-in-law's home on the main road.  Lloyda's neighbors know what she sells, so she has a number of regular customers.    

Lloyda is 32 years old and lives with her partner, who is a painter.  They have two children, 14 and 2.  Lloyda has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about two years and used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to invest in candy for sale.  She still continues to sell candy on occasion, but has since diversified into the sale of other items.  Lloyda plans to invest this loan of 1000 soles in more of the various goods that she sells.

Lloyda feels that her loans from Manuela Ramos have helped her business.  She is currently saving money to refurbish her house -- she would like to take down the wood siding and replace it with brick.  Lloyda also thinks that this loan might be her last for a while -- she feels that loans are a big commitment, one for which she must take all the responsibility.

loans.use: a variety of items for sale, including ice, soft drinks, beer and fruits; also chicken for sale at a BBQ

loans.name: Ana Consuelo

texts.en:
Señora Ana is pictured here with the oldest of her two children.  She is a 32-year-old single mother and has a business selling cooked food in the evenings from the front porch of her home.  Ana lives in the city of Pucallpa.

Ana has been working with Manuela Ramos, a Kiva field partner, for about two years. She belongs to the "Las Romanticas II" communal bank. Ana used her first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to purchase food for her restaurant business and also to purchase shoes which she sells to Pucallpa's prison.  Ana is currently requesting a loan of 1500 soles which she plans to invest in food for her restaurant as well as in beauty products, clothing, and sandals to sell. All of these investments will help her to continue to develop in the microbusiness environment.

Ana is grateful to Manuela Ramos for her loans and for the business education sessions she receives from the organization's loan officers at her communal bank's monthly meetings.

loans.use: Food for restaurant business and beauty products, sandals and clothing to sell

loans.name: Anora

texts.en:
Anora S. is from the village of Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Anora is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Anora owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, selling fish. The main source of income for the business comes from selling fish to local community members. Anora has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Anora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. Anora is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Anora from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase of additional fish to sell

loans.name: Tol

texts.en: Mrs. Tol S. is a farmer in Doem Pour Village in Takeo Province. She owns a piece of land on which she grows rice. She needs a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the field and make her crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. S. Chuon, is a hard-working man. Mrs. Tol S. is 37 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the other stays at home to do housework. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: Needs a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Len

texts.en: Mrs. Len L. lives in Ta Saum Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Eang Khom, is a construction worker. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to provide a good house for their family to live. Thus, Mrs. Len L. has decided to ask for a loan. She will use the loan funds, along with her savings, to build a house for her family. She is 41 years old and the mother of five children One of her children works in a garment factory, three attend the local school, and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband appears in the picture with her.

loans.use: To build a house for her family.

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Soy K. is 27 years old, married and devoted to four children who are students in the local public school. She stays at home to manage the family housework as well as selling some fruit to her villagers for income. She is married to 29-year-old Soun Chen, who helps support the family by running a motor taxi.

Soy K. thinks that it is time to sustain her investment's growth and look for extra revenue, which she proposes to do by selling fruit at the market. She wants to buy a larger quantity of fruit to sell to retailers in the market, but she complains that she doesn’t have a big sized vehicle to transport more fruit.

To achieve her goal, Soy K. has decided to seek a loan in order to purchase a trailer to connect to her existing motorbike so that she can use it to pick up more fruit. She and her husband are pictured at their house.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to connect to their existing motorbike

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mrs. Leng R. lives in Doem Pour Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she grows rice. She faces an obstacle because her field is far from an irrigation system. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy a pump. She will use the rest of money to purchase fertilizer to support the field and to make her crop more productive. Mrs. Leng R. is a 42-year-old widow with four children. One of her children is employed in a garment factory, another is a construction worker, and the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy an irrigation pump and fertilizer to support her rice field

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita hails from the city of Antipolo, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is a 43-year-old mother to three children, a boy and two girls. She is happily married to Renato, who is 46 years old. She knows that poverty is not a hindrance to success, but an opportunity to strive hard for a greener living.

In 2007, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, hoping to alliviate poverty in her family through access to capital for her business. She invested the funds from her first loan in her sari-sari (variety) store. The store brings her enough proceeds to meet the needs of her family.

Now she is excited to recieve a loan of 20,000 pesos to use as additional capital for her store. Specifically, the loan will use to pay for liquor, beverages, charcoal, rice and groceries for her store. She hopes that, with the trust and opportunity given by ASHI and KIVA, she can achieve her dreams of sending her children to school and expanding her business into a grocery store some day.

loans.use: To pay for liquor, beverages, charcoal, rice and groceries for her store.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe M. is from the village of Puntod Lopez Jaena Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Fe is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Fe owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, fishing and selling of fish. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling wild-caught fish to local community members. Fe has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Fe is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Fe from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sambok

texts.en: Mrs. Sambok A. is a farmer in Trapaing Knol Village in Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Thuok SA., sells firewood. Since his business is doing well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Sambok A. is requesting a loan, which she use along with her savings, to buy a horse and cart to transport the firewood to sell. She hopes to increase their income and improve the family's living conditions with this loan. She is 26 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school; the other two are too young to work or study. Her husband and a child appear with her in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy a horse and cart to transport the firewood to sell.

loans.name: Han

texts.en: Mrs. Han T. was born in 1977 and she now lives in Sambuor Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she grows rice. Her husband, Mr. Bin Chea, is a construction worker. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn less income than they need to support their household. In order to improve their lives, Mrs. Han T. is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding.  She has four children. Two of her children attend the local school. The others are just four and three years old. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Thach

texts.en: Mrs. Thach C. lives in Sambour Village in Takeo Province. She sells pork and fish in the local market. She also breeds pigs and chickens. Since her business is doing well, she needs a loan to buy more piglets, pig food, and chickens to breed. Her husband, Mr. Nhem Lo, sells bro houk in the local market. Mrs. Thach C. is 36 years old and the mother of five children. Two of her children work in a garment factory, one attends the local school, and the others are too young to work or study. Her husband and a child appear in the picture with her.

loans.use: Needs a loan to buy more piglets, pig food, and chickens to breed

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is a woman with the determination and faith needed to remove her family from poverty. She is 34 years old and the  mother of two children, a girl and a boy. She lives in Antipolo City, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is happily married to Joel, who is a hired laborer and is also her business partner.

To bring greener living for her family, Alma joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2007. Before her membership in ASHI, she was already reselling live chickens and bath soap. The business brings her income that is sufficient for the needs of her family.

Now she proposes a loan of 10,000 pesos to use as additional capital for her resale business. She is thankful to ASHI and KIVA for the trust and opportunity that they have given to a poor woman like her.

loans.use: As additional capital for her resale business.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is a woman of courage and strong determination. She strives hard to lift her family from poverty. She is 55 years old and mother of three children are of legal age. She is happily married to Santiago, who is 61 years old. She lives in the coastal town of Cardona, Rizal Province in the Philippines.

Opportunity knocks only once, so when she was given the chance to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, she really grabbed it. She is expert in managing a sari-sari (general store) because she has been doing it for ten years. She is happy with the proceeds that she receives from her business.

Now she is proposing a loan of 23,000 pesos as additional capital for her store. Specificallly, the loan will be used to buy 10 sacks of rice, beverages, liquor, cigarettes and groceries for her store. She is optimistic that, with the confidence of ASHI and KIVA, bit by bit, she can achieve her dream of purchasing a housing lot and having savings for her and her husband's future.

loans.use: To buy 10 sacks oof rice, beverages, liqours, cigarettes and groceries for her store.

loans.name: Mr. Peng Leang Heng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty people living in Kampong Trea Village in Kandal Province comprise this village bank loan group. They will use the loan for various purposes. 

Mr. Peng Leang H. is the 42-year-old village bank president. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which he grows vegetables. He faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds. Thus, he has decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family's living conditions with this loan. His wife, Mrs. Tin Tub, is a hard-working woman. This couple has three children who attend the local school. Mrs. H. Leang Hort, the group guarantor, appears in the picture with the group members.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seed

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
Charito is a gifted woman with a talent for sewing. She hails from the coastal town of Cardona, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is mother to three children and lives happily with her husband, Romeo, who is a 35-year-old fisherman.

She believes that one should use her God-given talent to get out of poverty. In 2007, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, hoping to have access to capital for her sewing business. She sews fishing nets for fisherman to buy.

Now on her 4th loan, she proposes a loan of 20,000 pesos as rolling capital for her sewing business. The loan will be used to buy two bundles of fishnets, big spools of thread, and bamboo that she will use to prepare fishing gear. Since fishing is one of the most common sources of income in their town, she hopes that her business will catch the eyes of fishermen. She also dreams of having her own house, sending her children to school, and later, having her own fish pond for much bigger income.

loans.use: To buy two bundles of fishnets, big spools of thread, and bamboo

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhom Vun Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank, which consists of nineteen members. is located in Kampong Trea Village in Takeo Province. Each member plans to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sokhom V. has been selected by the members to be the village bank president. She sells soup to earn income for her family. Since her business is doing well, she needs a loan to purchase more ingredients to make good soup for her customers. She will use the rest of money to buy a piglet to breedi. Her husband, Mr. Muon Ahn, is a hard-working man. Mrs. Sokhom V. is 45 years old and the mother of three children who are blacksmiths. Mr. Kol K. is not borrowing, but his wife is, so she appears in the picture instead of him.

loans.use: To purchase soup ingredients and buy a piglet to breed.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng K. is an older single mother of sixty-eight years old. She has three married sons; two of them are trailer motor-taxi drivers who pick up tourists to visit Angkor Wat Temple in Siem Reap Province, while the other one is a construction worker. All of her children have used their incomes to sustain their family’s expenses and needs.

Seng K. currently works as a 'requirement worker'. She gets hired by farmers to harvest their produce during the mature crop season. Seng K. would like a loan to replace her son’s motor taxi that has broken.

loans.use: To replace her son’s motor taxi that has broken

loans.name: Mrs. Sophath Bou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people living in Thma Kor Village in Kandal Province comprise this village bank loan group. They will use the loan for various purpose. Mrs. Sophath B. is the 39-year-old village bank president. She is a farmer who grows mangoes near her house. She is requesting a loan to buy pesticides to kill insects in the mango field. Her husband, Mr. Vorn Ra, is a mango middleman. This couple has five children, four of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. Mrs. Ny L. is not borrowing, but her husband is, so he is shown in the picture instead. 

All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loans term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy pesticides to kill insects in the mango field.

loans.name: Bengina

texts.en:
Bengina hails from the town of Cardona, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is a 32-year-old mother of five children. She is happily married to a responsible husband, Benigno, who is 39 years old. Being poor is not a hindrance to aim for  greener pastures.

Bengina makes door mats. In 2008, Bengina joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, hoping to access capital for her business. She been in business for two years and she finds contentment in the proceeds that she receives. She has regular customers and she also receives orders.

She is proposing a loan of 15,000 pesos to use as addtional capital for her business. The loan will be used to buy 55 kilos of assorted cloth, a raw material for door mat, as well as scissors. She will also use the loan to pay for her transportation expenses. She hopes that with the kind of business that she has, she can save for the future of her children and even plan to expand her business and hire a labor force.

loans.use: To buy cloth and scissors and pay for transportation expenses.

loans.name: Mimi

texts.en:
Mimi M. is from the village of Masahod. She is 19, is separated from her husband, and has one infant. Mimi operates a clothing business; her main source of income comes from buying and selling clothes in the local community. Mimi has been engaged in her business for 1 year and earns approximately Php2,400.00 a month for these activities.

In June 2009, Mimi joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mimi is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP, which she will invest in expanding her business. This will be the first loan taken out by Mimi from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hing

texts.en:
Hing S., 48, and her husband, Keut Om, 47, are both shown in the photo above. This couple uses their house to run their own business by getting cloth from garment industry to sew into other products in order to charge fees. They typically make a daily revenue of US$ 3 per day to contribute to their family’s daily expenses. They were married years ago and blessed with five children; three of them are working as sewing workers in a garment factory.

Hing S. finds it hard traveling anywhere and she needs to pay a lot of money for it, because she doesn’t have her own vehicle for her and her family’s traveling needs. She has therefore decided to seek a loan to buy a used motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike

loans.name: Mrs. Yom Muong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of seventeen members, is located in Ampov Prey village in Kandal province.  They plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Yom M. is the village bank president, elected by the members. She and her husband, Mr. Ros Sarath, are farmers. They own a plot of land and cultivate both rice and vegetables to earn their living. For rice production, they face an major obstacle: they do not have rice seed. Thus Mrs. Yom M. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, and for fertilizer, to make her crop more productive. She is 53 and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school. Her husband, Mr. Ros Sarath, is in the picture. The husbands of Mrs. Soeurn P. and Mrs. NaR. S. are shown in the picture instead of thE..  

For ten members in this group, the loans are end-of-term loans, while the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows thE. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer to support the field and make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em S., who is twenty-six years old, owns and operates a shop out of her home where she sells a variety of items. She sells cooking ingredients, soft drinks, and some beauty supplies to neighbors who live near her house. She usually generates an income of $5 a day, which helps with her family’s needs, especially feeding her three teenage children who are in school. Her husband stays at home to help conduct her business operations. Em is handling her investment very well. Recently, some of her inventory was exhausted, so she needs to restock.  She is requesting a loan from HKL, one of Kiva's field partners, to purchase soft drinks, sweets for kids, and beauty supplies.

loans.use: To restock soft drinks, sweets for kids, and beauty supplies

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.en:
Vanessa is a native of Cardona, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is 29 and has two boys. She is married to Noel, a fisherman, who is also 29. Vanessa wants to help her husband in earning income for their family.
In 2008, she decided to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She used her previous loans for her fishing business. Since Cardona is a coastal municipality and the main source of income for the people is fishing, she wants to continue her fishing business and continue putting additional investment into it. Now on her third loan, she requests a loan of 14,000 pesos as additional capital for her fishing business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for 10 bundles of fish nets, rope, threads for fishing gear and also for the maintenance of her boat.
She is looking forward for a sustainable and profitable business. She also dreams of having her own house, and to be able to send her children to school until they finish college.

loans.use: To pay for 10 bundles of fish nets, rope, threads for fishing gears and also for the maintenance of her boat.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta T. is from the village of Mialen. She is 45, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Julieta operates a furniture-making business. Her main source of income comes from selling furniture in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for more than 3 years and earns approximately 5,200 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC, which she used to purchase supplies,  including nails and lumber. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which she will use to invest in expanding the business. This will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for furniture making

loans.name: Mrs. Im Nem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-one people living in Tranh village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Im N., who is 50,  is the village bank president. She is a medicine seller. Since she has a lot of customers with many demands, she needs a loan to purchase more medicines to support her customers. Her husband, Mr. B. Khorn, is a farmer who owns a plot of land and cultivates rice. They have two children who are attending the local school. 

Fourteen members in this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Needs a loan to purchase more medicines to support her customers.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie F. is from the village of Canicapan. She is 56, married and has 4 adult children. Elvie raises pigs for sale. Elvie has been engaged in her business for 1 year and earns approximately Php1,000.00 a month.

In 2009, Elvie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
