Elvie requests 3,000 PHP, which she will use to invest in expanding her business. This will be her first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

In 2008, Arcelle joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arcelle repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC, which she used to purchase baby pigs to raise & sell. Arcelle is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be her 4th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhom N., 27, is a villager in Trapaing Thmor village in Takeo province. She is a farmer and owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice. She is also a pig breeder. Since her breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and pig food for breeding. Additionally, she would use the rest of money to buy fertilizer to make her rice crop more productive. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Keo Phorn, is a construction worker. They have a 3 year-old child. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: By purchasing more piglets and pig food for  breeding and to buy fertilizer to make her rice crop more productive.

loans.name: Run

texts.en:
Mr. Run K. lives in Orn Daung Samrith village in the Takeo province. He is a house builder who makes a small income to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Mom Kiv, is a farmer. 

Mr. Run K. is 50 years old and the father of five children, three of whom are employed in different positions while the others are attending the local school. Since his children's workplace is far from home, he decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for his children to go to work. His wife is on the left side of photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for his children to go to work

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli is a native of Carodona, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 59 years old and married to Edmeciano, who is also her business partner. She is a mother of three. All of her children have their own families already, but the perseverance for earning a living is still burning within her.

With her desire to have income, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2008. Her previous loan was used as capital for her secondary business in the resale of toys for kids. But just recently, she opted to change her business to fish selling. She is positive that her business will grow and will bring her enough proceeds to live on.

Now on her second loan, she proposes an amount of 10,000 pesos as starting capital for her proposed business of fish selling. The loan will be used to pay for 120 kilos of assorted fish. She is looking forward to having a space in the market someday and also to renovating her house into more spacious and more durable one.

loans.use: To pay for 120 kilos of assorted fish

loans.name: Mzabibu Group

texts.en:
Mwampombe is a member of the Mzabibu borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 32-year-old woman. She is separated from her husband and she is the mother of two children. Her children are 17 and 12 years old. She also cares for one other dependent.
Mwampombe started her own business selling clothes one year ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania Shillings. This is Mwampombe’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 TSH in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Mwampombe hopes to save money and expand her business. Rosemary, Ester, Moshi, and Johana are also members of the Mzabibu borrower group. They also requested 200,000 TSH each in order to support their own business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is a 41-year-old mother of four. The eldest son is 19 years old and in college while the youngest is a one-year-old girl. She lives in Tanay, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is hardworking and optimistic that she can bring her family out of poverty.
The courage and persistence to get out of poverty is burning in her. In 2003, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFi and KIVA partner in the Philippines, hoping to have access to capital for her business resale. Her previous loans were carefully spent on resale of silver jewelry and frozen foods. The business is well managed and it brings her enough income to sustain her family needs.
Now she proposes a loan of 45,000 pesos as additional rolling capital for her business. The loan will be used to pay for silver rings, earrings, necklaces, ladies' and men's bracelets, dressed chicken, pork and rice, all for resale.
She is hopeful that with the trust and confidence given by ASHI and KIVA, she can have her own silver shop someday and also be able to sustain the needs of her children in school.

loans.use: To pay for silver rings, earings, necklace, ladies and men's bracelets also dressed chicken, pork and rice.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna I. is from the village of Yahong. She is 39 years old. Edna is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Edna operates a business venture raising pigs for sale. Edna has been engaged in her business for three years and earns approximately Php1,600.00 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Edna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna is requesting a loan amounting to 3,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Edna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

The main source of income for the business comes from selling food products in the local community. Jorja has been engaged in her business for a year and earns approximately 1,500 Philippine pesos (about $31) a month for these activities.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene comes from a family who experienced poverty. Now that she is the mother of five, she doesn't want her children to experience the life that she had. She is 43 years old and married to Lydio, a carpenter. She lives in Morong, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

With her innate desire to remove her family from poverty, in 2004 Arlene joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She was very careful and wise in spending her loans and invested them in her resale business. Her business brings her income that can sustain the needs of her family, specially of her children.

Just recently, Arlene requested a loan of 20,000 pesos as additional rolling capital for her resale business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for fifty kilos of peanuts, rice, charcoal, bananas and vegetables, all for resale. She hopes that her business will grow and will bring her enough profit for her to achieve her dreams: to educate her children and also to build her own house.

loans.use: To pay for 50 kilos of peanuts, rice, charcoal and bananas

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita, a 38-year-old mother to four boys and three girls, is married to Dominador, an electrician. She lives in Morong, Rizal Province in the Philippines, where she operates a sari-sari store.

With her aspiration to rise above poverty, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2004. Her previous loans have been wisely spent on her store, and the business is running smoothly, her loyal customers consisting mainly of her village neighbors. Nenita is now requesting a loan of 20,000 pesos as her sixth loan from ASHI to buy five sacks of rice, one sack sugar, 20 sacks of charcoal, and groceries for her store. Her investments in her store yield sound profits which help her meet the needs of her family.

She dreams of expanding her business into a much bigger grocery store and sending her children to school up to the college level.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her store.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is a mother with the determination to give a decent life to her children. She is 41 years old and married to Donato. She is the mother to two boys. She lives in Jala-jala, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

Life was not easy for Sofia, just depending on the insufficient salary of her husband. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, hoping to have an opportunity to open a business. Her previous loan was wisely invested in her sari-sari store (general store) business. The store sells smoothly and well but the income from the store is not sufficient to sustain the needs of her family. She needs to think of another business in which to invest her next loan.

Now Sofia requests a loan of 15,000 as starting capital for her primary business selling rice. The amount will be used to pay for thirty-eight sacks of rice and payment for transportation expenses. From the field, after harvesting rice, farmers will sell rice to her and, for her profit, she will resell it to another businessmen with a much higher price than she paid.

Sofia dreams of having a grocery store someday and space in the market for a retail business.

loans.use: To pay for 38 sacks of rice and transportation expenses

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
Felicidad is 43 years old and the motivation to remove her family from poverty is still burning within her. She is the mother of two: a boy and a girl, and is married to Ediardo who is an electrician and is 50 years old. She lives in Jala-jala, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

In 2008, with her need for rolling capital for her business selling rice, Felicidad joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She carefully invested her previous loans in the resale of rice. People come to her to buy rice every day, every hour, since it is the staple food for Filipinos. And she is happy with the profits she receives that she knows are of great help to her family.

Now Felicidad requests a loan of 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her business, specifically to pay for ten sacks of rice and for transportation expenses. In the future, she hopes that she can rent a space in the market for her resale business and also send her children to school until college.

loans.use: To pay for ten sacks of rice and transportation expenses

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine D. is from the village of Upper Loboc, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is forty-four years old. Josephine is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a service-based business, providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $65 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Josephine joined one of Kiva's field partners, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from GDMPC. Now Josephine is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services she provides. This is her fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is a natiive of Pililia, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 46 years old and determined to bring her eight children out of poverty. She is married to Braulio, who is 55 years old.

With her desire to step out from the spiral of poverty, in 2008 she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She is hopeful to have access to capital for her business selling food, such as pork barbeque, grilled hot dogs, fish balls and other similar foods. She uses her tri-bike as a cart in roaming around the village. Her business is a favorite of kids during the afternoon, and the men who are drinking beer buy barbeque.

Alicia is now on her third loan. She proposes to borrow 14,000 pesos to pay for one sidecar, pork, hot dogs, fish balls, frying pans, and a stove. She hopes that through her business, she can reach her dreams of sending her children to school until college and of renovating her house to make it more spacious and durable.

loans.use: To buy a sidecar, pork, hotdogs, fishballs, frying pans, and a stove

loans.name: Mam

texts.en: Mam Y. is thirty-five years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province, where she lives with other family members in an old medium-sized wooden house. She currently relies on planting rice to earn a living. One part of the family income comes from her husband, who builds wooden boats. Also, he has been hired by neighbors to build and repair their fishing boat. Their daughter and son are in school and are dependent on Mam Y.'s income. She has a problem with transportation because she doesn’t own a vehicle. Therefore, she is taking out a loan to buy a motorbike for her family’s travel needs. She will use some of the loan to repair her old house that leaks and breaks down when heavy rains fall. Mam Y. and both of her children are pictured here.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her family’s travel needs

Neang's husband is a fisherman.  To help with the family income, Neang grows rice and also feeds a few pigs she keeps in a stall near her house. She will use the loan to buy extra fertilizers to improve her rice crop.

loans.name: Gulzat's Group

texts.en: Gulzat, 33, is the group leader. She is an excellent example of a woman who never hesitates to try something that she has never done before. Quite unfamiliar with keeping a household, Gulzat, ever since she inherited a cow from her parents, has kept it for its milk. She even started growing clover on a piece of land and selling the excess, thus starting to make decent profits. Eventually these profits have helped her take care of her three children. Gulzat’s husband works as a secondary school teacher and, naturally, this business of hers has been quite an important contribution to the family budget. All her children take an active part in helping her look after the cow and farm the land. At present, she manages to make 35 dollars a month. After saving this money, she has bought a car and some domestic equipment. Now Gulzat needs a loan to conduct some repairs and renovation work at her house. After that, she has already made up her mind on building a new shed for her cattle. Nasihat, 38, is a housewife. Nevertheless, along with her domestic chores, she sells milk that her cow yields. She also works in her vegetable garden. Nasihat would like to increase the amount of milk she has for sale. However, she needs a loan to buy a cow, as her earnings are not enough to save. Sherik, 44, is engaged in cattle raising: fattening and reselling livestock and selling milk. He has three children and a caring wife. Striving to improve the living standards of his family, Sherik has started building a house. Zhanyl, 36, is a housewife and mother of three children. Her regular job is making national rugs and matting to order. In future she plans to keep cows and start selling milk. Mirgul, 46, is married and has three children. She and her husband, own one hectare (2.5 acres) of land, where they grow corn. Also they sell milk. Now they need a loan to purchase two calves for fattening and resale. Sherik, Zhanyl and Mirgul need loans to purchase calves for fattening and resale. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Maktym's Group

texts.en:
Maktym, 32, is the group’s leader. Her husband is a builder. He works in Russia and sends money to his family. As for her, she deals in clothes. Mainly she sells children’s and teenager's clothes. Upon moving to another city, about four years ago, she was fortunate enough to meet a new neighbor, who suggested she start a business of trading in clothes. Her neighbor even lent her $120 of initial capital to begin.

Now Maktym earns $470 a month. Along with her work she raises four children alone, as her husband is away. However, due to her business, they have been able to furnish their house, purchase domestic products, sell the car and buy out the container where she works. Before fall starts Maktym is keen to obtain a loan to purchase more clothes to broaden the assortment and attract more customers. In future, Maktym and her husband plan to buy a big house and a car. They also want to build a new shop next to their house and breed cattle.

Muktarali is the father of three children. He works in the market with his daughter. They sell seasonal clothes. Muktarali needs to obtain a loan so that he can purchase more clothes: shirts with long sleeves, duffels and warm pants. He is desperate to provide an opportunity for his daughter to go to college.

Kibira, 37, sells manufactured goods: CD’s, DVD’s sunglasses, etc. Her husband is a taxi driver. They have four children. Kibira needs to purchase more goods but to do that, she needs a loan.

Chyngyz, 24, has two children. To provide for his family, he sells women’s, men’s and children’s shoes. He was lucky to buy out a container. He is thinking of doing some refurbishment in his house. Chyngyz needs a loan to purchase more shoes.

Lira, 36, a mother of five children, trades in light industry products: women’s gowns, T-shirts, and shoes. Lira needs a loan to purchase gowns, pants and galoshes. Her ultimate dream is to live in a big house and give her children a proper education.

============================= --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and shoes for several stores

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry and to provide a well for the irrigation of her greenhouse

loans.name: Gulnar's Group

texts.en: Gulnar, 52, is a widow with five children. Two of her daughters and a son live separately. She lives with one daughter, a college student and a younger son, who is disabled. Gulnar is their sole provider. When Gulnar got married, she was given a cow as a wedding gift. Then she began growing barley and clover on her land. Now, along with farming, she even purchases sheep for fattening and resale. Her daughter helps her look after the cattle and the farm. During twenty years of exerting gigantic labor and efforts she has built a house, bought a car and paid for her children’s education. Her monthly income consists of 250 dollars. The academic year is starting in a month and Gulnar does not have funds to pay for her daughter’s college education. She would be very happy to obtain a loan. Some of her other plans include purchasing fuel and lubricants needed for harvesting crops of barley and clover as she will sell them according to her needs and use the proceeds to repair her house. Also she is making preparations for the marriage of her daughter and is saving money for her daughter’s dowry. These are Gulnar’s partners: Asel, 24, is a saleswoman in a duty-free shop. She is enrolled in college as an external student. She decided to apply for a loan to pay for her education. Kerimbek, 47, works as a livestock breeder in a cooperative association and also grows clover and corn. He wants to obtain a loan for purchasing two calves to raise. Alchakul, 47, is a widow and the mother of four children. She has her own land and grows corn and clover. She needs a loan to buy a calf and to put new gates on her house. Anarkul, 47, has two children. Her house is under repair and she needs a loan to purchase cement and to buy a heifer. Anara is the deputy leader of this group. She is married and has raised five children. She keeps cows and sells milk. She needs a loan to buy two calves for sending to pasture and selling them upon return. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's education

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam Y. is a modest villager living in Kompong Tom Province. She is fifty-one years old and married with two children, one of whom is married and one is attending school. Sam Y. generates her daily income by selling snack cakes and other grocery items to neighbors and passers-by. She started her business years ago and makes a daily profit of around $4. Since her husband’s business of driving a horse-cart taxi is not going well, Sam Y. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase a used motorbike which her husband can use for his taxi service. She and her husband appear in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorbike for her husband’s taxi service

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
To break the wall of poverty that hinders her and her family's way to success is the greatest aspiration of Fe. She is married to Perfecto, who is a vendor and is 60 years old. She has five children to take good care of. She lives in Pililia, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

In 2008, Fe joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, hoping to have access to capital for her business operating a sari-sari store (general store). Since then, her business brings her enough proceeds for her family needs. It's her neighbors who are her avid customers.

Now she seeks a loan of 10,000 pesos as additional capital for her store. The amount will be used to pay for sacks of sugar, beverages, cooking oil and groceries.

She hopes that with the support of ASHI and Kiva, little by little, she can reach her dreams in life: to send her children to school until college and to expand her business into a bigger grocery store.

loans.use: To pay for sacks of sugar, beverages, cooking oil and groceries

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in the pig business.

loans.name: Nurzat's Group

texts.en:
Nurzat is the group’s leader. For a 25 year old woman, having two little kids, her occupation is quite unusual; cattle breeding. She purchases livestock, mainly calves, fattens them up and resells them. Her husband works as a controller in a correctional facility. Four years ago, they got their vacation pay, about six hundred dollars and purchased three calves. It took a year to feed and resell them, and increased their total number to nine. After selling all of them, they bought a flat!

Nurzat hopes to obtain a loan to purchase construction materials and materials for interior decoration of their new flat and two sheep. The two sheep are for family needs. Nurzat and her husband are making grandiose plans of furnishing their flat and buying a new car. With their passion and determination everything seems to be possible.

Here are Nurzat’s partners, all of whom are just over twenty. Asan is 21. In spite of his age, he has earned his family’s confidence as an independent entrepreneur. He works as a controller and raises cattle and farms land, growing tomatoes and pepper. He needs a loan to purchase calves for feeding.

Venera is a divorced woman. To provide for her four year old son and retired mother, she raises livestock. She also works as a controller. She needs a loan to buy a calf.

Nurgul is married and has one child. She is also engaged in cattle reselling. Along with her husband, they are building a house. Nurgul needs a loan to purchase slag stones, necessary for building. She is making plans to build a big shed for cattle.

Rasulbek is married and lives with his parents. He grows barley on a piece of land. He also keeps cows and raises calves. He hopes to obtain a loan to purchase sheep and buy a car. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: Purchase calves, sheep and cows, as well as construction materials.

loans.name: Thi

texts.en: Thi N. is thirty-two years old and works at raising pigs to sell, earning about $3 a day. She is married with two children, both of whom are students and live at home. Her husband, Mr. Hay Hang, is thirty-five years old and sells wood for carving that he finds in the forest. He has trouble picking up and moving his firewood, because he doesn’t have laborers to help. Therefore, Thi N. has decided to seek a loan to buy a water buffalo to help with transporting her husband’s firewood. She will also use this buffalo to help plow their farmland.

loans.use: To buy a water buffalo to help transport her husband’s firewood

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a 34 year old mother of four who lives and operates her small fish business in Kayole Nairobi. She is asking for a loan of Ksh. 20,000 to increase her stock of fish. She hopes that she will grow her business and diversify into hairdressing and selling clothes. She also hopes to build her own home and educate her children. She describes herself as friendly, thankful and faithful.

---------------------------------------
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie hails from the busy town of Cardona in the Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 29 years old and married to a construction worker. She has three children to take good care of. She is young and full of the energy needed to run a business.

With her desire to start a business, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2008. With her first loan, she started a business making doormats. The business is going well.

Now she is about to receive her second loan of 10,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. The loan will buy 20 kilos of assorted cloth, scissors and cover transportation expenses for doormat making.

Margie hopes to make her business grow. She also dreams of sending her children to college and wants to buy a house and lot of her own.

loans.use: Buy cloth, scissors to weave doormats.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Add stock of flour, beans and maize

loans.name: Kean

texts.en: Kean L. is forty-eight years old and a single mother of four children.  One is married and the others are single and working in different occupations. She is a local farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows rice. She planted her rice months ago but it is not growing well due to the lack of fertilizer. Kean is taking out a loan to buy fertilizer and will use it to make her crop more productive. She will also use some of the loan to fix a ladder at her house that is in poor repair. She and her grandchildren appear in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice crop

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida hails from the beautiful town of Cardona, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is 61 years old and the mother of three. All of her children are already of legal age except her youngest daughter who is 15 years old. Zenaida is married to Constantino who is 65 years old and a ministry pastor.

In 2008, Zenaida joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippiines, with a bagful of dreams to overcome poverty. Her first loan was used as additional capital for her current business of sewing. She has a lot of regular customers and she accepts orders too. The business has really helped her since her children are still kids.

Now Zenaida requests a loan of 10,000 pesos as additonal capital for her business. She proposes to purchase ten kilos of assorted clothes and to pay for transportation expenses. A portion of her loan will be spent on her secondary business selling charcoal and rice.

Zenaida is optimistic that her business will grow, especially now that she has access to capital. She hopes to send her youngest child to school up to college level and also to expand her business and hire a labor force.

loans.use: To purchase ten kilos of clothes plus transportation and to buy charcoal and rice

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita A., 48, has seven children. Through her handwork, her husband's her eldest child has graduated from college. Clarita's business has been of great help to sustain the education of their children. Every month, she receives money from her daughter.

She had a livestock raising business. In 2001, Clarita became a member of ASHI. It was hard for Clarita to accept the fact that she can't give her children the right education. But with her membership in ASHI she is hopeful that someday her business will grow and produce a big profit.

She planned to purchase cattle and pigs to raise in her backyard, surrounded by verdant grass which is good for cattle and less populated and good for raising pigs.

loans.use: Livestock raising and selling business.

loans.name: Тошбиби

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Тошбиби – женщина , которая занимается продажей пшеницы. Ей 65 лет , она мать пятерых детей. Полностью занимается этим бизнесом. Товар ей привозят сельские поставщики. Тошбиби закупив по оптовой цене перепродаёт с наценкой в розницу.
Её мужа нет в живых, поэтому Тошбиби сама вместе с сыновьями несёт семейные расходы. Один из сыновей помогает ей по бизнесу, замещает её в дни её отдыха.
Для закупа оптом пшеницы Тошбиби хочет получить кредит.

loans.use: на закуп товара , пшеницы

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy poultry.

loans.name: Morgana

texts.en:
Morgana is 35 years old and lives in Cardona, in the Philippines. She is mother to four; two boys and two girls. She is married to Simeon who is tricycle driver.

She is tired of being poor. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines to gain access to capital for her business. Her previous loans were carefully used in her current "general store" business. The business had helped them meet their daily needs.

Now she hopes for a loan of 15,000 pesos for her store. The loan will be used to pay for two sacks of rice, soft drinks, liquors, groceries and transportation expenses.

She is positive that her business will grow bigger since they have access to capital through ASHI and KIVA. She believes she can reach her dreams to send her children to school until college, and to expand her business into a much bigger store.

loans.use: Buy store supplies to sell.

loans.name: Chou

texts.en: Chou is twenty-nine years old and sells supplies from her home to the farmers in the village. She sells items like fertilizer, animal feed, and medicines for animals. She also raises pigs for slaughtering in a pen behind her house.  Another source of family income comes from her husband who distills white wine.  He also provides a service for a fee of hulling his neighbors' rice on his milling machine. Chou says that she manages her investment more successfully as the number of her regular customers increases. Recently, some of her supplies have been exhausted, so she wants to restock and is requesting a loan from Kiva’s partner, HKL, to purchase twenty-five sacks of fertilizer and a variety of other farm supplies to sell.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fertilizer and other farm supplies to sell

loans.name: Mr. Ngean Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank which consists of thirteen members is located in Ta Nu village in Kandal province. They plan to use the loan which they obtained in different purposes. Mr. Ngean C. is the village bank president, selected by the members. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates both rice and vegetables to earn a living.

In his vegetable growing, he faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to grow vegetables on the field. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. His wife, Mrs. Lang Poung, is a pig breeder. Mr. Ngean C. has three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school. Mrs. Yoem K. did not come to take the loan but her husband did, so he is shown in the picture.

loans.use: to grow vegetables in his field

loans.name: Музафар

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Музафар мужчина 31 года, женат имеет троих детей. Музафар занимается торговлей сезонной продукцией овощами и фруктами. Т.к.  сейчас сезонн арбузов и дынь, поэтому Музаффар сейчас продаёт арбузы и дыни. 
Товар завозит Музафар с Душанбе на Камазе, вместе с братом, поэтому он экономит на транспортных расходах. Получив кредит Музаффар хочет съездить за товаром и привезти одну партию арбузов и дынь.

loans.use: на закуп оптом арбуза

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in her pig and poultry business

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia A. is 56 years old and has six children, ranging in age from 39 to 25 years old. Three of them have their own families at present while three are still single and still live with Lilia, together with her husband Emelio. Emilio is a farmer while Lilia is an artist who weaves traditional sleeping mats made of "pandan" leaves called "banig" and traditional bags made of twigs and "abaka" (a kind of palm different from "pandan") fiber. This has been the kind of livelihood Lilia has worked at from 40 years ago up to the present. Her membership in ASHI in 2006 enabled her to support and grow her business as well as the needs of her family, including the needs of her grandchildren.

Lilia's children have learned the kind of business their mother generated her income from to support their needs since they were young. Now, they are helping their mother in the business and with Lilia's loan from ASHI, she can support the growth of her business and meet the demand of her customers. In the future, she wishes to reach the maximum amount of loan that ASHI can offer to really expand her business and generate employment within her community. For now, her loan will be used to purchase necessary materials for her business and produce a bigger volume of items than she could produce before, since her loan amount has increased.

loans.use: Buying "Pandan" (a kind of palm) leaves and other native materials to be used in her handicrafts

loans.name: Vun

texts.en: Vun T. is thirty-four years old and married with three school-age children, all of whom help with their parents' businesses when they are not studying. Vun makes a living by climbing palm trees to tap the palm juice for selling.  He also sells carving wood. For extra income, his wife fattens feeder pigs to sell.  This couple will also raise a crop of rice during the coming farming season. Vun requests a loan to buy additional piglets for his wife to raise, and he will use the remainder of the loan to buy fertilizer to improve his rice crop yield. Vun T. and his wife are pictured above at their home.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets for his wife to raise

loans.name: Mr. Choum Chev Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fifteen people living in Ta Nu village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan group, and they will use the loan for various purpose. Mr. Choum C. is the 37-year-old village bank president. He is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare field where he cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Toek Lat, is employed in a garment factory.

Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn not enough income to improve the family's living conditions. In order to improve the living conditions, Mr. Choum C. is requesting a loan to buy piglets to raise. He is the father of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the younger one is too young to work or study.

Note: Mrs. Srou C. did not come to take her loan but her husband did, so he is shown in the picture instead.

loans.use: to buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in her poultry-raising and pig business

loans.name: Mrs. Thol Korn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank group which consists of seventeen members is located in Ta Nu village in Kandal province, and they plan to use the loan which they obtained for different purposes. Mrs. Thol K. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is employed in a garment factory. She is also a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding.

Mrs. Thol K. is 31 years old and the mother of a child who is attending the local school.

Note: Mr. Sen S. did not come to take the loan but his wife did, so she is present in the picture instead.

loans.use: to buy more piglets to raise
